webTitle: Querying the Koran

fields.headline: Querying the Koran
fields.standfirst: Orthodox Muslims believe that this ancient Islamic text is the unchanging Word of God. One scholar is daring to question it
fields.trailText: Orthodox Muslims believe that this ancient Islamic text is the unchanging Word of God. One scholar is daring to question it.
fields.body:
A German academic fears a violent backlash from orthodox Muslims because of his "blasphemous" theory that the Koran has been changed and revised. Such a backlash is not to be taken lightly; the Salman Rushdie affair is a solemn reminder of the power of an angry Muslim community. After the author wrote his novel Satanic Verses, which was considered by Muslims to be blasphemous, a fatwa , or religious decree, was pronounced against him in 1989 that left him fearing for his life. Rushdie has only recently reappeared in public after nearly 10 years in hiding.

According to Muslim belief, the Koran is the eternal, unaltered Word of God, which has remained the same for 14 centuries.

But Dr Gerd R Puin, a renowned Islamicist at Saarland University, Germany, says it is not one single work that has survived unchanged through the centuries. It may include stories that were written before the prophet Mohammed began his ministry and which have subsequently been rewritten.

Puin's conclusions have sparked angry reactions from orthodox Muslims. "They've said I'm not really the scholar to make any remarks on these manuscripts," he said.

The semitic philologist, who specialises in Arabic calligraphy and Koranic palaeography, has been studying Sa'na manuscripts, ancient versions of the Koran discovered in Sa'na, the capital of Yemen.

So controversial are his findings that the Yemeni authorities have denied him further access to the manuscripts.

He says they shed new light on the early development of the Koran as a book with a "textual history", which contradicts the fundamental Muslim belief that it is the unchanging Word of God.

Any questioning of the authenticity of the Koranic text as the Word of God can expect a hostile reaction. The fatwa , or death sentence, was issued against Rushdie for hinting in Satanic Verses that the Koran may include verses from other sources - chiefly Satan.

Academics offering radical interpretations of the Koran put their lives at risk. In 1990, Dr Nasr Abu Zaid, formerly a lecturer in Koranic Studies at Cairo University, provoked a national outcry in Egypt over his book The Concept of the Text. There were death threats from Muslim extremists, general public harassment, and in 1995 he was branded an apostate by Egypt's highest court. The court forced him to divorce his wife because under Islamic law, marriage between an apostate and a Muslim is forbidden.

Zaid's proposal was arguably less radical than Puin's. Zaid's book argued that "the Koran is a literary text, and the only way to understand, explain, and analyse it is through a literary approach". A Muslim, Zaid remained in Egypt for a time to refute the apostasy charges, but fled with his wife to Holland in the face of increasing death threats.

Puin believes that he will not receive the same reaction, because unlike Zaid or Rushdie he does not have a Muslim name.

His claim that the Koran has changed since its supposed standardisation, and that pre-Islamic texts have crept in, would nonetheless be regarded as highly blasphemous by Muslims. He has not yet written a book on his radical findings, but says it is "a goal to achieve" in the near future.

Dr Tarif Khalidi, lecturer in Islamic Studies at Cambridge University, warns that the book may generate a controversy similar to Satanic Verses. "If Dr Puin's views are taken up and trumpeted in the media, and if you don't have many Muslims being rational about it, then all hell may break loose."

Khalidi fears Muslims will not accept Puin's work on the Sa'na manuscripts as having been done with academic objectivity, but see it as a deliberate "attack on the integrity of the Koranic text".

The manuscripts, thought to be the oldest surviving copies of the Koran, were discovered in the ancient Great Mosque of Sa'na in 1972, when the building was being restored after heavy rainfall, hidden in the loft in a bundle of old parchment and paper documents. They were nearly thrown away by the builders, but were spotted by Qadhi Isma'il al-Akwa, then president of the Yemeni Antiquities Authority, who saw their importance and sought international assistance to preserve and examine them.

Al-Akwa managed to interest Puin, who was visiting Yemen for research purposes in 1979. Puin in turn persuaded the German government to organise and fund a restoration project. The restoration revealed that some of the parchment pages dated from the seventh and eighth centuries, the crucial first two centuries of Islam, from which very few manuscripts have survived.

Until now, there were three ancient copies of the Koran. One copy in the Library of Tashkent in Uzbekistan, and another in the Topkapi Museum in Istanbul, Turkey, date from the eighth century. A copy preserved in the British Library in London, known as the Ma'il manuscript, dates from the late seventh century. But the Sa'na manuscripts are even older. Moreover, the Sa'na manuscripts are written in a script that originates from the Hijaz - the region of Arabia where the prophet Mohammed lived, which makes them not only the oldest to have survived, but one of the earliest copies of the Koran ever.

Puin noticed minor textual variations, unconventional ordering of the chapters (surahs), as well as rare styles of orthography. Then he noticed that the sheets were palimpsests - manuscripts with versions written even earlier that had been washed off or erased.

These findings led Dr Puin to assert that the Koran had undergone a textual evolution. In other words, the copy of the Koran that we have is not the one believed to have been revealed to the prophet.

This is something that Muslims would find offensive.The idea that the Koran is the literal Word of God, unchanging and permanent, is crucial to Islam.The traditional Muslim view holds that the Koran was revealed to Mohammed by God in fragments between 610 and 632 AD. The revealed verses were "recorded on palm leaves and flat stones and in the hearts of men [meaning memorised]," and remained in this state during the prophet's lifetime.

About 29 years after Mohammed's death during the rule of the third Muslim caliph, Uthman, a standard copy of the Koran in a book form, was made, because already divergent readings and copies were circulating in the growing Islamic empire. This Uthmanic recension, according to the Muslim view, was produced with meticulous care, based on earlier copies of the Koran made according to the instructions of the prophet.

Orthodox Muslims insist that no changes have occurred to the Koran since the Uthmanic recension. But this view is challenged by the Sa'na manuscripts, which date from shortly after the Uthmanic recension.

"There are dialectal and phonetical variations that don't make any sense in the text", says Puin. "The Arabic script is very defective - even more so in the early stages of its literature."

Like other early Arabic literature, the Sa'na Koran was written without any diacritical marks, vowel symbols or any guide to how it should be read, says Puin. "The text was written so defectively that it can be read in a perfect way only if you have a strong oral tradition." The Sa'na text, just like other early Korans, was a guide to those who knew it already by memory, he says. Those that were unfamiliar with the Koran would read it differently because there were no diacritical and vowel symbols.

As years went by, the correct reading of the Koran became less clear, he says. People made changes to make sense of the text. Puin gives as example Hajjaj bin Yusuf, governor of Iraq from 694-714 AD, who "was proud of inserting more than 1,000 alifs [first letter of the Arabic alphabet] in the Koranic text".

Professor Allen Jones, lecturer in Koranic Studies at Oxford University, agrees.

"Hajjaj is also responsible for putting the diacritical marks in the Koran. His changes are a defining moment in the history of the Koran".

After Hajjaj's changes in around the 700s, "the Koranic text became pretty stable", he says.

Puin accepts this up to a point, but says that certain words and pronunciations were standardised in the ninth century. He says the Uthmanic text was the skeleton upon which "many layers of interpretation were added" - causing the text to change.

This is blasphemy, according to orthodox Muslims, and is not entirely accepted by other academics.

Jones admits there have been "trifling" changes made to the Uthmanic recension. Khalidi says the traditional Muslim account of the Koran's development is still more or less true. "I haven't yet seen anything to radically alter my view," he says.

He believes that the Sa'na Koran could just be a bad copy that was being used by people to whom the Uthmanic text had not reached yet. "It's not inconceivable that after the promulgation of the Uthmanic text, it took a long time to filter down."

Puin's other radical theory is that pre-Islamic sources have entered the Koran. He argues that two tribes it mentions, As-Sahab-ar-Rass (Companions of the Well) and the As- Sahab-al-Aiqa (Companions of the Thorny Bushes) are not part of the Arab tradition, and the people of Mohammed's time certainly did not know about them.

"These are very unspecific names, whereas other tribes are specifically mentioned," said Dr Puin.

His researches have shown that the ar-Rass lived in pre-Islamic Lebanon and the al-Aiqa in the Aswan region of Egypt around 150AD, according to the Atlas of Ptolemy. He argues that pre-Islamic sources entered the Koran, presumably when the growing Islamic empire came into contact with those regions and sources.

Khalidi says finding pre-Islamic registers in the Koran does not discredit the Muslim belief in any way, because it does not threaten the integrity of the Koran. "The Koran was revealed at a particular time in the vocabulary of the age", he says.

Puin also questions another sacred belief that Muslims hold about the Koran, that it was written in the purest Arabic. He has found many words of foreign origin in the text, including the word "Koran" itself. Muslim scholars explain the "Koran" to mean recitation, but Puin argues that it is actually derived from an Aramaic word, qariyun, meaning a lectionary of scripture portions appointed to be read at divine service. He says the Koran contains most of the biblical stories but in a shorter form and is "a summary of the Bible to be read in service".

Orthodox Muslims have always held that the Koran is a scripture in its own right, and never a shortened version of the Bible, even if both texts contain the same prophetic tradition.

Khalidi says he is weary of constant attempts by western Islamicists to analyse the Koran in a parallel way to the Bible. Puin, however, sees the need for a "scientific text" of the Koran, and this is what he intends to achieve. He says that Muslims believe that "the Koran has been worked on a thousand years ago" and "is not a topic anymore".

Not all Muslim reaction to him has been hostile. Salim Abdullah, director of the German Islamic Archives, affiliated to the powerful pan-Islamic Muslim World League, has given him a positive response.

"He asked me if I could give him the permission to publish one of my articles on the Sa'na manuscripts", said Puin. Warned of the possible controversy it could raise, he replied: "I am longing for this kind of discussion on this topic."
fields.bodyText: A German academic fears a violent backlash from orthodox Muslims because of his "blasphemous" theory that the Koran has been changed and revised. Such a backlash is not to be taken lightly; the Salman Rushdie affair is a solemn reminder of the power of an angry Muslim community. After the author wrote his novel Satanic Verses, which was considered by Muslims to be blasphemous, a fatwa , or religious decree, was pronounced against him in 1989 that left him fearing for his life. Rushdie has only recently reappeared in public after nearly 10 years in hiding. According to Muslim belief, the Koran is the eternal, unaltered Word of God, which has remained the same for 14 centuries. But Dr Gerd R Puin, a renowned Islamicist at Saarland University, Germany, says it is not one single work that has survived unchanged through the centuries. It may include stories that were written before the prophet Mohammed began his ministry and which have subsequently been rewritten. Puin's conclusions have sparked angry reactions from orthodox Muslims. "They've said I'm not really the scholar to make any remarks on these manuscripts," he said. The semitic philologist, who specialises in Arabic calligraphy and Koranic palaeography, has been studying Sa'na manuscripts, ancient versions of the Koran discovered in Sa'na, the capital of Yemen. So controversial are his findings that the Yemeni authorities have denied him further access to the manuscripts. He says they shed new light on the early development of the Koran as a book with a "textual history", which contradicts the fundamental Muslim belief that it is the unchanging Word of God. Any questioning of the authenticity of the Koranic text as the Word of God can expect a hostile reaction. The fatwa , or death sentence, was issued against Rushdie for hinting in Satanic Verses that the Koran may include verses from other sources - chiefly Satan. Academics offering radical interpretations of the Koran put their lives at risk. In 1990, Dr Nasr Abu Zaid, formerly a lecturer in Koranic Studies at Cairo University, provoked a national outcry in Egypt over his book The Concept of the Text. There were death threats from Muslim extremists, general public harassment, and in 1995 he was branded an apostate by Egypt's highest court. The court forced him to divorce his wife because under Islamic law, marriage between an apostate and a Muslim is forbidden. Zaid's proposal was arguably less radical than Puin's. Zaid's book argued that "the Koran is a literary text, and the only way to understand, explain, and analyse it is through a literary approach". A Muslim, Zaid remained in Egypt for a time to refute the apostasy charges, but fled with his wife to Holland in the face of increasing death threats. Puin believes that he will not receive the same reaction, because unlike Zaid or Rushdie he does not have a Muslim name. His claim that the Koran has changed since its supposed standardisation, and that pre-Islamic texts have crept in, would nonetheless be regarded as highly blasphemous by Muslims. He has not yet written a book on his radical findings, but says it is "a goal to achieve" in the near future. Dr Tarif Khalidi, lecturer in Islamic Studies at Cambridge University, warns that the book may generate a controversy similar to Satanic Verses. "If Dr Puin's views are taken up and trumpeted in the media, and if you don't have many Muslims being rational about it, then all hell may break loose." Khalidi fears Muslims will not accept Puin's work on the Sa'na manuscripts as having been done with academic objectivity, but see it as a deliberate "attack on the integrity of the Koranic text". The manuscripts, thought to be the oldest surviving copies of the Koran, were discovered in the ancient Great Mosque of Sa'na in 1972, when the building was being restored after heavy rainfall, hidden in the loft in a bundle of old parchment and paper documents. They were nearly thrown away by the builders, but were spotted by Qadhi Isma'il al-Akwa, then president of the Yemeni Antiquities Authority, who saw their importance and sought international assistance to preserve and examine them. Al-Akwa managed to interest Puin, who was visiting Yemen for research purposes in 1979. Puin in turn persuaded the German government to organise and fund a restoration project. The restoration revealed that some of the parchment pages dated from the seventh and eighth centuries, the crucial first two centuries of Islam, from which very few manuscripts have survived. Until now, there were three ancient copies of the Koran. One copy in the Library of Tashkent in Uzbekistan, and another in the Topkapi Museum in Istanbul, Turkey, date from the eighth century. A copy preserved in the British Library in London, known as the Ma'il manuscript, dates from the late seventh century. But the Sa'na manuscripts are even older. Moreover, the Sa'na manuscripts are written in a script that originates from the Hijaz - the region of Arabia where the prophet Mohammed lived, which makes them not only the oldest to have survived, but one of the earliest copies of the Koran ever. Puin noticed minor textual variations, unconventional ordering of the chapters (surahs), as well as rare styles of orthography. Then he noticed that the sheets were palimpsests - manuscripts with versions written even earlier that had been washed off or erased. These findings led Dr Puin to assert that the Koran had undergone a textual evolution. In other words, the copy of the Koran that we have is not the one believed to have been revealed to the prophet. This is something that Muslims would find offensive.The idea that the Koran is the literal Word of God, unchanging and permanent, is crucial to Islam.The traditional Muslim view holds that the Koran was revealed to Mohammed by God in fragments between 610 and 632 AD. The revealed verses were "recorded on palm leaves and flat stones and in the hearts of men [meaning memorised]," and remained in this state during the prophet's lifetime. About 29 years after Mohammed's death during the rule of the third Muslim caliph, Uthman, a standard copy of the Koran in a book form, was made, because already divergent readings and copies were circulating in the growing Islamic empire. This Uthmanic recension, according to the Muslim view, was produced with meticulous care, based on earlier copies of the Koran made according to the instructions of the prophet. Orthodox Muslims insist that no changes have occurred to the Koran since the Uthmanic recension. But this view is challenged by the Sa'na manuscripts, which date from shortly after the Uthmanic recension. "There are dialectal and phonetical variations that don't make any sense in the text", says Puin. "The Arabic script is very defective - even more so in the early stages of its literature." Like other early Arabic literature, the Sa'na Koran was written without any diacritical marks, vowel symbols or any guide to how it should be read, says Puin. "The text was written so defectively that it can be read in a perfect way only if you have a strong oral tradition." The Sa'na text, just like other early Korans, was a guide to those who knew it already by memory, he says. Those that were unfamiliar with the Koran would read it differently because there were no diacritical and vowel symbols. As years went by, the correct reading of the Koran became less clear, he says. Puin gives as example Hajjaj bin Yusuf, governor of Iraq from 694-714 AD, who "was proud of inserting more than 1,000 alifs [first letter of the Arabic alphabet] in the Koranic text". webTitle: Musical tours for youngsters

fields.headline: Travel notes
fields.standfirst: Setting up musical tours for youngsters is now big business, reports Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Setting up musical tours for youngsters is now big business, reports Peter Kingston.
fields.body:
The main piazza is bursting. Every citizen of Levico, it seems, has turned out to hear la banda inglese. Stacey Westbrook, a musician with the Abraham Darby showband, is feeling pretty cool about it.

"This is my first time on tour and it's absolutely fabulous," she says. And hey! After playing the Royal Albert Hall and winning two national trophies with the band, a small gig in an Italian town isn't so frightening.

This tour, the 43 kids from Abraham Darby comprehensive in Telford, Shropshire, have already pulled off a major triumph in Verona.

They are veterans at the touring game. Since 1979 the band has played in Austria, the US, Spain, France and the Bahamas.

And it is far from alone. Summer is migration time for Britain's young musicians. Bands at all levels, from primary-school recorder group to county youth orchestra, have been wowing foreign audiences since the end of term.

Although not a solely British phenomenon, sending musical youngsters to perform overseas does seem a more popular activity here than in most other countries, says Liz Pepper, sales manager of Club Europe, which organised the Abraham Darby tour.

Often such music trips used to be organised by teachers using contacts in the music fraternity. But it has now become a multi-million pound business. Club Europe is one of three major players involved. "The market for this kind of music tour is worth about eight to ten million a year," says Tim Johnson, the firm's managing director.

It is running 45 trips this year, ranging from a small choir with 12- year-olds from Harlow to 74-piece concert orchestras. And it takes a lot of planning. Crucial to the success of each venture and to the credibility of successive tours by young Britons is making sure that everyone gets appropriate venues. There would be nothing worse than a primary school recorder and tambourine band, top players at Grade 3 standard, finding themselves facing a full 2,000-seat concert hall. Although Liz Pepper discreetly maintains that she has not heard of any such fiascos, this is why Club Europe insists on tapes or CDs from applicant school ensembles.

Nobody is rejected, she says: "We've got so many contacts in the towns and cities around Europe that we can find venues to meet any school's requirements." The primary school wind band might, for instance, be fixed up with performances in schools or old people's homes. A top youth orchestra or choir, on the other hand, could find itself playing to audiences of thousands in concert halls, cathedrals and festivals.

The Suffolk Youth Orchestra, for example, has just completed a tour that included gigs in three Parisian churches, in the cathedral at Meaux and at the Rheims festival.

An ensemble's age and standard will also suggest an itinerary. "Younger players on a first-time tour would probably go to Belgium, Holland or the northern coast of France, basically places not too far from home, and they'll probably last three or four days," says Pepper. "Older players go further afield and for longer, typically eight or nine days."

Certain cities are very hard to get dates in. Berlin and Vienna, for instance, have so much professional music going on that it would be hard for a British youth group to find a slot. But not impossible. Prague and Vienna are a popular combination to take in on an eight-day tour, says Pepper. The company negotiates with venues, and supplies the more prestigious ones with recordings of appropriate ensembles. The groups perform free. They will be charged a fee by bigger venues, but in such cases may break even by recouping some of the box office takings.

As well as promoting and arranging the concerts, Club Europe organises transport and accommodation and provides a bilingual representative for the duration. Eighty per cent of the trips are by coach - and between concerts and travel, there's usually space for some pleasure and leisure.

webTitle: Obituary: Gyorgy Petri

fields.headline: Gyorgy Petri
fields.standfirst: Hungarian whose poetry tested liberal communism to its limits
fields.trailText: The poet Gyorgy Petri, who has died aged 56, was, to his fellow Hungarians, the most original poet of his generation and something of a national hero. But he was not a typically Hungarian writer.
fields.body:
The poet Gyorgy Petri, who has died aged 56, was, to his fellow Hungarians, the most original poet of his generation and something of a national hero. But he was not a typically Hungarian writer.

For most Hungarian poets, including Petri, politics are inescapable, but the rhetoric of his native tradition - romantic, nationalist and libertarian - seemed to him fatally compromised by association with communism. Drawing on foreign ironists, such as TS Eliot and CP Cavafy, he developed a more indirect approach. Rejecting inflated language, he wrote in a style that was harsh, spare and colloquial, sometimes to the point of coarseness.

He eschewed overt expressions of beauty, pathos and idealism, as much in his disarmingly frank love poems as in the political satires. What moves us in his work is its truthfulness. In 1989, as former communists wept for the crimes of the past, Petri wrote: "My eyes are dry. I need them for looking with."

Petri was an urban poet. He died in Budapest a few doors away from the house where he was born. His family was of Serbian origin, his father a small businessman in the book trade. In several poems, he recalls the doomed revolution of 1956 as an incident from his boyhood - the morning, for instance, "when the town woke to gunfire/ that blew it apart". At university, he studied philosophy, a subject he continued to quarrel with in his poetry.

Petri worked as a trainee journalist and as a psychiatric nurse, but mostly his was the hand-to-mouth existence of the fulltime writer. He was a distinguished translator from French, German and English. His first book, published in 1971, came out at a time of relaxed censorship.

It was a time when Janos Kadar was creating "goulash communism" - a climate of superficial freedom depending on nods, winks and conspiracies of silence. The authorities managed not to notice literary political dissent, provided it was not expressed too bluntly.

Petri's first two books were issued by the state publishing house. The poems, sceptical in tone, are mostly concerned about identity and relationships. There are brutally honest pieces about the sexual life, which sometimes associate sexual hypocrisy with the petty deceits that shore up dictatorship. A handful of poems are obliquely critical of what appears to be the Kadar regime.

By 1981, however, Petri's political disgust was occupying centre-stage. When he submitted a third collection for publication, he was told that the book could only be printed if he cut 30 poems from it. He refused. In 1982, the book was illegally published in samizdat.

It had become Petri's main purpose to expose the dishonesty of Kadarian "liberalism" by pushing official tolerance to its limit, and deny himself the prestige and privilege reserved for officially successful writers. He also made himself a target for police surveillance. Yet it is now impossible to read his 1980s work without sensing his excitement at the discovery of freedom. Much of it is vehemently satirical, with a Rabelaisian glee to much of its language. I think, for example, of the imagined apparatchik who explains to the public "that prices have a randy nature", rising "like furious Don Juans" at the sight of queuing housewives, and I remember Petri's delighted grin when I compared him to Jonathan Swift.

The political commitment in his poetry seemed to Petri "a moral obligation", and its logical consequence was involvement in the so-called democratic opposition. He wrote for its underground paper Beszelo, spoke at meetings, demonstrated in support of Poland's Solidarity and Czechoslovakia's Charter 77. When political parties were legalised, Petri joined the radically liberal Alliance Of Free Democrats, and campaigned in the 1990 election. But his delight was always in anarchy and dissent, and with the departure of communism, he lost his "favourite toy" - as he said in a recent poem.

Petri had an almost medieval feeling for the omnipresence of death. When, in the summer of 1998, he learned that he had cancer of the larynx, he had an enemy grander than the state. His respect for that enemy, and his cool awareness of his responsibility for the grip it had on him, produced a poetry of memorable courage and clarity."It's time to die: I'm bored with the state of being. I'd welcome stomach-cancer or oedema of the lungs. My time on earth is duller than words can say; I've no taste for myself, though I still have some self-respect. I am clearing myself away."

Petri tended to depict himself as a dissipated and world-weary bohemian, resigned to the narrow limits of human life. When I first met him in 1988, I was struck by how slight he seemed, as if shrunken and prematurely aged. Smoking and drinking incessantly, he never seemed to eat. Yet he was also charming, witty, considerate and courteous. There was a vitality to his swarthy features, and his talk was often wonderfully terse and acerbic. "I was always ideologically suspect," he said to me. "It began before I wrote my first political things." He touched his nose: "The smell."

He was married twice, though there were three other major lovers in his life, and he jokingly claims, in one poem, to remember 150 sexual partners. His poetry has been widely translated: two volumes have appeared in English, both published by Bloodaxe Books and translated by George Gomori and myself: Night Song Of The Personal Shadow (1991) and Eternal Monday (1999). The latter was shortlisted for this year's Weidenfeld translation prize.

He is survived by his partner, Mari Pap, a daughter from his first marriage and a son from his second.

webTitle: Keegan attacks England pay-TV plan

fields.headline: Keegan attacks England pay-TV plan
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan yesterday hit out at the prospect of an England game being shown on pay-per-view television for the first time, a new landmark for this controversial form of broadcasting.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan yesterday hit out at the prospect of an England game being shown on pay-per-view television for the first time, a new landmark for this controversial form of broadcasting.

The live rights to the World Cup qualifier against Finland in Helsinki on October 11 have been bought by U-Direct TV, which means viewers will have to pay around £10 to see it.

The decision to sell the rights to U-Direct was taken by the Finnish FA as the host federation and the Football Association was powerless to intervene although it will be contacting its Helsinki counterpart to check whether something can be done to reverse it.

According to the company, the agreement has definitely been signed, and the England coach for one was less than happy at the prospect of a limited audience for the game. "I am [against it] for the national side, definitely," he said. "I think it should be available for everybody and I feel that about all the major events, to be honest.

"I don't think you should have to buy one of these or have one of those to get it because it is our national sport. But it is Finland's game."

According to the FA spokesman Adrian Bevington: "As the host nation the Finns are empowered to make such a decision without any input from ourselves. When brokering our own TV contracts it is always a fundamental aim to provide as large a viewing audience as possible."

In fact, the FA sold the rights to England's home World Cup qualifiers to BSkyB which scores much lower viewing figures than terrestrial channels.

U-Direct, a company owned by Pearson Television, Deutsche Bank and Nomura International, is estimated to have paid £1m for the rights, although one source put the figure as high as £2.7m.

Roger Hall, U-Direct's marketing director, defended the project. "This is a first, but the sports rights market is a competitive one and we are not the first people to charge for watching sports on TV. What we are doing is not new, we are just charging in a different way."

"Chrysalis will produce the programme but we will have a full support team in the studio and an on-site commentary team."

U-Direct will use the Sky Sports Digital channel for its broadcast, with highlights made available to terrestial channels the same evening. Although this will be the first England game shown live on pay-per-view, three Nationwide League games were aired using this method on BSkyB 18 months ago. fields.bodyText: Kevin Keegan yesterday hit out at the prospect of an England game being shown on pay-per-view television for the first time, a new landmark for this controversial form of broadcasting. The live rights to the World Cup qualifier against Finland in Helsinki on October 11 have been bought by U-Direct TV, which means viewers will have to pay around £10 to see it. The decision to sell the rights to U-Direct was taken by the Finnish FA as the host federation and the Football Association was powerless to intervene although it will be contacting its Helsinki counterpart to check whether something can be done to reverse it. According to the company, the agreement has definitely been signed, and the England coach for one was less than happy at the prospect of a limited audience for the game. "I am [against it] for the national side, definitely," he said. "I think it should be available for everybody and I feel that about all the major events, to be honest. "I don't think you should have to buy one of these or have one of those to get it because it is our national sport. But it is Finland's game." According to the FA spokesman Adrian Bevington: "As the host nation the Finns are empowered to make such a decision without any input from ourselves. When brokering our own TV contracts it is always a fundamental aim to provide as large a viewing audience as possible." In fact, the FA sold the rights to England's home World Cup qualifiers to BSkyB which scores much lower viewing figures than terrestrial channels. U-Direct, a company owned by Pearson Television, Deutsche Bank and Nomura International, is estimated to have paid £1m for the rights, although one source put the figure as high as £2.7m. Roger Hall, U-Direct's marketing director, defended the project. "This is a first, but the sports rights market is a competitive one and we are not the first people to charge for watching sports on TV. What we are doing is not new, we are just charging in a different way." "Chrysalis will produce the programme but we will have a full support team in the studio and an on-site commentary team." U-Direct will use the Sky Sports Digital channel for its broadcast, with highlights made available to terrestial channels the same evening. Although this will be the first England game shown live on pay-per-view, three Nationwide League games were aired using this method on BSkyB 18 months ago. The season after next NTL plans to show 40 Premiership games using pay-per-view.

webTitle: Mouth that launched a thousand chants

fields.headline: Mouth that launched a thousand chants
fields.trailText: While it has long been suspected that David Beckham's brains reside mainly in his feet, the search for the centre of Victoria's intellectual activity goes on. She's dropped him in it again.
fields.body:
While it has long been suspected that David Beckham's brains reside mainly in his feet, the search for the centre of Victoria's intellectual activity goes on. Some time ago - though the memory still lingers - Posh revealed to a world with an unhealthy appetite for this sort of thing that though hubby may not wear the trousers in the Beckham household he does wear the thongs. Her thongs. And Posh was not talking about flip-flops.

Of course, Victoria may have thought the nation would be as amused as she was by this brief insight into her husband's private life. Perhaps also she felt it showed the human side of a man with one of the most instantly recognisable faces of his generation but whom only a few really know.

Unfortunately Victoria had failed to anticipate that whereas a pop audience may have laughed at her bedroom revelation and moved on, David's constituency remains somewhat less sympathetic to blokes wearing women's underwear.

The headlines and sniggers followed. Added to the fallout from Becks's sarong period and his sending off in the last World Cup, it gave football audiences up and down the country evidence aplenty to brand arguably England's most gifted player a pretentious weirdo who deserved every insult that came spitting down from the terraces.

The vilification reached what one hopes was a peak in June when a handful of England fans at Euro 2000 chanted such obscenities at Beckham that the Football Association refused to reveal what they were.

Eventually the Mirror published the offending words - "I hope your baby gets cancer" was one example - and Posh reportedly rang the paper to congratulate them on exposing what David has to put up with.

By now even she knew. Indeed, one of the most popular Beckham-baiting chants of recent seasons involved her. And one of the highlights of her surprisingly entertaining recent television documentary was a segment where she and Elton John traded the best football-crowd insults that had been thrown at them.

So it came as some surprise this weekend to find that Posh had once again provided yet more material for those who like to provide a discordant accompaniment to Beckham's twice-weekly performances on the field.

First she described him as "a total animal" in bed. Ammunition enough for your mates, never mind thousands of disparaging football fans. But next came news from the kitchen, a room where most husbands' conversation is confined to "what's for dinner?". Not chez Becks.

"David walks around the kitchen going, 'I'm a gay icon, I'm a gay icon'," Posh said. "When I try and say 'so I am' he just goes: 'But they love me. You've got nothing on me, baby'."

If you did not know she loved him you would think she was doing it deliberately. At this very moment fans up and down the country are composing songs to serenade Beckham with based specifically on the latest information supplied by his wife. Songs that will enjoy more lasting popularity than Posh's just-released first solo single, the aptly titled Out Of Your Mind.

But perhaps that's it. Posh has allowed the nation an intimate glimpse behind the curtains of Beckham Palace to ensure the headlines she hopes will turn into sales.

Certainly, the fact that her domestic revelations coincided with her appearance on a gay radio show and at a gay concert sent out a pretty obvious message: "Me and David are quite clearly not gay, of course, because he's an animal in bed, but we really empathise with you guys and if you want to buy my record then feel free. You treat Kylie Minogue as a gay icon after all, and I'm more famous than her."

Unfortunately this PR equation forgot one ingredient: the effect on David next time he plays at Chelsea, or Liverpool or Maine Road.

Now Becks has a much better grasp of how to avoid an embarrassing story. As Posh helpfully revealed: "I like short skirts but David says I can't do that now. He says when Brooklyn goes to school all the kids will come up to him and say, 'I've seen your mum's knickers'."

Impeccable logic. If only Posh could take a lesson from David's PR book. Otherwise, the poor lad will have only one option left: to make make Victoria sign the sort of gagging order the Beckhams insist on for their staff.

webTitle: Platt prepares to pick himself

fields.headline: Platt prepares to pick himself
fields.trailText: David Platt has been preparing for a surprise resumption of his playing career by getting fit with another 30-something player-manager, Chelsea's Gianluca Vialli.
fields.body:
David Platt has been preparing for a surprise resumption of his playing career by getting fit with another 30-something player-manager, Chelsea's Gianluca Vialli.

The Nottingham Forest player-manager is seriously considering selecting himself for Saturday's opening game of the season against West Bromwich Albion at the City Ground.

And though he admits the days of his all-action, box-to-box style of play have long gone, he has no doubts about his overall fitness after spending some of the summer with Vialli.

"I spent six weeks in Sardinia getting fit with Gianluca Vialli, who's been a friend since our days at Juventus," Platt said. "We did a lot of hill running as well as playing a lot of tennis and five-a-side football. I followed that by continuing to build up my fitness on our pre-season tour of the USA."

Although the 34-year-old joined Forest as player-manager last summer, his last appearance was 10 months ago. That game - against Sheffield United - is one Platt prefers to forget: he was sent off after collecting a second booking in a skirmish with the United forward Paul Devlin.

But if he does play against West Brom it will not be because the former England captain wants to restore his Mr Clean image, more a case of needs must.

"We suffered badly from a shortage of goals last season, especially from midfield. There were times when we were 1-0 down and I couldn't envisage where an equaliser would come from," Platt said.

That problem hardly appears to have been addressed since the close-season departure of Nigel Quashie to Portsmouth and the arrival of Gary Jones from Tranmere. Hence Platt's comeback.

"I still believe I can do a job and finish off moves," said Platt, who proved as much by hitting a hat-trick in a pre-season friendly against Nigel Clough's Burton Albion.

"In the long term I hope to make the signings that will mean I won't have to play. But I won't be rushed into making them. So, as far as this Saturday is concerned, let's say I'm very much in the manager's thoughts."

Arsenal are on the verge of signing the France international striker Sylvain Wiltord in a compromise deal worth around £10m.

Bordeaux's chairman Jean-Louis Triaud confirmed yesterday that the only direct approach they had received for the player was from Arsenal and, with Wiltord having fallen out with the French club, a deal is likely soon.

"They offered £8m for him and have barely budged from that figure since," said Triaud. "I have never insisted on £15m for him and it is wrong to say that Arsenal have offered £13m. Although I am keeping calm about this tug-of-war between Sylvain and myself I would prefer a straightforward solution."

Arsenal's manager Arsène Wenger is eager to strengthen his squad before the new season begins in two weeks and the deadline for registration for the Champions League a week today. He has given Bordeaux a deadline of this week to make up their mind on Wiltord.

webTitle: Hammam dreams of Wales United

fields.headline: Hammam dreams of Wales United
fields.standfirst: The Crazy Gang's godfather now has big plans for Cardiff City
fields.trailText: Madman or genius? The Crazy Gang's godfather now has big plans for Cardiff City
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson thinks he's mad; so does the man who runs the Cardiff City Supporters Club - not to mention many of its members - but Sam Hammam doesn't care. As his £3.1m takeover of the relegated Third Division team nears completion, one question is dominating football conversation in south Wales: has the godfather of the Crazy Gang finally taken leave of his senses?

After taking Wimbledon from the Southern League and making them into a feared Premiership team, the Lebanese businessman wants to transform the fortunes of the Welsh capital's club.

As part of his plan to provide a team to match the city's status, Hammam has drawn up an audacious blueprint that both delights and outrages Cardiff City's supporters. In return for his money - £500,000 for team strengthening, £1.5m to help clear debts and another £1m to cover losses over the next two years - the prospective owner would like to see: Cardiff City become the Cardiff Celts; the club's colours change from blue to green and white; their bluebird symbol replaced with a Celtic cross; and Cardiff City become the Welsh team, possibly under the banner of Wales United.

Hammam finally severed his ties with Wimbledon just before they lost their place in the top flight after 14 years. Under his leadership, the Crazy Gang had a field day. Expensive clothes were destroyed, graffiti was scrawled on opposition dressing room walls and intimidation - especially under Vinnie Jones - was the name of their game.

Since selling out to a Norwegian consortium, Hammam has been on the look-out for a new toy, with 19 clubs - including Tottenham, Sheffield Wednesday, Portsmouth and Crystal Palace - reportedly in contention. After considering a move to south Wales in the early 90s when Wimbledon's relations with Merton council over Plough Lane reached rock bottom, he re-established the Welsh connection nearly 12 months ago. The Dons were playing Cardiff in front of only 2,272 spectators in the Worthington Cup at Selhurst Park.

"We beat them 3-1 but their fans outnumbered ours by three to one on the night - I couldn't believe it," says Hammam. "I'm attracted to Cardiff because they're underdogs. I've been a fighter all my life - I fought for 23 years at Wimbledon and I want to prove the sceptics wrong again. Sir Alex Ferguson says I'm mad to buy Cardiff but there's something about City which I didn't see in any other club - a cause to correct, a dream to be achieved. I really feel very strongly that Cardiff City should be a Welsh club.

Marching army
"The change of name is something which we have to discuss very deeply with the fans - all I want now is the commitment because Cardiff can go places. We can aspire to compete with Bristol City or Birmingham, maybe even Coventry, but that's not interesting enough for me. I'm hoping that, within 15 to 20 years, we can aspire to compete with Liverpool, Arsenal or Manchester United. To do that, we have to be the team of the whole nation.

"If the supporters have the guts and the vision to become the marching Welsh army, then I think we have a chance to dream that we can compete with the best."

In the two months since he first threw the beleaguered board a lifeline, Hammam has fallen in love with Cardiff City and their supporters - and they with him. Directors and fans have been seduced by an irresistible cocktail of money and passion.

"With Sam's genuine enthusiasm, you'd expect him to generate ideas," says the chairman Steve Borley, "but nothing's cast in stone and you have to look down every avenue. Cardiff City has never just represented the capital; it's been the club of south Wales and we have supporters from all over Wales."

The Wales United proposal has been given particularly short shrift outside Cardiff. "With respect, I don't think Mr Hammam has done much research into Welsh football," says Carroll Clark, chairman of Wrexham Supporters Club.

"Bearing in mind the intense rivalry between Cardiff, Swansea and Wrexham, he hasn't got a hope of establishing Cardiff as the main club in Wales. I'm all for Welsh fans getting behind the national team - that's totally realistic. But this idea just isn't."

Forty miles west of Cardiff, the chairman of Swansea City Supporters Club, John Button, is equally dismissive. "I hope Mr Hammam is just being naive," he says. "If not, it's arrogance at its worst.

"We didn't attract too many non-Swansea supporters when we were top of the old First Division. People support their own team and it's very difficult to change - you stick with your side through thick and thin."

As part of his charm offensive, Hammam met 300 supporters on successive nights at Ninian Park last week and, by all accounts, went down a storm.

"The man has charisma and contacts which can only help the club," says Tony Jeffries, of the Cardiff City Supporters Club. "He's totally bonkers - in the nicest possible way - but you don't get to be a multimillionaire by being an idiot.

"Sam's doing this for all the right reasons. Directors will have to pay for their match tickets and meals, and he says he'll work 24 hours a day, seven days a week and not take one penny out of the club.

"If Sam gets us to the top of the table or going for promotion, he'll realise that there's no need to change the club's name. People from all over Wales and England will come flooding back - which is what he wants. All he's asked supporters to do is to keep an open mind."

As speculation persists that Bobby Gould or Joe Kinnear is about to replace the manager Billy Ayre, Hammam has already scored a spectacular success: everybody is talking about Cardiff City. He wants the deal giving him 82% of the club to be delivered by their first home game against Blackpool, a week on Saturday.

As well as Hammam, Wimbledon and Cardiff have something else in common: Plough Lane and Ninian Park were both built on former council refuse tips. After his brass-and-muck success in south London, City supporters are confident his vision for their club will not become a load of rubbish.

webTitle: Bradford take a chance on Carbone

fields.headline: Bradford take a chance on Carbone
fields.trailText: Benito Carbone will fly into England today to finalise the details of a shock transfer to Bradford City that was billed by the club last night as "the most exciting signing in our history".
fields.body:
Benito Carbone will fly into England today to finalise the details of a shock transfer to Bradford City that was billed by the club last night as "the most exciting signing in our history".

After leaving Aston Villa in acrimonious circumstances last month Carbone is a free agent and Bradford have taken advantage of the apathetic reaction to his availability from Italy's Serie A to tempt him back to England.

The controversial 28-year-old forward is due at Leeds/Bradford airport with his agent Giovanni Branchini by late morning, when they will be met by officials from the Yorkshire club and taken to Valley Parade for a medical.

According to the Tykes' manager Chris Hutchings: "This signing will raise a few eyebrows in the world of football."

His sense of anticipation was shared by the Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond after a turbulent summer in which the club's ambition has been questioned following Paul Jewell's unexpected defection to Sheffield Wednesday.

"This will be seen by the supporters as the most exciting signing in the history of the club," Richmond predicted.

After a build-up like that, Bradford's fans will no doubt be relieved that it is not Middlesbrough's Brian Deane - the subject of an unsuccessful bid last week - but Carbone who will be unveiled at a press conference scheduled for 11am tomorrow.

At Wednesday the Italian was best remembered for a string of rows with the then manager Danny Wilson rather than the occasional flashes of brilliance he displayed on the field.

The Villa manager John Gregory encountered similar problems upon signing him last season and finally ran out of patience with the former Internazionale forward after the club's offer of a new contract did not even merit an answer.

Since then Carbone has spoken to Reggiana and Perugia but his status in Italy is such that he has not received a single offer.

That Bradford are willing to meet his £30,000-a-week demands - three times higher than their previous pay ceiling - speaks volumes for Richmond's determination to stay in the Premiership.

Bradford have not given up hope of enticing Paulo Wanchope to the club from under the nose of Manchester City.

Richmond is believed to have offered the West Ham striker improved terms yesterday and, contrary to some reports, Wanchope's future is still unclear after asking for the night to mull over his decision. Earlier the Maine Road manager Joe Royle claimed to have signed Wanchope for £3.65m but last night the Manchester City spokesman Chris Bird said: "Paulo has gone back to London to think things over and speak to his family in Costa Rica."

West Ham cleared the way for Rio Ferdinand to join Barcelona yesterday after telling Leeds United that their £15m offer for the England defender was a waste of time.

Harry Redknapp insisted that he would not allow the 21-year-old to go to Elland Road, but the West Ham manager added: "If a club like Barcelona came in it might be different, but they haven't made any contact. I am told they are prepared to offer us £14m plus Winston Bogarde, but that doesn't make sense because I've already been offered the same player for less than £1m.

"The truth is, though, that I don't want to lose Rio."

Middlesbrough have received a work permit for the Croatian international striker Alen Boksic to complete his £2.5m transfer from the Italian champions Lazio.

The Aston Villa wing-back Mark Delaney will miss the start of the season after suffering medial knee ligament damage during Saturday's friendly at non-League Tamworth. The Welsh international could be on the sidelines for up to a month.

His sense of anticipation was shared by the Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond after a turbulent summer in which the club's ambition has been questioned following Paul Jewell's unexpected defection to Sheffield Wednesday. "This will be seen by the supporters as the most exciting signing in the history of the club," Richmond predicted. After a build-up like that, Bradford's fans will no doubt be relieved that it is not Middlesbrough's Brian Deane - the subject of an unsuccessful bid last week - but Carbone who will be unveiled at a press conference scheduled for 11am tomorrow. At Wednesday the Italian was best remembered for a string of rows with the then manager Danny Wilson rather than the occasional flashes of brilliance he displayed on the field. The Villa manager John Gregory encountered similar problems upon signing him last season and finally ran out of patience with the former Internazionale forward after the club's offer of a new contract did not even merit an answer. Since then Carbone has spoken to Reggiana and Perugia but his status in Italy is such that he has not received a single offer. That Bradford are willing to meet his £30,000-a-week demands - three times higher than their previous pay ceiling - speaks volumes for Richmond's determination to stay in the Premiership. Bradford have not given up hope of enticing Paulo Wanchope to the club from under the nose of Manchester City. Richmond is believed to have offered the West Ham striker improved terms yesterday and, contrary to some reports, Wanchope's future is still unclear after asking for the night to mull over his decision. Earlier the Maine Road manager Joe Royle claimed to have signed Wanchope for £3.65m but last night the Manchester City spokesman Chris Bird said: "Paulo has gone back to London to think things over and speak to his family in Costa Rica." West Ham cleared the way for Rio Ferdinand to join Barcelona yesterday after telling Leeds United that their £15m offer for the England defender was a waste of time. Harry Redknapp insisted that he would not allow the 21-year-old to go to Elland Road, but the West Ham manager added: "If a club like Barcelona came in it might be different, but they haven't made any contact. I am told they are prepared to offer us £14m plus Winston Bogarde, but that doesn't make sense because I've already been offered the same player for less than £1m. "The truth is, though, that I don't want to lose Rio." Middlesbrough have received a work permit for the Croatian international striker Alen Boksic to complete his £2.5m transfer from the Italian champions Lazio. The Aston Villa wing-back Mark Delaney will miss the start of the season after suffering medial knee ligament damage during Saturday's friendly at non-League Tamworth. The Welsh international could be on the sidelines for up to a month.

webTitle: Curtain of rain falls on a thriller

fields.headline: Curtain of rain falls on a thriller
fields.standfirst:
Trescothick was the biggest plus for England but West Indies can savour Lara's return to brilliance
West Indies 157 & 438-7dec
England 303 & 80-1
Match drawn
fields.trailText: After four days of international cricket at its best, the Manchester weather had the final say in the destiny of the third Test yesterday. Having given England a minimum of 71 overs to make 293 to win after a declaration posted shortly past noon, West Indies had their ambitions thwarted by an opening stand of 61 from Mike Atherton and Marcus Trescothick, and by the curtains of drizzle that drifted across the ground.
fields.body:
After four days of international cricket at its best, the Manchester weather had the final say in the destiny of the third Test yesterday. Having given England a minimum of 71 overs to make 293 to win after a declaration posted shortly past noon, West Indies had their ambitions thwarted by an opening stand of 61 from Mike Atherton and Marcus Trescothick, and by the curtains of drizzle that drifted across the ground.

There was some glowering and glaring from Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose as they cranked the pace up in a last-ditch effort to sneak an unlikely victory, but realistically, once the England openers had survived the early challenges, it became little more than a matter of scoring points to take forward to the fourth Test at Headingley on Thursday week.

Bad light brought proceedings to an end at 5.20 with England having reached 80 for one, of which Trescothick had made 38 with Nasser Hussain, badly dropped at the wicket off Walsh when one, on six.

The series remains tied at one match apiece, but there was a reminder too that Test match cricket is not just a one-act play. This match contained some exceptional performances: Alec Stewart's vivid century on his 100th appearance matched by Brian Lara's immaculate effort on Sunday; Darren Gough's wonderful fast bowling in the first innings, and that from Walsh and Ambrose, which matched their own highest standards; Hussain's phenomenal catch to dismiss Ambrose and his instinctive run-out of Lara; Walsh's incredible slower ball first up to Graham Thorpe which so bamboozled the batsman on his return to Test cricket that he sat in the dressing room and laughed at the absurdity of it; and Trescothick's debut, which brought him 104 runs for once out and which, from an England perspective, was the most significant feature of the match.

Trescothick was placed in the furnace again yesterday and survived intact, displaying the admirably unflappable temperament and solid technique that had brought him to notice in the triangular tournament. Perhaps that tournament came at the right time, allowing him to display his credentials in one-day games without fear of failure. Credit then to those who identified his potential and had the presence of mind to pick him. A part of the next generation appears to be in place.

Yesterday when Walsh and Ambrose brought all the toys out of the box he was equal to the task and, with Atherton, made sure that there was no early breakthrough to give West Indies the sniff of a chance. Walsh finally snared Atherton, caught at the wicket for 28, to give him his 23rd wicket of the series and was urgently seeking his 24th when the draw was agreed.

By and large, although they suffered as West Indies racked up 438 for seven in their second innings, it was a good, workmanlike performance from an England team that is growing in confidence match by match. The top six have a look of authority all the way down (although Hussain's miserable run of scores continues) and the pace bowling, led by Gough, has a classy look to it, even if Andy Caddick's capacity to wilt when under the cosh appears undiminished.

The surprise package was Craig White, who bowled with genuine pace and skill, particularly when reverse-swinging the old ball to left-handers from around the wicket. The part he might play in Pakistan this winter, where reverse swing is a must, should not be underestimated.

The disappointment was Robert Croft's offspin. Here he was presented with a pitch that turned and the pressure was on him to exploit it. He was expected to take wickets and figures of one for 124 from 47 overs do not indicate a success.

There is little doubt that a spinner will be superfluous to requirements at Headingley, and a seventh batsman or all-rounder will come into the reckoning for that match, but the character of Oval pitches on which Saqlain Mushtaq and Ian Salisbury take so many wickets for Surrey has changed. England might well want two spinners there for the final Test, but will think long and hard as to whether Croft should be one of them.

West Indies can take encouragement from the match. A little more than a month ago they were humiliated at Lord's, bowled out for 54 when they had the match under control, and their performances in the one-day tournament were less than adequate.

But they fought back superbly here, not just through Lara's brilliance and that of Walsh and Ambrose, but through Jimmy Adams's diligence, and a return to something like form for Adrian Griffith. There was a statement of sorts too in the way that Wavell Hinds and then Lara pulled the short ball with gusto after the feeble attempts to cope with it at Lord's.

The back-up bowling remains poor, however, with Reon King and Franklyn Rose appearing to have neither the skill nor the appetite to take over the mantle from Walsh and Ambrose.

webTitle: Waugh blames county pitches for international failure

fields.headline: Waugh blames county pitches for international failure
fields.trailText: Worcestershire's Glenn McGrath, the country's leading wicket-taker this season, has blamed county pitches for England's international failures.
fields.body:
Worcestershire's Glenn McGrath, the country's leading wicket-taker this season, has blamed county pitches for England's international failures.

The Australian fast bowler, who has taken 62 first-class wickets and 88 in all competitions, said that while Test pitches were generally "good and hard", county pitches were "slow and low".

"The kind of surfaces at county level aren't good cricket wickets and it's tougher to score runs and time the ball and to take wickets," said McGrath.

"Then you step up to Test level and a decent pitch and the batsmen find the fast bowlers are a bit quicker to deal with and they tend to nick the ball a lot more. It makes it harder to adjust."

McGrath said that English players were "at least on a par" with other countries but were held back by the difference in conditions.

"On a good pitch you get value for your shots with the ball coming on to the bat and if a bowler if prepared to put his back into things he will get a bit of reward," he said. "On some of the wickets I've played on this season I can't even get the ball to bounce above chest high however much I put in.

"It's something they have to work on over here in the future. They can produce good Test pitches so I'm sure they can do the same at county level."

webTitle: Dutchman jumps at the chance

fields.headline: Dutchman jumps at the chance
fields.standfirst: Sussex Sharks 213-6 v Lancashire
fields.trailText: Sussex Sharks 213-6 v Lancashire
fields.body:
This was the third of Sussex's five National League matches under the floodlights they installed with the help of a local egg producer last season. There was the usual music and mascots, plus a jazz band who would not pipe down when the rain stopped, and a martial arts display before the start.

But what gave this game its unique place in cricket history was the opportunity to bungee-jump from the Cromwell Road End for £30. It was only used every other over, when the bowling was from the Sea End, to avoid any sudden movement behind the bowler's arm. Andy Flintoff may have been tempted to try it as an unorthodox solution to his back problems.

There was added novelty value in an impressive innings from Bas Zuiderent, a 23-year-old from Utrecht who was given the daunting task of filling in for Michael Bevan, Sussex's Australian inspiration who has gone home to play in a one-day series against South Africa.

Wearing a cap rather than a helmet - not a Dutch cap, Sussex's coach Pete Moores pointed out, but the county's second-team colours - Zuiderent struck a stylish 68 in a fifth-wicket stand of 141 in 24 overs with Will House, the left-hander who headed west from Kent during the winter.

Zuiderent, who hit 54 for Holland against England in Peshawar in the 1996 World Cup, was making his first appearance of the season but reached his half-century from 67 balls with four fours and a six off Gary Yates, one of three spinners used by Lancashire.

House ended unbeaten on 80, the Cambridge Blue's first half-century in any form of cricket for Sussex, as the Sharks posted 213 for six in a match which was reduced to 41 overs per side by a half-hour shower, with Lancashire's target revised upwards to 220 by messrs Duckworth and Lewis.

Ian Austin was playing his first game since suffering a calf injury on June 23, a timely boost for Lancashire ahead of Sunday's NatWest Trophy semi-final in Bristol, and did not take long to make an impact, having Chris Adams caught by Flintoff at first slip with his third ball.

By the time Austin retired with figures of 7-1-15-1, Sussex had lost two more wickets, Umer Rashid deceived by Glen Chapple's slower ball and Tony Cottey run out after a mix-up with Richard Montgomerie.

When Montgomerie was caught behind during an impressive spell from Flintoff - maybe he took a bungee jump before the start - Sussex were in trouble at 64 for four. But Zuiderent and House responded superbly.

webTitle: Umpire Whitehead found guilty of verbal attack on bowler

fields.headline: Umpire Whitehead found guilty of verbal attack on bowler
fields.trailText: Alan Whitehead, one of the most experienced umpires on the first-class circuit, was found guilty by an England and Wales Cricket Board disciplinary hearing at Lord's yesterday of verbally abusing the Warwickshire all-rounder Dougie Brown during a National League match against Durham last month.
fields.body:
Alan Whitehead, one of the most experienced umpires on the first-class circuit, was found guilty by an England and Wales Cricket Board disciplinary hearing at Lord's yesterday of verbally abusing the Warwickshire all-rounder Dougie Brown during a National League match against Durham last month.

Whitehead denied breaching regulations on "fair and proper conduct" but his defence was rejected by a disciplinary team chaired by Lancashire's Eddie Slinger and including Whitehead's umpiring colleague George Sharp. He was cautioned as to his future conduct and ordered to pay £250 towards costs. The ECB said the punishment had "taken into account Whitehead's long and distinguished career as a player and umpire". Whitehead allegedly swore at Brown after the bowler had asked for an explanation of why he had turned down an lbw appeal. Brown has not been accused of a hostile approach.

Umpire Whitehead and Warwickshire do have a history of bitterness, however. Warwickshire were furious at the end of last season when Whitehead and his fellow umpire, John Steele, took the players off for rain at a critical time in a National League match against Hampshire.

webTitle: Hussain hopes for county remedy

fields.headline: Hussain hopes for county remedy
fields.standfirst: England's captain looks for clues in Kidderminster
fields.trailText: David Hopps hears England's captain look for clues in Kidderminster in his search for form.
fields.body:
A drawn Test and the Cornhill series still in the balance: next stop Headingley. If only for Nasser Hussain it was that simple. Hussain's thoughts will stray no further this week than Kidderminster, where Essex's championship match against Worcestershire gives him a desperately needed opportunity to arrest a lean run of form that is assuming disturbing proportions.

It is hardly new for an England captain, weighed down by the demands of office, to find his own form is suffering. But Hussain is adamant that his shortage of runs is merely the product of random ill luck in a bedraggled summer.

There is good reason to believe him. England are progressing under his captaincy; his grasp of the job's finer points has been widely praised. Nevertheless, whether you prefer the statistic of 134 runs in 12 first-class knocks this summer, or 126 Test runs in nine completed innings since his hundred in Durban in December, the pressure is growing. An uncomfortable 45 minutes at the crease yesterday provided no solution.

"I don't want to dwell too much upon it," said Hussain. "The wicket was juiced up and they were not the easiest batting conditions. I admit I don't feel in the best of form, but I just put it down to a stop-start summer. Some time at the crease at Kidderminster should help me find out whether the problem is technical or mental."

Hussain was fortunate to survive, with six to his name, after the wicketkeeper Ridley Jacobs spilled a simple opportunity off Courtney Walsh. That was not the only tentative moment in a dead innings largely played out in indifferent light.

Walsh said nothing but, as his eyes widened like saucers at Hussain's struggles, the implication that he had Hussain on the run was obvious.

The West Indian fast bowlers have long believed that exposing the opposing captain goes a sizeable way towards undermining his team. How successfully Hussain responds could yet have a major bearing on a well-balanced series. The absence from Worcestershire's attack of Glenn McGrath could prove timely.

It would be tempting to present Hussain currently as an emperor with no clothes, were it not for the fact that nakedness has again become a touchy subject. Fears that Old Trafford's place on the Test rota could be threatened because of ICC displeasure about the number of streaking incidents over the past five days are exaggerated; talk of fencing in supporters entirely unnecessary. Nevertheless, it is not necessary to be a prude to be weary of pot-bellied drunken oafs revealing bodies that the slightest common sense should tell them are best left covered.

"I'm not overly amused," said Hussain. "We are giving everything for our country and it gets you down that a few people think it is better entertainment to run on the pitch with no clothes on."

The police claim they have no powers to act, and the threat of immediate ejection just ensures that the streaks are reserved for the final hour. Perhaps Tony Blair might like to dream up an overnight policy where streakers are dragged off immediately to pay their dues at the nearest cashpoint?

There is no easy solution, but rugby-style tackles from Lancashire's Pitch Incursion Team smacked of heavy-handedness. On the assumption that nudity itself no longer causes serious offence, a Clothes Nicking Team would be much more effective, with the exhibitionists invited to make their own way home as nature intended.

webTitle: Third car bomb in 24 hours hits Spain

fields.headline: Third car bomb in 24 hours hits Spain
fields.trailText: At least six people are injured following the third terrorist bomb attack in Spain in the last 24 hours.
fields.body:
At least six people are injured following the third terrorist bomb attack in Spain in the last 24 hours.

A car bomb exploded in central Madrid at 6.45pm local time, coming just hours after a car exploded in the Basque town of Zumaia killing a businessman. The earlier attack was blamed on the Basque separatist group Eta.

"For the moment all we know is that a car has exploded and that six people are being treated on the scene for what we think are light injuries," a spokesman for Madrid city paramedics told state radio.

Yesterday four suspected Eta members were killed when a car they were driving through Bilbao exploded. Police said that one victim is thought to be Paxti Rementeria, the reputed leader of Eta's extremely violent Vizcaya commando unit.

Eta, a Basque-language acronym for Basque homeland and freedom, is suspected of killing some 800 people since it began a violent campaign in the late 1960s to carve an independent state out of Basque areas in northern Spain and south-west France.

The recent spate of violence included the assassinations in July of a town councillor in the southern city of Malaga and a former senior government official in the Basque country.
