webTitle: Aston Villa

fields.headline: Aston Villa
fields.trailText: Two seasons ago, John Gregory took Aston Villa to the top of the table before dropping so far out of contention as to miss a place in Europe. Last season, Villa began terribly and finished strongly, earning a place in the Cup final and an Intertoto spot. John Gregory will be hoping that he will be able to stretch the positive spells to cover a whole season this year. Football Unlimited, however, suspects the opposite might happen.
fields.body:
Two seasons ago, John Gregory took Aston Villa to the top of the table before dropping so far out of contention as to miss a place in Europe. Last season, Villa began terribly and finished strongly, earning a place in the Cup final and an Intertoto spot. John Gregory will be hoping that he will be able to stretch the positive spells to cover a whole season this year. Football Unlimited, however, suspects the opposite might happen.

John Gregory has made three summer acquisitions: David Ginola, Luc Nilis and Alpay Ozalan. Of Ginola much has been said already, and whether you agree with those who think the Frenchman still has a lot to offer or not, the question remains as to where the winger will fit in Gregory's 3-5-2 formation. Debate over Nilis is less fierce, as his best form has not been in evidence for a couple of seasons. Alpay meanwhile acquitted himself well during Euro 2000, but why Gregory felt he had to strengthen one of the Premiership's meaner defences (35 goals conceded last season) points to perhaps the most decisive factor in Villa's outlook for the season.

Gareth Southgate and Ugo Ehiogu, the two pillars in Villa's backline, are both unsettled at the club. While neither might actually leave (there are, as yet, no offers for Southgate), their continuing presence will hardly do wonders for morale. Add Julian Joachim and Lee Hendrie to the disgruntled mix and you have a team that is pulling in different directions, not one heading for success.

Gregory's bombastic approach to management has not helped matters. He seems to enjoy criticising his players in public so often has he done it, and will ostentatiously drop players like Hendrie, Merson and Carbone despite the effect it has on both the shape and the rhythm of the side (which is questionable at the best of times). However, for the first time in his eventful career, chairman Doug Ellis appears to see Gregory as his man, and stuck with him last season when other managers (Brian Little, for example) might have got the sack. How long this loyalty will last could determine the outcome of Villa's season.

In Luc Nilis (PSV Eindhoven), Alpay Ozalan (Fenerbache), David Ginola (Tottenham)

Out Mike Blackwood (Wrexham), Darren Byfield (Walsall), Steve Watson (Everton), Mark Draper (Southampton)

Odds 80-1

Football Unlimited writers' prediction 11th

webTitle: Arsenal

fields.headline: Arsenal
fields.trailText: The Highbury faithful - so cocksure and confident in recent years - are pensive, and it's not hard to see why. Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit have jumped the good ship Wenger and joined Barcelona in megabucks deals; Davor Suker and Nigel Winterburn have deserted leaving the squad short of cover; and the club's pre-season results have been poor.
fields.body:
The Highbury faithful - so cocksure and confident in recent years - are pensive, and it's not hard to see why. Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit have jumped the good ship Wenger and joined Barcelona in megabucks deals; Davor Suker and Nigel Winterburn have deserted leaving the squad short of cover; and the club's pre-season results have been poor.

So will Arsenal wither away? Well, it's certainly possible. Because their once iron-like defence is rusting, and those loyal roundheads Seaman, Dixon, Keown and Adams aren't going to defy age and injury for much longer. Last season the gaps started appearing and the goals against tally shot up. Expect this to be season the defence that George Graham built finally crumbles.

And losing Petit will make it so much worse. For years the French axis of Petit and Viera have acted like Roman centurions, imposingly guarding the back four. Without them snapping away, those gaps will become even more apparent.

However, there will be compensations. The Cameroonian international Lauren, signed from Real Mallorca for £7.5m, is an attacking, creative midfielder who has already impressed in pre-season. Come next May he will be hailed as yet another master-signing from Wenger.

But the future of Robert Pires, the French international who has the unenviable task of replacing Marc Overmars, is more cloudy. For years people have talked about his enormous potential, but that's largely what it has been. This year he will have to deliver in droves - and even if he does, Overmars destructive pace will still be sorely missed.

Yet Arsenal will still be exceptionally dangerous going forward. Petit and Viera were never noted for their charging runs into the box, but both Lauren and Ljungberg are capable of doing that. Furthermore Arsenal possess Thierry Henry, who scored 16 goals in the last 17 games at the tail end of last season and is a great bet to finish as the Premiership's top scorer.

Of course, any side that boasts Bergkamp, Viera, Kanu, Ljungberg, Adams, Silvinho and Henry - and is managed by Wenger - won't be far away, especially if Sylvian Wiltord and Phillip Cocu come on board. But you usually need a reliable, injury-free defence to win the Premiership - and Arsenal just don't have that anymore.

In Lauren (Mallorca), Robert Pires (Marseille)

Out Davor Suker (West Ham), Nigel Winterburn (West Ham), Narada Bernard (Bournemouth), Jay Bothroyd (Coventry), Marc Overmars (Barcelona), Emmanuel Petit (Barcelona)

Odds 4-1

webTitle: PM's wife under fire from Tories

fields.headline: PM's wife under fire from Tories
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Cherie Booth QC, the prime minister's wife, was yesterday accused of becoming "an unaccountable cross between First Lady and Lady Macbeth" after co-authoring a newspaper article in defence of the new Human Rights Act.
fields.body:
Cherie Booth QC, the prime minister's wife, was yesterday accused of becoming "an unaccountable cross between First Lady and Lady Macbeth" after co-authoring a newspaper article in defence of the new Human Rights Act.

The attack was launched, with the apparent support of Conservative Central Office, by John Bercow, MP for Buckingham and a newly-appointed member of Ann Widdecombe's shadow home affairs team.

"Cherie Blair is breaking the long-standing convention that prime ministers' spouses do not push their own political agendas. It is unclear whether Cherie's end goal is to be lord chancellor or whether she is happy to direct policy from behind the throne," he said.

The Tories have had huge problems getting women elected to parliament: of the 122 women MPs, only 14 are Tories and few have been selected to fight winnable seats at the next election.

Mr Bercow's attack coincided with a report that the Conservative Policy Forum, the link between Mr Hague and grassroots Tories, had warned him the party was anti-gay and in danger of being out of touch on women's issues and marriage.

The MP, who was responding to Ms Booth's article in yesterday's Daily Telegraph, was hitting two targets for the price of one. Tory rightwingers do not like the Human Rights Act which is due to incorporate the European convention on human rights into British domestic law from October 2.

Nor, with the exception of Margaret Thatcher, do they like powerful political women, especially clever women lawyers. "What is clear is that Cherie has a bad dose of Hillary syndrome," Mr Bercow said.

Mrs Blair has spoken out in favour of family-friendly employment policies, job shares and stronger protection against sex and gender harassment.

Yesterday Tory HQ issued a five-page statement highlighting "the increasing public profile of Cherie Booth QC" on such issues, suggesting she may follow Mrs Clinton in seeking elected office.

The reality is more prosaic. Friends believe Ms Booth would like to become a high court judge. That may not be easy while her husband is in No 10. The game plan is said to be that he retires to make money and she makes legal history.

webTitle: Walk-on victims in Milosevic's power play

fields.headline: Walk-on victims in Milosevic's power play
fields.standfirst: The charges against two British policemen in Yugoslavia mark an increase in anti-western agitation as the president attempts to maintain his grip on power, writes Simon Tisdall
fields.trailText: The charges against two British policemen in Yugoslavia mark an increase in anti-western agitation as the president attempts to maintain his grip on power, writes Simon Tisdall.
fields.body:
The regime of Yugoslav president and indicted war criminal, Slobodan Milosevic, upped the ante today in its war of nerves with the west, moving to charge two off-duty British policemen and two Canadians with terrorism and transferring them to Belgrade for a possible show trial.

The two Britons, Det Sgt Adrian Prangnell and PC John Yore, were picked up last week inside Montenegro, close to its border with Kosovo, by Yugoslav federal troops when they were returning from a holiday break on the Montenegrin coast.

Although British diplomats have so far been denied access to the pair, their lawyer said that they may face four counts including attempted terrorism and violating Yugoslav sovereign territory.

The two men are on secondment to the organisation for security and cooperation in Europe, helping with police training in UN-administered, Nato-controlled Kosovo. The Foreign Office dismissed the Serbian charges on Monday as "paranoid" while the men's relatives have described the accusations as ridiculous.

While there seems to be no doubt about the men's innocence, this may not spare them from a long and arduous ordeal. Their misfortune is to have been caught up in a new wave of anti-western agitation launched by Mr Milosevic in the run-up to snap federal presidential elections due on September 24.

As so often in the past, the policemen and the two Canadian civilians (like four Dutch nationals arrested in similar circumstances three weeks ago) have become virtual hostages as Mr Milosevic, using the state-controlled media, attempts to persuade Serbs that they are once again under assault from the western nations that failed to oust him during last year's Kosovo war.

Mr Milosevic is not especially popular among the population of Serbia, but the west is even less so after a year of sanctions and ostracism following Nato's bombing campaign.

The Yugoslav leader is also using the incident to underscore his claims that the pro-western government of President Milo Djukanovic in Montenegro is in league with western spies and assassins determined to subvert the Yugoslav federation.

As in Slovenia, Croatia, Macedonia, and Bosnia over the past decade, there is growing sentiment within Montenegro in favour of independence from the Yugoslav federation dominated by Serbia. But the Yugoslav army maintains 15,000 troops there and Mr Milosevic seems determined to thwart any attempt at secession.

The recent G8 summit in Okinawa expressed support for the Montenegrin leader, as have the US, Britain and some other European countries. But two close neighbours, Italy and Greece, are more ambivalent, fearing another Balkan conflict on their doorstep.

Mr Milosevic, meanwhile, calculates that despite expressions of solidarity, Nato countries would be extremely reluctant to launch another Kosovo-style intervention in Montenegro.

The fate of the two policemen may now depend on the outcome of the September polls. Mr Milosevic's chances of re-election have been helped by a split among the notoriously fractious Serbian opposition parties, which currently plan to field two, rival anti-Milosevic candidates. If he wins, the "hostages" may be quietly released.

If Mr Milosevic loses, all bets are off. As an indicted war criminal wanted by The Hague tribunal, and a man with few friends beyond Moscow and Beijing, he may refuse to relinquish power for fear of being arrested or being forced to go on the run.

If he calculates that he is going to lose the election, Mr Milosevic could launch an even bigger internal crackdown than anything he has attempted in the past. He may also be tempted to provoke Montenegro into open conflict as a diversion from his own troubles and as a way of "uniting" the Serbs in fabricated adversity.

He has tried such tactics several times in the past, and is ruthless enough not to balk at trying them again.

webTitle: Malaysian court finds Anwar guilty of sodomy

fields.headline: Malaysian court finds Anwar guilty of sodomy
fields.trailText: Malaysia's former deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim, was found guilty of sodomy today and sentenced to nine years in prison, the culmination of his two-year battle against what he has called a political conspiracy against him.
fields.body:
Malaysia's former deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim, was found guilty of sodomy today and sentenced to nine years in prison, the culmination of his two-year battle against what he has called a political conspiracy against him.

Before sentencing, 52-year-old Anwar accused his one-time mentor, the prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, of using the judiciary to destroy him, and vowed to keep fighting for democracy from jail.

The nine-year sentence will begin after Anwar finishes serving six years for a corruption conviction handed down in 1999, removing him from the Malaysian political scene that he once seemed destined to lead.

Judge Ariffin Jaka could have imposed a maximum sentence of 20 years for the sodomy conviction, but his verdict was still more harsh than the six years Anwar had predicted. "These are despicable acts in our society," Judge Ariffin said. "This order of offence should meet with utmost condemnation. People who commit such an offence should be dealt with properly." Anwar's last words to the judge were: "See you in 2014."

Anwar's wife, Azizah Ismail, who led a political party carrying his banner of reform in elections last year, lost her composure and their two daughters wept. "An appeal will be filed in 14 days," Azizah told reporters.

Several hundred pro-Anwar supporters gathered outside the courthouse and nearby streets, carrying banners and shouting "Reformasi", the Malaysian word for reform. There was no violence, but protesters were confronted by hundreds of riot police.

Eyewitnesses said at least 12 people were arrested in the protests before and during the verdict, including Tian Chua, a vice-president of the National Justice party led by Azizah.

Anwar veered between acceptance and outrage after the verdict was read. "You have to be realistic. Bloody, rotten judiciary," Anwar said. He added, however, "I can't blame him. He's just following orders." Then he shouted, "Sick!"; and threw up his hands up in frustration.

The trial was Anwar's second since he was removed from office in 1998 and has raised concerns about Malaysia's human rights record and Dr Mahathir's iron determination to extend his 19-year rule, the longest in Asia.

Before he was sentenced, Anwar said that Dr Mahathir had used his dominance of Malaysian politics to crush all dissent. "He is a coward who will not seek responsibility for his own evil, so he used the court," Anwar declared. "Dr. Mahathir's lust for power is insatiable. He will lie and force others to lie."

Judge Ariffin, who had maintained that he would render a verdict based on the facts, not politics, rejected Anwar's claims of conspiracy and also found Anwar's co-defendant and adopted brother, Sukma Dermawan, guilty on the same charge. The two had been accused of sodomising the Anwar family's former driver, Azizan Abu Bakar, one night between January and March 1993.

Sukma was sentenced to six years imprisonment and four lashes with a rattan cane, but Judge Ariffin granted him bail pending an appeal.

Anwar was a high-profile figure on the international stage in the years that he was Dr Mahathir's heir-apparent, but was sacked after the two men increasingly disagreed on how to handle the Asian economic crisis.

Anwar then called for reform of a political system that he said was corrupt and beset with cronyism, bringing some 30,000 supporters into the normally peaceful streets of Kuala Lumpur in the biggest protests in recent memory.

The criminal charges soon followed. Anwar was arrested and beaten in custody by the chief of the national police, fuelling public anger at the government.

Human Rights Watch described the verdicts as "another blow to justice in Malaysia". Joe Saunders, the group's deputy Asia director, said: "What has happened to Anwar and his supporters highlights the fragility of rights there.

"If you're out of favour with the political leadership, no matter how high you might rise in the movement, you have very little protection. This is a real step backwards for Malaysia."

webTitle: Suharto formally charged with corruption

fields.headline: Suharto formally charged with corruption
fields.trailText: Indonesian prosecutors formally filed charges of corruption against ex-President Suharto today and said that, if the former dictator is found guilty, he may spend the rest of his life behind bars.
fields.body:
Indonesian prosecutors formally filed charges of corruption against ex-President Suharto today and said that, if the former dictator is found guilty, he may spend the rest of his life behind bars.

After lodging 3,500 pages of documents with the South Jakarta District Court, state attorney Umbu Laga Lozara said that the man who ruled Indonesia with an iron fist for 32 years will be prosecuted for embezzling the equivalent of about $570m in state funds.

"Suharto has been charged with corruption," he said, as dozens of police officers stood guard around the courthouse. "If he is found guilty, he can be imprisoned for 20 years or life." Current President Abdurrahman Wahid has offered to pardon Suharto if he returns any illegal gains.

South Jakarta District Court Chief Judge Lalu Mariyun said the trial is set to start before the end of August. He added that five judges are due to preside over proceedings, during which 130 witnesses will be called as Suharto is prosecuted by a team of eight state attorneys.

Suharto, 79, was informally charged with corruption last week. Prosecutors allege that he siphoned a fortune in state funds through a complex network of tax-free charities that he controlled to finance the creation of huge business empires for his family and cronies.

Suharto denies any wrongdoing and his legal team says he is too ill to stand trial. They claim a series of strokes has damaged the former president's brain and impaired his memory and ability to answer and understand questions.

Suharto was forced to quit office in May 1998 amid bloody student protests and riots. He has been under house arrest for four months.

webTitle: Elizabeth Wurtzel explains why she loves Britney Spears's

fields.headline: Why I love Britney
fields.standfirst: She doesn't have a great voice, she can't write songs, she isn't even  that beautiful. And yet, aged just 18, this Baptist girl from Kentwood, Louisiana has become the undisputed queen of pop. So just what is it about her?  Elizabeth Wurtzel looks for the answer, and below a rough guide to Britney by Jemima Sissons
fields.trailText: She doesn't have a great voice, she can't write songs, she isn't even that beautiful. And yet, aged just 18, this Baptist girl from Kentwood, Louisiana has become the undisputed queen of pop. So just what is it about her? Elizabeth Wurtzel looks for the answer.
fields.body:
I recently met a man who I'd have to describe as an acid casualty who has never taken acid. He claims to be a film-maker, and has recently directed an instructional video for would-be cult leaders called Mind Control Made Easy. This guy is, naturally, a Nietzschean at heart. And after a few too many beers at a Manhattan microbrewery, he can apply the principles of The Birth of Tragedy to explain his obsession with Britney Spears. "It's the Dionysian drag of her ass and the Apollonian snap of her breasts that's got me hooked," he says. He does not own either of her albums because the drag and the snap have nothing to do with music.

As Britney herself would say, Whatever.

Like most pop culture phenomena, people's fascination with Britney Spears has absolutely nothing to do with what she is purportedly famous for, which is to say, singing and dancing. This is, most understandably, a source of huge frustration for Britney and for many other modern icons: they wish to be famous for their talent. After all, they insist, long before they became a thing, they sang schmaltzy ballads at wedding receptions or acted in soap operas, and were paid to do an honest day's work because they were good at it, not because they were famous, since they were not yet famous.

Hence we have a situation wherein Demi Moore wants to be known as a great actress, not as a pregnant woman with a bare belly on the cover of Vanity Fair. Madonna wants us to believe that The Next Best Thing is a good movie, not that she is just a compelling cocoon of public metamorphoses and an occasional advocate of free expression. Marilyn Monroe married Arthur Miller and then more or less died of her desire to be more than a dumb blonde.

Occasionally, the person actually does transcend the persona. Cher won an Oscar. Princess Diana devoted herself so thoroughly to international good deeds that, by the time of her death, she was actually thought of as an international do-gooder. But mostly you are left with a situation where Britney Spears can say to Rolling Stone: "It's not about my personality. People couldn't see me through the radio."

As if.

Since I myself earned more notoriety for being naked on the cover of my book Bitch than for anything I actually wrote in the pages between, I am intrinsically and intuitively sympathetic with the burden of being Britney. It is, no doubt, a pain in the ass to be all tits and ass. But, my God, she is so good at it that I wish she would simply embrace this role and stop trying to deny it.

Trouble is, unlike all the other aforementioned icons, Britney Spears's entire appeal is in denying her entire appeal. Unlike, say, Madonna, who never pretended to be anything other than an overtly sexual being, Britney Spears has built an entire image around insisting that she does not mean to be sexy. She can't help it if men get hot and bothered when they see her in a schoolgirl uniform, a plaid micro-mini with thigh-high tights and a top tied just below her breasts, the better to bare her slightly fleshy midriff. She can't help it if guys get excited over pigtails and baby fat, the two main characters in her very first video. And it is not her fault if people with dirty minds think that she is asking to be bent over and spanked when she begs a boy to "Hit me baby one more time". It's not her fault that grown-ups don't know that that's just a teenage way of asking a guy to call her pager.

The hot pants and push-up bra on her first cover of Rolling Stone were just normal: down south where Britney comes from and sweat is plentiful, no one wears much clothing. The skin-tight vinyl in the video for Oops ... I Did it Again, the python outfit cut down to there and up to there designed especially for her 18th birthday party, the sequinned cleavage top that served as slight support for her absolutely natural bursting breasts at the American Music Awards and the clingy white jumpsuit she performed in at the Grammys are all a fashion statement, a fun day of dress-up for a little girl raiding Mommy's closet. Choosing Gregory Dark, a director of pornographic movies, to make the video for From The Bottom of my Broken Heart was simply an artistic decision, a tribute to his vision. And she cannot be blamed that lesser minds might find her Yorkshire terrier, Baby, and her tour bus full of puffy pillows and scented candles from K-Mart reminiscent of a New Orleans bordello.

After all, she told YM magazine that she plans to stay a virgin until she is married, and despite rumours of a heady romance, Britney and Justin Timberlake - of the boy band 'N Sync - have only recently enjoyed their first kiss. She is still a good, Baptist girl from Kentwood, Louisiana, who is saddened that she often cannot find the time to attend church when she is on the road. And, whatever perverted fantasies might pollute the minds of men, most of her albums are purchased by pre-pubescent girls with innocent ears who like to sing along with danceable pop songs and love to imitate Britney's style.

In her cover of the Rolling Stones' Satisfaction, lyrics like "He can't be a man because he doesn't smoke the same cigarettes as me" have been excised because Britney Spears would never smoke anything. In another twist on Satisfaction, she even delivers some babe-a-licious feminism: when the girl comes on and tells her "how tight my skirts should be", she doesn't pay attention because "She can't tell me who to be/ I've got my own identity". And when Britney sings the line, "I'm not that innocent", she is just being gamely in a song about playing games.

She is a good actress who, like Brooke Shields as an 11-year-old prostitute in Louis Malle's Pretty Baby, does not really know the implications of the part she is playing. "It's like on TV, if you see Jennifer Love Hewitt or Sarah Michelle Gellar kill someone, do you think they go out and do that?" she asked in a recent Rolling Stone interview. And she is so good at insisting that she has no idea why more people search the internet for naked pictures of her than for any other celebrity that I must admit that I am not certain that she is in on her own image. Who the hell knows?

All this is much too confusing for a simple girl like me.

I like bubblegum music as much as the next person - if the next person happens to be 12 years old. But for all the emphasis on how Britney Spears is a product of some wizardly Swedish producers, I find both her albums damn near unlistenable; optically unnerving; jarringly brassy - like having your ears boxed with a pair of large metal cymbals. Her voice is nothing special. If Dear Diary is any indication, she can't write songs to save her life. And yet I admit I am charmed by Britney Spears. If I am confused by her pleas for sexual absolution, I completely believe that she is a sweet, sweet girl who has worked hard and deserves all her success.

But there's something wrong with this. After all, sweetness should not sell albums; talent should. And I'm pretty convinced that she has little to none. Christina Aguilera, Britney's main rival for the teenybopper, girl-power audience, has a big, beautiful voice. And I think her song What A Girl Wants is a pretty good argument for boys' deference to female desire. But I can't stand Christina - she has none of the Britney charm, none of the sugar, none of the southern honey. Aguilera's music is less irritating, but her personality is more so. Britney wins on congeniality alone.

And who can say that talent is anything so great anyway? Britney Spears's career is basically Debbie Gibson redux, right down to their early days entertaining shoppers as they passed between the Body Shop, the Gap and Laura Ashley in the local malls. Feature for feature, Debbie and Britney look unbelievably alike, neither one a beauty, but both full of cheerleader, popular-girl prettiness that makes them so appealing to teenage girls who can safely aspire to their bottled-blonde good looks. Just as Britney is linked with one of the members of 'N Sync, Debbie was constantly denying rumours that she was dating Jordan from New Kids On The Block. If it were 1988, this essay would be about Debbie Gibson.

But instead of pondering her latent sexuality, any article about Gibson would beg the question about why such a talented teenager would be the purveyor of such schlock. After all, Gibson played the piano, had her own studio in the garage of her parents' Long Island home, actually wrote the songs on her albums and acted as her own producer and arranger. Just the same, in the United States you can buy a porn magazine called Barely Legal and a teenage pop star's career can still be built on her accidental sexuality. Of course, Humbert Humbert's fantasy about Lolita was predicated on the idea that she is unaware of "her own lusciousness, that as a nymphet she is almost grubby and boyish". But later in the book, Lolita - or rather, Dolores - takes the sexual power that Humbert has assigned her and turns it against both of them. By the end, she is a tawdry housewife, and her seducer and tormentor is a ruined man. Lolita did not age very well; awareness destroyed her just as Adam and Eve's eating from the Tree of Knowledge got them expelled from the Garden of Eden.

How long can Britney Spears linger in paradise before all of us notice that her eyes were wide shut all along?

Rough guide to Britney by Jemima Sissons

Born December 2, 1981, in Kentwood Louisiana to a tightknit baptist family. Her mother is a teacher, her father a building contractor.

Career

Auditioned for the Mickey Mouse Club when she was eight years old, but was too young. So after a spell on Broadway she joined the show at 11, along with rival Christine Aguilera and current boyfriend Justin Timberlake.

Debut single Hit me Baby One More Time released in 1998. Album of the same name went straight to number one and sold 27m copies worldwide.

Latest album, Oops ... I Did it Again, was released last May and has sold 13m copies so far.

Love

Goes out with long time childhood sweetheart Justin Timberlake, her co-star in the Mickey Mouse Club. There are rumours that they are engaged. Britney won't have sex before marriage.

Has frequently been linked to Prince William, though has never actually met him. When asked if she would like to marry him, she did say: "Who wouldn't like to be a princess?"

She was recently offered £7.5m for sex by a businessman. She declined, saying it was "totally disgusting".

Friends

Baby, her Yorkshire terrier puppy.

Nyla's Burger Basket - her favourite restaurant in Kentwood. The restaurant proudly claims it is "a Britney family restaurant".

Everybody - her name is searched for on the internet more than anyone else

Enemies

Cyndi Lauper - vehemently opposed to Britney's image: "You don't have to be some little tart," she said, talking of the Lolita image plugged by record companies.

The American Family Association - as above, for her appearance in hotpants on the cover of the Rolling Stone magazine, but didn't take into account the patriotic stars and stripes design on them.

Has built a mock-Tudor house in Louisiana for her and her mother, to pay homage to her love of English antiquity.

webTitle: May the fake be with you

fields.headline: May the fake be with you
fields.trailText: Impressive looking trailer for Star Wars Episode II, made by wannabe film editor and circulated via the internet, exposed as fake
fields.body:
An impressive looking trailer for Star Wars Episode II which has been circulated via the internet has been exposed as a fake, Hollywood.com reports today.

Although the film only began shooting two weeks ago, a Star Wars fan site promoted the trailer, which shows futuristic landscapes, warriors running with ignited lightsabres and some romantic moments between young Darth Vader and Queen Amidala.

The wannabe film editor who made the trailer is so worried about reprisals from Lucasfilm that s/he has chosen to be called simply the Anonymous Director. In an interview with Hollywood.com, s/he explained the inspiration behind the trailer: "I was a little let down over Episode 1. I wanted something to help restore my faith in the Star Wars saga. I initially shared the work with friends and other Star Wars fans I knew. When they loved it, they suggested I put it on the internet for all the other Star Wars fans in the world."

As well as clips from previous Star Wars episodes, the Anonymous Director has also used scenes from Dune, Braveheart and Last of the Mohicans. To have a peek at the trailer go to TheForce.net.

webTitle: Denouncing the devil in Nick

fields.headline: Denouncing the devil in Nick
fields.standfirst: The Sun is busy again with a campaign against Big Brother contestant Nick. But Gwyn Topham wants to cheer this summer pantomime villain
fields.trailText: The Sun is busy again with a campaign against Big Brother contestant Nick. But Gwyn Topham wants to cheer this summer pantomime villain.
fields.body:
While the News of the World has been making the public aware of paedophiles in their midst, its sister paper the Sun has also taken it upon itself to alert a vulnerable group to an unknown danger: namely, to reveal to his unsuspecting housemates the duplicitous machinations of "Nasty Nick" on Channel 4's gameshow Big Brother. It is, once again, an ill-judged campaign.

With every move in the Big Brother house recorded, the viewing public has had the opportunity to see the character of Nick, a 32-year-old broker from Fulham, in gruesome detail.

An instinctive Machiavellian, he quickly grasped the essential joy of the contest: that while the world at large may hate him and would vote him out at any opportunity, his flatmates are none the wiser.

Befriending them individually, he avoids nomination and by extension, the chop. Of 38 votes for ejection cast by contestants so far, Nick has received not one.

His deliciously brazen dealings are fast becoming the stuff of legend in viewing circles. Most spectacularly, having arrayed the entire male contingent into a voting bloc to ensure the ejection of either Caroline and Sada, within minutes Nick was seen outside comforting the upset women separately, assuring them he would hate to see either leave the house.

Having warmed up, Nick spotted a real danger in Anna, a lesbian ex-nun who has proved well-liked by all the housemates. Nick was soon spotted casually remarking to other individuals how Anna - lovely though he found her --was playing the situation very well.

Leaving even the least strategically-minded contestant chewing thoughtfully, Nick would glide off to leave the same words hanging in another ear.

The complete joy of Nick is his sheer bloody-minded egotism. Loudly professing the importance of team-playing in group discussions, the cameras catch him smoking from a hidden stash of the house's remaining cigarettes while the others go through the agonies of nicotine withdrawal. (Nick, an insurance broker, declares himself a non-smoker on the Big Brother website). "It's crazy to share everything, otherwise it just goes," he reasoned.

This was too much for the Sun, who responded to anguished howls from readers by attempting to breach the contestants' news blackout with a leaflet drop from a helicopter.

Yet the Sun and Nick should be soulmates. Both are manipulative and cunning. Both attempt to hide their deeply conservative and moneyed souls from the public under a veneer of laddishness.

While News International, built on union-bashing, steers itself firmly in the image of white van man and manages to portray itself as the workers' friend, the Gordonstoun-educated Nick cultivates a modishly footballing image.

And if any of the rather bland Big Brother bunch had the resourcefulness and cheek to carry out a similar stunt to the Sun's chopper escapade, it would only be Nasty Nick.

Ultimately, Nick has provoked such intense antipathy because he embodies what Hollywood constantly portrays, and what the rest of Europe has long suspected - the Englishman can't be trusted.

While we prefer to term it manners or a stiff upper lip, the French characterise us as perfidious Albion, a nation of hypocrites. Nick may be square-jawed, well-bred, and, in his ostensible attempts to ease domestic crises, embodying the famous Dunkirk spirit.

But the hidden cameras have revealed that it is perfectly possible to show all of these things to the people around you and be a backstabbing egotist.

In truth, none of the contestants can be genuinely unmoved by the £70,000 prize for the last remaining housemate. Only Nick, in a philosophical moment, has owned up: "Life is like a shit sandwich. The more bread you have the better it is."

Avaricious, duplicitous and a consummate politician, Nick has become the undoubted star of this summer's pantomime. And the Sun would do well to remember that no good pantomime can operate without a villain.

In truth, none of the contestants can be genuinely unmoved by the £70,000 prize for the last remaining housemate. Only Nick, in a philosophical moment, has owned up: "Life is like a shit sandwich. The more bread you have the better it is." Avaricious, duplicitous and a consummate politician, Nick has become the undoubted star of this summer's pantomime. And the Sun would do well to remember that no good pantomime can operate without a villain. Useful links Channel 4's Big Brother

fields.standfirst: Ten rumours put in a house for nine weeks and monitored until the entire country realises every single one is totally objectionable
fields.trailText: Real Madrid coach Vicente del Bosque is prepared to sell Steve McManaman, according to Planet Football. "I have pointed out to him that there are others in front of him at the club and said there is little chance of him playing this year," del Bosque revealed yesterday. In addition, Spanish newspaper Marca has suggested that a "top five" club has joined Middlesbrough and Aston Villa in the race for the ex-Liverpool winger. Planet Football throws the names of Arsenal and Leeds into the ring, but argues that Chelsea would be the only club prepared to meet McManaman's £80,000-a-week wage.
fields.body:
Real Madrid coach Vicente del Bosque is prepared to sell Steve McManaman, according to Planet Football. "I have pointed out to him that there are others in front of him at the club and said there is little chance of him playing this year," del Bosque revealed yesterday. In addition, Spanish newspaper Marca has suggested that a "top five" club has joined Middlesbrough and Aston Villa in the race for the ex-Liverpool winger. Planet Football throws the names of Arsenal and Leeds into the ring, but argues that Chelsea would be the only club prepared to meet McManaman's £80,000-a-week wage.

Aston Villa boss John Gregory wants Celta Vigo duo Benni McCarthy and Valery Karpin. However, the Express claims chairman Doug Ellis will sanction an £8m bid for striker McCarthy, but will not stretch to a similar fee for the 31-year-old Russian.

Joonas Kolkka, the PSV Eindhoven striker being tracked by Leeds, is now on Celtic manager Martin O'Neill's shopping list, according to Planet Football. The 25-year-old Finnish international's agent, Kees Ploegsma, said: "If PSV were willing to allow him to leave he would be interested in moving to a club of Celtic's size and reputation. Coming to Scotland certainly would not be a problem for him."

Lazio coach Sven Goran Eriksson wants to be the next manager of Manchester United. "I would love to manage Manchester United," said the man Jack Walker once tried to install as manager of Blackburn yesterday. "When you talk about the big clubs, they are one of the greats. You have Real Madrid, Bayern Munich, Barcelona, Juventus, AC Milan and United. I want to take Lazio to the top but we cannot compete with the history and reputation of these clubs." Eriksson, who only has one year left on his contract with the Italian champions, would have to take at least one year off if he wants to take over from Alex Ferguson - the current United boss has two years left on his contract.

Napoli are to increase their efforts to sign Gianfranco Zola from Chelsea. Club president George Corbelli said: "Zola is our objective and we will put in more lira in our attempt to persuade Chelsea to let him leave."

Regi Blinker, who was freed by Celtic at the end of last season, is a target for Bolton. Bolton are also interested in 23-year-old Icelandic striker Andri Sigurdsson - they have competition from Portsmouth.

Preston have taken Bermudan strikers Steve Astwood and Roban Simons on trial.

webTitle: Matthew Engel: in praise of 40 winks after lunch

fields.headline: In praise of 40 winks after lunch
fields.standfirst: Why do the British ruthlessly persecute afternoon-nappers?
fields.trailText: Why do the British ruthlessly persecute afternoon-nappers?
fields.body:
It is important for a chap approaching his middle years to maintain his zest for life by acquiring a new interest. Adultery is an ever-popular option, but tends to go down badly with one's wife. Golf even more so. For those who really wish to irritate their loved ones, extremist religion can be far more effective.

Woodwork requires dexterity, and the appeal of German lessons fades very fast. Me, I prefer to sleep. Not the early nights of childhood or the long lie-ins of youth, destroyed by work, parenthood and a changing metabolism. My hobby is my siesta.

It has taken time to raise the courage to tell you this. Afternoon-nappers are ruthlessly persecuted in Britain. Although most of us have been exposed on summer holidays to the enlightened views of southern Europe, British prejudice on the subject has, if anything, hardened.

Over the past 20 or 30 years, open-plan offices have made a quiet catnap at the desk far more difficult. And a more ferocious work ethic has made it more dangerous too: "Look, old Engel's asleep!" "He's losing it, y'know. We better have a look at his contract." Utter rubbish. Everyone knows how hard it is to achieve anything in the hour after lunch. Employees who accept this, and deal with it, return to their jobs re-energised.

Don't just listen to me. "Napping is part of being a productive worker," says William Anthony, professor of psychology at Boston University. "If we operated machinery the way we treat our body," says James Maas of Cornell University (author of Power Sleep), "we would be accused of reckless endangerment." And enlightened American firms have taken their advice. The train operator Conrail actually instructs its freightyard workers when to break off and sleep. Other companies have set aside nap rooms, in some cases providing pillows and blankets.

British attitudes remain primeval. Our workplaces usually have less space than American ones. But since fewer people drive there, the option of slipping off to the car park for 40 winks is less widely available. Some are believed to aim for the loo and rest their heads on the toilet paper. Who dares admit it?

Yet the problems caused by sleep deprivation are worsening. "Tiredness can kill," say the motorway signs. "Take a break." Still, drivers urge themselves onwards. That really is reckless endangerment: a third of accidents on the M40 have been attributed to drivers dozing off, especially in the afternoon.

Long hours spent at computer screens are quite obviously tiring too. But usually only the smokers take the sort of breaks that everybody needs.

Sometimes, people respond to my passionate advocacy of napping by saying that they have tried it and end up feeling worse. That's just bad technique. I can't explain the science here, but it seems to me that lunchtime fatigue is different from whole-body night-time tiredness: it is a tiredness of the eyes. And the right response is a different kind of sleep.

First, a nap should be just that. Half-an-hour is far too long. Ten to 15 minutes is perfect - but, in extremis, I have found that even a microsleep of a few seconds can be refreshing.

Second, you should not recreate night-time conditions. Deep sleep is not the idea. The room should not be too dark. Don't stretch out full-length even if that option is available: if your lifestyle allows you to go to bed, then prop yourself up with pillows and remain facing forward. Use an alarm clock if you're worried. A car seat rolled back to 45 degrees is actually a near-ideal angle. My own great ambition is an office big enough to contain a chaise longue.

And of course far greater men than me have proved the efficacy of all this. The Holy Roman Emperor Charles V was the pioneer of siestas. Winston Churchill, power-napper supreme, won the war that way. Bill Clinton is said to be a devotee. Maybe he combines his naps with adultery. But sex can be a sensible optional extra even for married couples: there is some evidence that sperm-counts are higher in the daytime and that conception is more likely then.

That is not the point, though. I contend that siestas produce a happier, more productive and more effective workforce. It is time for employers to accept this, to end the outrageous prejudice against dozers - nappism - and let staff give in gracefully to their body-clocks. Should you acquire the habit on holiday this month, I urge you not to fight it on your return to work.

 This column is about to take a slightly extended summer break. It will be back in the autumn, God and the editor willing. After all, I'm out as a napper now. Is the Guardian liberal enough to tolerate such a person? The hell with it: I'm off for a zizz.

Matthewengel@ndirect.co.uk (office closed: 2pm-2.15pm)

webTitle: Diary: Richard Adams

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: •There must be something in the air inside the Labour party at the moment - love, to be precise. Only a few days after the marriage of Gordon Brown and Sarah Macaulay - which had been so confidently predicted in the Diary - comes news of another match made in Millbank Tower.
fields.body:
There must be something in the air inside the Labour party at the moment - love, to be precise. Only a few days after the marriage of Gordon Brown and Sarah Macaulay - which had been so confidently predicted in the Diary - comes news of another match made in Millbank Tower.

The latest issue of A Women's Place, a newsletter sent to Labour party women, carries some charming news from Labour's national women's officer Rachel MacLean - the person, you may recall, who advised female candidates not to wear "dangly earrings" to parliamentary selection meetings. "For those of you I haven't already told, I will be getting married on 12 August." Hurrah! Hats off. "My surname will change to McCollin." Isn't it a bit odd for the national women's officer to take her husband's surname? "And in case you think that it's a bit odd for the national women's officer to take her husband's surname, it's a combination of our two names, McLean and Collins." The Diary sends its best wishes to the happy couple for Saturday. But in the sad event of a divorce, who takes the Mc?

Back to Gordon and Sarah, the couple were looking radiant on honeymoon in Cape Cod. That's according to the Mail and the Mirror yesterday (I wouldn't advise taking our word for it), in stories that were virtually identical in every respect - except one. According to the Mirror, the MacBrowns will be visiting "left-wing writer" Noam Chomsky (how romantic, eh?). But the Mail thinks the couple will also be visiting another left-wing writer, named Norm Chomsky. Ah, those Chomsky brothers. It's so hard to tell them apart.

A copy of a wonderful letter from Biffa Waste Services arrives, which suggests that Donald MacIntyre perhaps shouldn't have bothered with a revised edition of his semi-official biography of Peter Mandelson. "To whom it may concern," writes Gillian E Lyall, key accounts manager for Biffa. "We confirm that the loads of waste material ... contained 944 copies of the publication Mandelson." Oh dear. "These loads were taken in their entirety directly to Patersons of Greenoakhill landfill site and disposed in accordance with the site operators instructions, ie landfill." Better luck for the second edition, Donald.

I'd advise reading this next item after the 9pm watershed, but here goes. I'm indebted to The Register website for pointing out www.williamhague.com, which is illustrated. But not of that William Hague. Oh no. "Hi, I am William Hague and a very keen naturist," it reads. "I am not William Hague the conservative politician from England!" It's worth a look, but please, not in front of the children. (According to the site, the naturist William Hague is willing to sell the address, so I'd advise Central Office to nip around with a cheque.)

Poor Gerald Ford suffered a couple of mild strokes last week, but something seemed a bit wrong earlier the same day when the former US president did a phone-in interview with a cable TV channel at the Republican convention. A viewer phoned in, saying she was Iranian and wanted to know what a Republican administration might do in terms of improving the US relationship with Iran. "I'm a great onion eater," replied Gerry. "I had a delicious onion relish with my steak last night. It's one of my favourite delicacies ..." before being cut off by the studio host. Gerald's recovering and should be out of hospital in a few days, but still sounds in better shape than Ronald Reagan during most of his presidency.

Here's a special message for dedicated readers who have managed to get this far. Tomorrow's Diary will contain one of the most explosive stories of the summer. It's all very hush hush at the moment. Loose lips sink ships, and all that. But I can say this: I'd read tomorrow's Diary if I were you, David Yelland. Oh yes.

webTitle: Moving targets

fields.headline: Moving targets
fields.standfirst: The chancellor's public service agreements are an admirable idea, but putting them into practice raises awkward questions of responsibility
fields.trailText: The chancellor's public service agreements are an admirable idea, but putting them into practice raises awkward questions of responsibility
fields.body:
Like party-goers on the morning after, Whitehall departments are wondering just what they signed up to during Gordon Brown's orgy the other week. His largesse comes with strings attached - public service agreements (PSAs), contracts between ministers and the Treasury to deliver.

PSAs are not new. Mark I was launched in December 1998, to run from April 1999 to March 2002. Too many, too artificial, critics said. Only a third of them referred to what government does (outputs) rather than how it does it (processes). Too many, the former Labour MP and spending expert John Garrett snorted, were boring: who cares about civil servants' sick leave?

Mark II is also a mixed bunch. By 2004, the Treasury tells the Department for Education and Employment, school truancy should be cut by 10% compared with 2002; at least 38% of 16-year-olds have by then to pass at least five GCSEs at grades A* to C. There is to be a one-tenth reduction in the number of pregnant mums who smoke. By 2004, 17% of household waste is either to be recycled or composted. By 2002, the satisfaction of victims of crime with their treatment by the criminal justice system is to improve by 5%.

That one is worth re-reading. Can "satisfaction" be so easily measured? A single event - the Tony Martin case, say - could have lasting effects on perceptions of the fairness of courts and the law.

Some PSAs turn out to be redescriptions of what Whitehall is doing, but dressed up in pseudo-precise language. The Foreign Office promises to oversee "the launch of a new broad-based liberalising trade round". That is not a target. It is highly controversial policy-making, as recent argument about the ideology behind the World Trade Organisation shows.

The problem with PSAs is not just methodology. Targets only work if somebody can be fingered if they are not met. So is Gordon Brown now to sit in judgment on his cabinet colleagues' performance? Or his own? Take the targets now set for Sure Start, the ambitious programme to improve life chances for pre-school children from poor families. One is to "reduce the number of children aged 0-3 in Sure Start areas living in households where no one is working" - by 2004. This depends on macroeconomic circumstance. But who is responsible for economic prosperity if not the chancellor of the exchequer (ie the Treasury itself) and the monetary policy committee of the Bank of England? It is a bit harsh for the Treasury to say the only people responsible for this PSA are public health minister Yvette Cooper and David Blunkett.

Last week Giles Radice led the majority on the Commons' Treasury committee in recommending that PSAs should be monitored by someone other than the Treasury, perhaps the audit commission and the national audit office. These bodies are presented as the ultimate citizens above suspicion, neutral experts on spending. But is there such a thing? The audit commission has its own set of targets and injunctions as to good behaviour by the local authorities it supervises. To check councils are delivering this Best Value programme, there is a separate army of inspectors. What happens if they overlap or even conflict with the PSAs which the Treasury has now extended to councils?

The NAO is the executive arm of the public accounts committee, which is chaired by a partisan Tory, David Davies. He has shown signs of wanting to use the office to score party points rather than develop tools for understanding why good intentions do not always turn into effective programmes of public spending.

The NAO annual report claimed that it has saved the taxpayer £1.3bn over the past three years. But that is only 0.21% of the £600bn of the spending it audited - where are its "targets"? The NAO, like the audit commission, cannot quite decide whether its principal job is to be bookkeeping, making sure money is properly accounted for, or asking hard analytical questions about the very purpose of spending.

That quickly embroils you in political argument for which accountants and civil servants are unsuited. Even harder, the critics may have to suggest better ways in which spending can be delivered. The UK administrative system is crawling with inspectors, auditors and, now, connoisseurs of PSAs and targets; it lacks for people who do. Who is going to tell those pregnant mums to quit smoking? Who is going to turn around a failing school or renew the litter-strewn estate? Taking money away from an under-performing hospital doesn't make political sense.

Mr Brown's spending plans expose the gap between ministers' intentions and the sharp end. The PSAs for councils are being tried out in seven areas, including Camden and Warwickshire. They are based on bribery: local authorities get extra if they perform. The problem is that councils are not dogs in Pavlov's experiments, salivating on cue. They are complex groupings of public, politicians and officials, professionals and amateurs. Labour favours active social policies which involve changing the way people behave. Can a PSA capture the tricky business of exhortation, incentive and rule-making by which that target on smoking in pregnancy could be realised?

The case for PSAs is that without objectives, the ship of state will drift. But make them too detailed and you risk burdening those who should be out there serving the public with excessive form-filling; alternatively, they will simply be ignored.

Treasury committee 9th report can be read at www. publications.parliament.uk david.walker@theguardian.com

But who is responsible for economic prosperity if not the chancellor of the exchequer (ie the Treasury itself) and the monetary policy committee of the Bank of England? It is a bit harsh for the Treasury to say the only people responsible for this PSA are public health minister Yvette Cooper and David Blunkett. Last week Giles Radice led the majority on the Commons' Treasury committee in recommending that PSAs should be monitored by someone other than the Treasury, perhaps the audit commission and the national audit office. These bodies are presented as the ultimate citizens above suspicion, neutral experts on spending. But is there such a thing? The audit commission has its own set of targets and injunctions as to good behaviour by the local authorities it supervises. To check councils are delivering this Best Value programme, there is a separate army of inspectors. What happens if they overlap or even conflict with the PSAs which the Treasury has now extended to councils? The NAO is the executive arm of the public accounts committee, which is chaired by a partisan Tory, David Davies. He has shown signs of wanting to use the office to score party points rather than develop tools for understanding why good intentions do not always turn into effective programmes of public spending. The NAO annual report claimed that it has saved the taxpayer £1.3bn over the past three years. But that is only 0.21% of the £600bn of the spending it audited - where are its "targets"? The NAO, like the audit commission, cannot quite decide whether its principal job is to be bookkeeping, making sure money is properly accounted for, or asking hard analytical questions about the very purpose of spending. That quickly embroils you in political argument for which accountants and civil servants are unsuited. Even harder, the critics may have to suggest better ways in which spending can be delivered. The UK administrative system is crawling with inspectors, auditors and, now, connoisseurs of PSAs and targets; it lacks for people who do. Who is going to tell those pregnant mums to quit smoking? Who is going to turn around a failing school or renew the litter-strewn estate? Taking money away from an under-performing hospital doesn't make political sense. Mr Brown's spending plans expose the gap between ministers' intentions and the sharp end. The PSAs for councils are being tried out in seven areas, including Camden and Warwickshire. They are based on bribery: local authorities get extra if they perform. The problem is that councils are not dogs in Pavlov's experiments, salivating on cue. They are complex groupings of public, politicians and officials, professionals and amateurs. Labour favours active social policies which involve changing the way people behave. Can a PSA capture the tricky business of exhortation, incentive and rule-making by which that target on smoking in pregnancy could be realised? The case for PSAs is that without objectives, the ship of state will drift. But make them too detailed and you risk burdening those who should be out there serving the public with excessive form-filling; alternatively, they will simply be ignored. webTitle: Dicing with death on France's murderous roads

fields.headline: Dicing with death on France's murderous roads
fields.standfirst: Every hour of every day someone dies on a French road. Jon Henley in Paris looks at the reasons for this startling statistic
fields.trailText: Every hour of every day someone dies on a French road. Jon Henley in Paris looks at the reasons for this startling statistic
fields.body:
Business as usual on the French road network yesterday: in the early morning a coach overturned on the A71 near Vierzon, killing a 15-year-old British schoolboy and badly injuring four other people. French police are considering the possibility that the Scottish driver fell asleep at the wheel.

Then at two in the afternoon, for reasons as yet unknown, a heavy goods lorry ploughed through the central safety barrier of the A7 outside Valence and slammed into a truck travelling in the opposite direction. The drivers, both French, were killed instantly, as was the young daughter of one of them who was riding with him in the cab.

A couple of hours later, the driver of an army truck carrying 20 foreign legionnaires apparently lost control of his vehicle and drove into a tree near Castelnaudary in the south of France. Four young soldiers died and seven others were seriously injured.

These were dramatic accidents, and the one involving the British coach -- which was carrying 38 children and eight adults from Scotland and Essex to a week's canoeing, raft-building, abseiling and windsurfing holiday in southern France -- made headlines here as well as in Britain.

Armand Jung, a French socialist MP, has renewed calls for an outright ban on overnight coach journeys, citing statistics that show the worst road accidents occur between 2am and 7am. "Tour operators just want to save a night's hotel bills, so the passengers sleep on the coach," he said. "Unfortunately, so do the drivers, even if they take shifts at the wheel."

But French road accident statistics show a lot more than that. The busiest weekend of the year, when July holidaymakers returning home cross August vacationers heading south, was relatively accident-free this year thanks to some 400 miles of tailbacks around the country.

The three spring Bank Holiday weekends, however, clocked up 271 dead and more than 5,000 injured. On average, one person (1.037, to be exact) dies every hour on a French road. Since 1945, almost as many French people have been killed in cars as died in the second world war.

In fact, France's roads are more dangerous than those of any other country in Europe except Greece and Portugal, where surfaces tend to be lousy and cars old. In 1998, there were 144 French road fatalities per million inhabitants, compared with 117 Italian, 93 German and 58 British.

Even Isabelle Massin, who heads the government's inter-ministerial working group on road safety, is not optimistic. "The average French person does not take driving offences seriously," she said. "We have never had such tough road legislation, but French society just does not react. Murderous driving is a French disease."

The main cause of this mass slaughter is well known: the French still drink and drive, and they do it more than anyone else in Europe. Alcohol is the most important factor in more than 30% of fatal French road accidents, a proportion that has not changed in 20 years. In Britain over the same period, it has halved.

According to the statistics, the French also gaily ignore speed limits, red lights and stop signs more frequently than all their European neighbours, and somehow neglect to fasten their seatbelts as often.

University sociologists looking for an explanation for such behaviour have seized on one interesting fact: the worst danger on French roads is posed not by the young hothead but by the middle to upper-level executive, aged 35 to 50 and driving a fast, expensive car.

The authoritative daily, Le Monde, recently argued that with people like this -- adult, responsible citizens -- heading the accident statistics, France was clearly grappling with a problem that was about more than just bad driving. Maybe, it suggested, driving represented a subconscious desire by the French to escape from their nannying, ever-present state, to thumb their noses at the forces of law and order. In protestant northern Europe, it suggested, people tended to have a much better developed sense of collective responsibility.

Jean-Pascal Assailly, a psychologist who specialises in driver behaviour, says the French tolerate dangerous driving because "it's a kind of agreed escape valve for violence. In America, everyone has a gun. In France, we speed. We love speeding. Speeding is a positive value in French society, like confidence, competitiveness and a stylish disregard for danger. The car satisfies that".

Sadly, for some 8,500 people a year, that "stylish disregard for danger" means the end of their lives. And until there is the will to change French attitudes, through effective anti-drink driving campaigns, better traffic policing, road safety education from primary school up, and maybe (why not?) a ban on overnight coach journeys, accidents like yesterday's will continue to happen.

webTitle: Radioactive MoD sites sold 'blind' for building, says nuclear watchdog

fields.headline: Radioactive MoD sites sold 'blind' for building, says nuclear watchdog
fields.standfirst: Special report: Britain's nuclear industry
fields.trailText: Sites contaminated with radioactivity have been sold by the Ministry of Defence and used for housing, factories and recreational use without the new owners being told, the government's nuclear watchdog says in a report out today .
fields.body:
Sites contaminated with radioactivity have been sold by the Ministry of Defence and used for housing, factories and recreational use without the new owners being told, the government's nuclear watchdog says in a report out today .

The MoD's "bash, burn and bury" policy of disposing of surplus stores and equipment meant that many of the 3,000 military sites were contaminated with radioactivity and other substances. The problem was made worse by the MoD's habit of destroying records of what sites contained, says the government's radioactive waste mangement advisory committee.

The report was ordered by the government because the MoD is selling off many of its land holdings spread over 600,000 acres. The MoD says hundreds of sites might be contaminated with toxic substances but the RWMAC estimates that "tens of sites" are contaminated with radioactivity.

The committee says that most of the contamination came from radium-226, a substance commonly used for luminous dials and other components, but there was also tritium and promethium-147 - all three of which are cancer-producing agents.

The report says: "It is not clear how many sites that were once part of the MoD estate have been returned to civilian occupation or the extent to which these may have been contaminated with radioactivity."

The policy of destroying records had not helped with the inquiry but tests demonstrated significant radioactive contamination of MoD land in regular use by members of the public. The committee also feared that some radium may get into ground water used for public consumption and advised the MoD to check.

The problem arose partly because in times of war standards fell below those of peacetime. As a result MoD sites could be littered with hazardous substances, including munitions, solvents, hydrocarbons, heavy metals and asbestos, as well as radioactive materials.

"Bash, burn and bury practices inevitably fell short of what would be considered acceptable today," the report says.The report makes clear that not all these problems were caused by the war.

The MoD continued to use radium luminising until the 1960s. The committee also discovered that some sites had been so badly surveyed before sale that they had failed to detect radioactivity which subsequent investigation had revealed.

The issue had not been given sufficient funding to compile proper reports, the inquiry revealed.

The report suggests that the MoD should compile a list of those sites already disposed of and assess the possibility of contamination and investigate. No one at the MoD doubted that such contaminated sites existed, the report says.

The report recommends better compiling and keeping of records both for contamination and remediation carried out.

The chairman, Charles Curtis, said: "Our view is that the current planning system alone cannot ensure that land to be redeveloped for new uses will be properly cleaned up.

"The planning system simply was not designed for this purpose."

webTitle: Compromise proposals tabled over hunting

fields.headline: Compromise proposals tabled over hunting
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Spot fines of up to £5,000 could be levied on foxhunters who broke new regulations designed to protect both hounds and foxes from cruelty, according to a compromise designed to end the stalemate over hunting without imposing a ban.
fields.body:
Spot fines of up to £5,000 could be levied on foxhunters who broke new regulations designed to protect both hounds and foxes from cruelty, according to a compromise designed to end the stalemate over hunting without imposing a ban.

In an effort to bring both sides of the divisive issue together, the Middle Way Group of MPs and their supporters yesterday published a plan to create a statutory hunting authority - to supervise more closely regulated hunting by licensing hunts and by staging unscheduled inspections.

With a clear majority of the Commons in favour of a ban, but the Lords unlikely to back such a move, the government is seeking to resolve the protracted controversy by offering MPs a range of options.

Yesterday the Liberal Democrat MP for Montgomeryshire, Lembit Opik, whose campaign is backed by Labour's Llin Golding and the Tory Peter Luff, appealed for both sides to join in debate to find a "sensible and rational solution".

Admitting his group was a minority voice, Mr Opik said they had spent less than £3,000 to advocate a compromise, compared with hundreds of thousands spent by the Countryside Alliance and opponents like the League Against Cruel Sports.

webTitle: Opposition says Draskovic a spoiler

fields.headline: Opposition says Draskovic a spoiler
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Fifteen Serbian opposition parties yesterday chose the nationalist leader of the Democratic party of Serbia as their candidate to run in September against the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.
fields.body:
Fifteen Serbian opposition parties yesterday chose the nationalist leader of the Democratic party of Serbia as their candidate to run in September against the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.

"We unanimously decided to name Vojislav Kostunica as our joint candidate," Dusan Mihajlovic, leader of the New Democracy party, said.

Party officials met in Belgrade to make their decision after crisis talks with the biggest opposition party, the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO), which had nominated its own candidate on Sunday despite appeals not to risk splitting the opposition vote by going its own way.

The SPO leader, Vuk Draskovic, said that he had not changed his mind about his candidate, the Belgrade mayor Vojislav Mihajlovic, who the rest of the opposition fear will split the anti-Milosevic vote in the September 24 election.

Mr Kostunica, chosen by the other parties because his nationalism reflects popular opinion in Serbia, yesterday abandoned his acceptance condition that Montenegro, Yugoslavia's smaller republic, would stop its boycott of the vote. The public was expecting him to run, he said.

A recent opinion poll gave Mr Kostunica greater popularity than President Milosevic, while the Belgrade mayor backed by Vuk Draskovic has not even appeared on pollsters' lists.

The Democratic party leader, Zoran Djindjic, said Mr Draskovic would not discuss a joint candidate.

Mr Mihajlovic said that Mr Draskovic's insistence on his own presidential runner meant that he could not join their candidate lists for local elections, also due September 24.

"We unanimously supported the idea of going together with SPO to all elections, but after the SPO came out with its separate presidential candidate, we decided that a coalition is impossible at one level if there is competition at another."

Mr Djindjic said Mr Kostunica's advantage was that he could travel to Montenegro and Kosovo, whereas Mr Milosevic could not.

Montenegro's pro-western authorities have agreed to cooperate with the UN war crimes tribunal. It has indicted Mr Milosevic for war crimes committed by Serb forces last year in Kosovo before Nato bombing forced the withdrawal of the Yugoslav army from the province, which mainly ethnic Albanian .

"Our candidate can go everywhere," Mr Djindjic said. "And where can Mr Milosevic go? To his bunker. Well, let him win in his bunker; we will win in Serbia."

On the right, meanwhile, the ultra-nationalist Radical party has proposed Tomislav Nikolic, its vice-president and Yugoslav deputy prime minister, as its presidential candidate for September.

webTitle: Holocaust outburst widens Israeli rifts

fields.headline: Holocaust outburst widens Israeli rifts
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The rabbinical sage who called Holocaust victims sinners, and Arabs snakes, demanded police protection yesterday after a Jewish stalker was arrested outside his Jerusalem home.
fields.body:
The rabbinical sage who called Holocaust victims sinners, and Arabs snakes, demanded police protection yesterday after a Jewish stalker was arrested outside his Jerusalem home.

Anger at the outburst by Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef, Israel's most politically powerful rabbi, showed little sign of subsiding among Palestinians or Jews - despite his half-hearted attempt to soften the shock of his weekend diatribe.

In a second sermon, released to Israeli television yesterday and broadcast on the pirate radio networks of his followers, Rabbi Ovadiah accused his critics of misinterpreting his words.

"Who doesn't bemoan the Holocaust?" asked the spiritual leader of the Shas party. "Six million Jews, among them 1m children were killed by the wicked Nazis. All were holy and pure and complete saints."

However, in his original sermon the rabbi had said the 6m embodied earlier souls who had "sinned time and again and were reincarnated so that things could be set right".

That was the version that reverberated across Israel yesterday, threatening to deepen the two faultlines cleaving Israeli society: the antagonism between secular and ultra-Orthodox Jews, and the economic and cultural divide between Jews of European origin, and the Jews of Middle Eastern origin, or Sephardim, who form the majority of the underclass.

Support groups for the 300,000 Holocaust survivors in Israel said that they were flooded by calls and visits.

Some survivors were hungry for a genuine expression of regret from the rabbi. Others wanted to hold a vigil in striped concentration camp uniforms outside the rabbi's house - where police arrested a man who said he wanted to "put a bullet through the head" of Rabbi Ovadiah. The unarmed man said his family had perished in the Holocaust.

"All the losses and all the memories are coming flooding back to people," said Rachel Peterburg of the Amcha organisation, which counsels Holocaust survivors. "They really need an apology so they can go on with their lives."

But there was no sign of such an apology from the rabbi yesterday, or from leaders of the Shas party, said Noah Flug, leader of the Centre of Organisations of Holocaust Survivors, and an Auschwitz survivor who lost 119 family members to the Nazis.

Instead, officials of the Shas party called for a 24-hour police guard for their leader to stem the tide of protest against his remarks. And the rightwing and religious Hatzofeh newspaper accused Israeli television and radio of fabricating the sermon.

"Radio stations have broadcast what sounds like the voice of Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef saying these things, and on television, his figure is seen speaking these words," the newspaper said. "The rabbi is simply not capable of saying such things; the conclusion is that those who are slandering Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef ... are employing impersonators."

The extreme reactions to the rabbi's sermons illustrates the centrality of the Holocaust to non-Orthodox Israeli Jews.

"In the non-religious part of Israel, the Holocaust is increasingly important and has become a very very central part of Israeli identity," said author Tom Segev, who has written extensively about the Holocaust.

"There are some who say the Holocaust is practically a religion. It is the way non-Orthodox Israelis connect to Jewish history. If the Orthodox world attacks the Holocaust, it definitely deepens the gap in Israeli society."

The annual commemoration of the Holocaust has been a source of friction. Some ultra-Orthodox Jews ignore the siren that sounds two minutes' silence each year on Holocaust Day, arguing that the dead should be remembered only through prayer.

Even so, few Orthodox religious scholars would dare to argue as Rabbi Ovadiah did that the Holocaust was God's way of punishing sin. Most believe the Holocaust is too enormous an evil to be understood by mere human beings.

webTitle: Leader: The Dome is not the only Millenium money failure

fields.headline: Millennial money
fields.standfirst:
The dome is not the only failure
Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The Millennium Commission is a "good cause". Since 1993 it has been spending a part of the proceeds of the national lottery. The dome has been its most controversial offspring; less noticed have been worthwhile schemes like cycle-ways, science centres and wobbly bridges.
fields.body:
The Millennium Commission is a "good cause". Since 1993 it has been spending a part of the proceeds of the national lottery. The dome has been its most controversial offspring; less noticed have been worthwhile schemes like cycle-ways, science centres and wobbly bridges. Not all of them, however, are succeeding when compared to promoters' plans. The amazing success of Tate Modern, confirmed by new figures yesterday, is the gold standard; many would-be museums will struggle for bronze. So here comes Patrick Green of the Museums Association saying that certain schemes should be cancelled and the savings banked as a reserve in case of difficulties.

An old saw is being played here. Museums and galleries - with arts groups and voluntary bodies of all sorts - want help with running costs as well as capital. What use is a building if you cannot afford staff, they ask. But grant-givers (the Millennium Commission is not alone) want a permanent reminder of their largesse and don't want to get sucked into open-ended support. Ideally, capital grants for buildings should come trailing one-off endowments to produce a dedicated income stream.

One of Patrick Green's candidates for the chop is in Cardiff, which has seen much new building lately. The other is The Tower in Portsmouth, over which some have seen white elephants flying for years. The commission is nothing if not politically sensitive; fierce regional (national) lobbies are at work, which may explain why Yorkshire appears to have a number of marginal projects. But it will win no public thanks for littering towns with follies and empty shells. Visitor numbers can be more accurately forecast and allowances made for the weather. Commercial criteria need not be rigorously applied to projects that have an educational or cultural content but thresholds of viability must be set. The sad history of the dome should steel millennium commissioners to take hard decisions.
