webTitle: Arts: Edinburgh: Festival diary

fields.headline: Festival diary
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh Festival 2000
fields.trailText: Special report: the Edinburgh Festival 2000
fields.body:
You've heard about the bogus social worker; now we've got the bogus tourist information officer. Presumably the worst offenders direct the public to toilets they know are closed. The Diary has spotted a crack squad of young folk handing out flyers, wearing yellow jackets stamped with a black "i" on the back. They come from a comedy promoter called Fatbloke Productions, which by pure coincidence has chosen the same uniform as that worn by the council's own city centre reps.

"This is the first I've heard of it," said chief Fatbloke Andrew Collier, when the similarity was pointed out. "Our intention was to fill a gap. During the festival there are a lot of visitors who need help finding directions." Despite this clearly altruistic motive, the council plans to investigate.

Big Brother has arrived in Edinburgh. Word is filtering out from the Pleasance of a shadowy coupling captured on the CCTV cameras after the venue closed in the early hours of Sunday morning. This would imply it was an inside job, though the venue is keeping tight-lipped about the identity of the amorous pair. The Diary has its suspicions, but this paper does not operate a name-and-shame policy. These people know who they are, and must be praying that the video does not fall into unfriendly hands.

The red carpet at the fringe's opening gala on Sunday night remained pristine after a couple of notable no-shows. The rope line was thronged with paparazzi who had been tipped off that Dannii Minogue was in town, while Boy George was also due to put in an appearance. In the end the snappers had to make do with Susannah York. Perhaps the prospect of arriving in a courtesy car supplied by the event's sponsors, Skoda, was just too appalling. Still, fun was had without them at Dynamic Earth, which looks not unlike the Millennium Dome, except with visitors.

webTitle: Move to merge probation and jail roles attacked

fields.headline: Move to merge probation and jail roles attacked
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Official plans published yesterday to merge the prisons and probation watchdogs into a single inspector of corrections were last night attacked as a politically driven means to curb the power of the chief inspector of prisons.
fields.body:
Official plans published yesterday to merge the prisons and probation watchdogs into a single inspector of corrections were last night attacked as a politically driven means to curb the power of the chief inspector of prisons.

The trenchant reports on jail conditions by Sir David Ramsbotham and his criticism of wider criminal justice policy have repeatedly stung Home Office ministers. He has also proved a thorn in the side of the prison service ever since he led an inspectors' walkout of Holloway prison, in north London, because it was filthy and infested with rats.

A Home Office consultation paper published yesterday confirmed that ministers are considering the abolition of his separate job and merging it with the post of the chief inspector of probation.

The Home Office minster Paul Boateng said: "There is already considerable overlap in the work of the two services and this should be reflected in the inspection process. We are looking at ways of best ensuring that inspection arrangements support joint working between the prison and the probation services. Equally we must ensure that nothing is lost in the current independence and rigour of the inspection process for either service."

The official consultation document says that more than a third of those sent to prison will spend part of their sentence under the supervision of probation officers, and "the public has a right to expect that we do in fact have a coherent system either side of the prison gates which works to reduce reoffending".

It does, however, recognise that there is "a potential risk that the chief inspector's responsibilities become so wide that he or she is not sufficiently in touch with practice on the ground to inspire the confidence of the public or of ministers".

The director general of the prison service, Martin Narey, is already pushing for some common standards to be laid down for the chief inspector of prisons, so that governors are not torn between satisfying Mr Narey's objectives and those of Sir David when they clash. For example, Sir David recently criticised prisons that provide only a narrow range of education at a time when Mr Narey asked them to concentrate on expanding literacy teaching.

Sir David's five-year term in office expires in November and he has been given only a nine-month extension. The chief inspector of probation, Sir Graham Smith, is also due to retire next summer.

Last night Harry Fletcher, assistant general secretary of the National Association of Probation Officers, said the merger seemed bizarre at a time when a national probation service was being created, the first national director of probation had been appointed, and probation had just received public funds to expand its courses to tackle reoffending.

"It does seem a means of reducing the power of the prisons inspectorate. Everybody suspects it is politically driven, and the real agenda is about reducing the impact of the prison inspector."

webTitle: Leader: Arrests of off-duty policeman in Montenegro bears hallmarks of Milosevic provocation

fields.headline: The Milosevic miasma
fields.standfirst:
Another Balkan crisis is brewing

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The arrests of two off-duty British policemen and two Canadian civilians by the Yugoslav authorities in Montenegro, and the subsequent, outrageous moves to charge them with terrorism and espionage, bear all the hallmarks of a Slobodan Milosevic provocation.
fields.body:
The arrests of two off-duty British policemen and two Canadian civilians by the Yugoslav authorities in Montenegro, and the subsequent, outrageous moves to charge them with terrorism and espionage, bear all the hallmarks of a Slobodan Milosevic provocation. But given that Belgrade knows very well that the two Britons, seconded to the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe to help with police training in Kosovo, are victims, not villains, who or what is the real target of the indicted Yugoslav dictator's latest machinations?

With snap presidential and federal elections called for September 24, Mr Milosevic has already begun to use the case to highlight what he claims are the west's continuing attempts to subvert the Serbian nation. The incident, whether or not it leads to a show trial, will be exploited for electoral ends, with Mr Milosevic cast by supine official media as a vigilant defender of freedom against vengeful Nato countries that failed to destroy him during last year's Kosovo war. Another case, that of four Dutchmen recently held and accused of plotting to kidnap or assassinate Mr Milosevic, can be expected to be used in a similar way.

The arrests of the Britons and Canadians are also of use in embarrassing and provoking the Montenegrin president, Milo Djukanovic, on whose territory they were seized by federal troops. The pro-western Mr Djukanovic, who has made no secret of his fervent wish to quit the Yugoslav federation and has declared a boycott of the forthcoming elections, is proving ever more irksome to Belgrade. Despite the presence in Montenegro of an estimated 15,000 Yugoslav army troops, Mr Djukanovic has succeeded in securing increasingly high-level pledges of support from the US and Europe, and from the recent G8 summit in Okinawa.

But Montenegro, with a significant number of Serbs among its population, is by no means united on the question; and Mr Milosevic knows full well that Nato would be reluctant, to put it mildly, to launch another Kosovo-type intervention if he sought to impose direct rule from Belgrade. Growing concerns that he may do exactly that after September 24 were the subject of recent White House and Nato meetings, with Clinton officials reportedly fearful that a Yugoslav military move against Mr Djukanovic may be timed to coincide with the paralysing climax of the US presidential campaign. Fabricated incidents such as that involving the two Britons are part and parcel of Mr Milosevic's now only-too-familiar strategy of destabilisation and terror in Montenegro and elsewhere.

The debauching of the federal constitution, the silencing of much of the remaining independent media in Serbia, the abuse of the judicial system, and the intimidation of moderate Serbs (especially in Kosovo) are other tools that Mr Milosevic is currently employing to prolong his reign. To counter him, the US and others have urged Serbia's many opposition parties, and the Montenegrins, to unite behind a single federal presidential candidate. But true to form, they have failed miserably to agree and appear set on fielding two, rival candidates who will split the anti-Milosevic vote.

The fate of the two Britons and the other detainees is thus only one aspect of a far bigger dilemma: how to stop Mr Milosevic stealing the elections and provoking yet another Balkan war, this time in Montenegro. Whatever Britain, Nato, the UN and the Osce may do, the best chance may lie with Russia and China, which still have direct influence with Mr Milosevic. They should be prevailed upon to use it, before it is too late.

webTitle: Leader: Selection of Lieberman as running mate reinforces Gore's credentials as a moderate

fields.headline: Gore goes for safety
fields.standfirst:
He should have picked a woman

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Once George W Bush selected Dick Cheney as his running mate, it became clear that Al Gore would need to make a smart, eye-catching choice of his own.
fields.body:
Once George W Bush selected Dick Cheney as his running mate, it became clear that Al Gore would need to make a smart, eye-catching choice of his own. In an election light on policy differences, questions of character are set to loom large - and the choice of potential deputy is about the most significant choice a presidential candidate ever makes. Today Mr Gore is set to name the baritone-voiced senator from Connecticut, Joseph Lieberman, as his No.2. It is certainly an eye-catching choice - for reasons that may not please the candidate. But is it a smart one?

In the credit column is Mr Lieberman's status as one of the senate's most respected figures. His willingness to break ranks and attack President Clinton early over the Monica Lewinsky affair should inoculate the Gore ticket on that issue. Now it will be much harder for Bush- Cheney to cast themselves as restorers of integrity to the Oval Office: Gore-Lieberman are squeaky clean. The senator also runs no risk of outshining the perennially dull Mr Gore, and reinforces the candidate's credentials as a moderate, "new" Democrat in the centrist, Clinton mould.

But there is a downside. Mr Lieberman is cut from the same wooden timber as Mr Gore. What the Democrats needed on the ticket was a candidate with zip who might create genuine excitement. An immediate buzz would have come from picking only the second female candidate for national office in US history. Mr Gore could have done that; or at least picked a younger, fresher face. Instead he has chosen a man who is solid, worthy and of undoubted integrity - but who is unlikely to set this race on fire.

One fact about Mr Lieberman is dominating the instant reaction to his choice: he is the first Jewish candidate for national office. And he does not just "happen to be" Jewish, but is a devout Jew who never works on the sabbath and who will do no campaigning during this autumn's high holidays. Some believe that will not only win over America's 6m Jewish voters but also play well with committed Christian voters who like politicians "of faith" - no matter what that faith is.

But it also sets America a question. Just as John F Kennedy's candidacy asked America whether it was ready for a Catholic president, now the US has to decide if it is ready for a Jew a heartbeat away from the Oval Office. Just for raising that question, Mr Lieberman's choice is a welcome one.

webTitle: Gore allies himself to integrity

fields.headline: Gore allies himself to integrity
fields.standfirst:
Running mates compensate for candidates' weaknesses

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore took a leaf out of George W Bush's book yesterday, opting for gravitas rather than glamour in his choice of vice-presidential running mate for the Democrats.
fields.body:
Al Gore took a leaf out of George W Bush's book yesterday, opting for gravitas rather than glamour in his choice of vice-presidential running mate for the Democrats.

For all the occasional talk of putting a woman or a black candidate on the presidential ticket one day, both have in the end following the way of all but one of their predecessors: picking an ageing white male to reassure the voters.

By choosing Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut, Mr Gore gives the line-up an apparent symmetry of age and appeal. In both cases the younger man heads the ticket for the November 7 election.

Although the age difference between the candidates and their running mates is narrow, the cultural gap on each ticket is much wider.

Mr Gore, 52, and Mr Bush, 54, are self-evidently part of the same rock'n'roll generation as 53-year-old President Bill Clinton. But Mr Lieberman, 58, and the Republican vice-presidential nominee Dick Cheney, 59, could almost pass for their parents, and are unmistakably the products of the Eisenhower rather than the Kennedy years.

The similarity ends there, however, since Mr Lieberman has much less experience of Washington and public life than Mr Gore, whereas Mr Cheney has been chosen in part to compensate for Mr Bush's glaringly short political track record.

The two men's political histories are very different, too. Mr Cheney was a youthful Republican high-flyer, recruited to work in the Nixon White House while still in his 20s, becoming Gerald Ford's White House chief of staff at 34, and defence secretary under President Bush after 10 years as a Wyoming congressman. He remains a quintessential Washington insider.

Mr Leiberman, on the other hand, has built his political career entirely in his home state, Connecticut. Born in Stamford, where his father owned an off-licence, he went to Yale (as did Mr Cheney, who dropped out), served in the state senate in 1970-80, ran unsuccessfully for Congress, and served two terms as Connecticut attorney general before winning a US Senate seat in 1988.

At first sight both seem to have been picked for essentially defensive reasons. Mr Cheney brings White House experience to Mr Bush, Mr Lieberman brings integrity to the Democratic ticket. His moral stature helps Mr Gore to shake off the shadow of the Clinton-Lewinsky affair, to say nothing of the persistent allegations of campaign fundraising improprieties in 1996.

Mr Lieberman was one of seven Democrats Mr Gore's spin-doctors said last week were under consideration. In reality, at least three of the short-list - Bill Bradley, Dick Gephardt and Jeanne Shaheen - were only there to make Mr Gore look broad-minded. The real choice came down to three senators: John Edwards of North Carolina, John Kerry of Massachusetts, and Mr Lieberman.

All three have centrist political instincts, like Mr Gore, and each came with a characteristic whose political impact Mr Gore had to weigh carefully in making his choice: Mr Edwards is inexperienced, Mr Kerry is married to a Heinz foods heiress, and Mr Lieberman is now be the first Jew on a White House ticket.

A further crucial contrast between was immediately apparent yesterday. While Mr Cheney spent his final hours before joining the Bush campaign arranging his tax affairs at the giant oil multinational Halliburton Corporation in Dallas, Mr Lieberman went ahead with a speaking engagement at a trade union conference in Hartford.

"I can't think of a place I'd rather be this morning at this momentous time in my life than with you, the working people of the state of Connecticut," he told them. Such words would be improbable, to say the least, coming from Mr Cheney.

The two will spend most of the next three months going their separate ways. Mr Cheney is likely to spend much of the campaign in the south and west, where he will exploit his conservative record and views to mobilise the Republican voter base. Mr Bush, meanwhile, will take his greater appeal to moderates and independents to the swing states of the midwest.

Mr Lieberman's role is likely to be less sectional. As a moderate he is certain to play a big role in the midwest himself.

They will come face to face just once during the campaign, in a vice-presidential debate which will be televised from Danville, Kentucky, on October 5.

Vote getters

Joseph Lieberman: Senator 1988-present

For
Tax cuts for small businesses
Gulf war use of force resolution
Sale of F-15s to Saudi Arabia
School vouchers experiment

Against
Ban on 'partial birth' abortion
Humanitarian aid to Cuba
Ban on flag-burning
Oil drilling in Alaskan wildlife reserves
Cutting aid to Vietnam
Cutbacks in national missile defence

Dick Cheney: Congressman 1979-89

For
Sale of Awacs to Saudi Arabia
Raising pensionable retirement age
Covert aid to Contras
Production of MX missiles
Humanitarian aid to contras
Cutting federal spending on health, labour and education

Against
Oil profits windfall tax
Equal rights amendment
South African sanctions and release of Nelson Mandela
Notifying workers before plant closures
Seven-day waiting period for hand-gun purchases

webTitle: Gore ditches Clinton legacy

fields.headline: Gore ditches Clinton legacy
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore staked his tottering White House dream on the high moral standing of America's first Jewish vice-presidential candidate yesterday, selecting Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut as his running-mate in a move that symbolically underlined the end of the Bill Clinton era.
fields.body:
Al Gore staked his tottering White House dream on the high moral standing of America's first Jewish vice-presidential candidate yesterday, selecting Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut as his running-mate in a move that symbolically underlined the end of the Bill Clinton era.

"Miracles happen," a delighted and emotional Mr Lieberman told reporters outside his home in New Haven. Mr Lieberman will be officially unveiled as the number two on the Democratic ticket at an event in Nashville today.

Mr Gore's surprise choice finally draws the line between the Clinton years and his own candidacy in his attempt to overcome George W Bush's daunting poll lead. A Gallup poll yesterday showed Mr Bush 17 points ahead of Mr Gore following last week's Republican convention.

No Democrat is better qualified to convey that message than Mr Lieberman, who on the Senate floor in September 1998 delivered the most memorable moral denunciation of Mr Clinton's conduct towards Monica Lewinsky of the 15-month impeachment crisis, castigating the president's behaviour as "inappropriate, immoral and harmful".

The public reprimand was all the more telling because Mr Lieberman and Mr Clinton are old friends from Yale Law School days and political allies on the right of the Democratic Party, who agree on most issues of political substance. Mr Lieberman was the first senator to endorse Mr Clinton's presidential bid in 1992.

"I think he's one of the most outstanding people in public life," Mr Clinton said yesterday. "He's a bold thinker. He's always full of new ideas."

Mr Gore's choice of running mate is a gamble, more on account of the 58-year-old Connecticut senator's relative national obscurity than because of his religion as an orthodox Jew who refuses to campaign on the Sabbath.

Mr Lieberman is from humble origins, the son of a drinkstore owner from Stamford. He has spent his whole career in Connecticut politics, where he was twice attorney-general before winning a US Senate seat in 1988. His wife, Hadassah, whose parents are Holocaust survivors, is also orthodox Jewish. The couple have four children.

Before he made his attack on Mr Clinton, Mr Lieberman was most prominently in the public eye for his assaults on television and media depiction of violence and obscenity, in which he joined with the Republican campaigner William Bennett to denounce gangsta rap lyrics and the Jerry Springer Show, among many other targets.

There are 11 Jewish senators, but Mr Lieberman is unusual in his observances of kosher dietary laws and Sabbath laws. When the senate meets between sunset on Friday and sunset on Saturday Mr Lieberman takes part, but walks three miles from his home to avoid using motor vehicles.

The issue of Mr Lieberman's religion will be attentively watched in the Middle East, but is unlikely to be a major factor in the election, most observers believe, although it is in the nature of these things that few voters openly admit to anti-semitism. A poll in March 1999 suggested that 92% of Americans would vote for a Jew as president.

The decision was welcomed as "a milestone in America's political maturity" by Abraham Foxman of the Anti-Defamation League. "While anti-semites and those on the fringe of society who subscribe to conspiracy theories may have a field day, we remain confident the American people will dismiss the extremists and consider him on his public record," Mr Foxman said.

By choosing Mr Lieberman, Mr Gore has opted for a running-mate from the Democratic right who can appeal to the electoral centre-ground which Mr Bush staked out last week in Philadelphia.

Mr Lieberman has one of the most independent voting records among all Democratic senators, cooperates regularly with moderate Republicans, and has voted against his party on issues such as national missile defence and school voucher experiments, both of which he supports.

Mr Bush had no public comment on his rival's choice yesterday, but his spokesman Ari Fleischer said Mr Lieberman was "a good man. It's nice that the vice-president has picked someone who agreed with Governor Bush on so many issues."

Even before getting Mr Gore's call, Mr Lieberman was quickly into on-message political action yesterday, telling a trade union rally in Hartford that he was "happy to be here at a convention where working people are a priority, not as they were in Philadelphia last week, just props".

webTitle: Why Barak needs the controversial sage

fields.headline: Why Barak needs the controversial sage
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef has a penchant for antagonising secular Israelis - over the years he has cursed the supreme court, cabinet ministers, kibbutz dwellers, doctors and Israeli Arabs. Yet his view of the peace process between Israel and the Palestinians is far more liberal than that of other religious leaders.
fields.body:
Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef has a penchant for antagonising secular Israelis - over the years he has cursed the supreme court, cabinet ministers, kibbutz dwellers, doctors and Israeli Arabs. Yet his view of the peace process between Israel and the Palestinians is far more liberal than that of other religious leaders.

The followers of Rabbi Ovadiah's Shas party, overwhelmingly members of an Israeli underclass made up of Middle Eastern and north African Jews, take a hardline view of negotiations with the Palestinians. But the Baghdad-born rabbi has argued since the early 70s that religious law supports territorial concessions - if they save Jewish lives. That stance, together with the 400,000 voters who see the rabbi as a divine figure - and the network of religious schools it has fostered - has transformed Shas into a powerhouse.

It is the third largest party in the Israeli knesset (parliament) and its departure from the ruling coalition last month robbed the Labour-led government of its majority in parliament.

By fusing ethnic pride with ultra-orthodoxy and a relatively mild approach to the quest for peace, Shas has in theory been a willing coalition partner for rightwing and leftwing governments since the 1980s.

The party proved its muscle yet again last week when it got a relative nonentity elected president instead of Nobel prize winner Shimon Peres. After the rabbi's remarks on the Holocaust and Arabs, liberal commentators yesterday urged the prime minister to stop wooing Shas back.

"Any pursuit by Ehud Barak of the blasphemous rabbi, from this moment on, will be considered un conscionable kowtowing, the disappearance of any trace of self respect, grovelling," a leader in the Tel Aviv daily Ma'ariv said.

But Mr Barak will continue to grovel. His emissaries were hard at work yesterday courting the rabbi's acolytes.

"Shas represents a political reality that can not be ignored. To have any real power to make decisions regarding the peace process, the coalition needs Shas," said a commentary in Ha'aretz newspaper, which criticised Mr Barak for failing to hold regular meetings with the rabbi.

webTitle: Cluster bombs: the hidden toll

fields.headline: Cluster bombs: the hidden toll
fields.standfirst:
Landmine campaigners accuse Nato of suppressing evidence casting doubt on weapon's effectiveness
Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The number of civilians prey to unexploded cluster bombs is significantly higher than admitted by governments, including the British, which have consistently suppressed evidence about the weapon's military effectiveness, according to a devastating report published today.
fields.body:
The number of civilians prey to unexploded cluster bombs is significantly higher than admitted by governments, including the British, which have consistently suppressed evidence about the weapon's military effectiveness, according to a devastating report published today.

Cluster bombs, which contain at least 147 "bomblets" scattered over a large area, were used extensively in the Vietnam, Falklands and Gulf wars, and most recently during Nato's air assault on Kosovo.

Cluster bombs have killed 50 people - about one a week - over the past year in the Serbian province, and injured more than 150, says the report by the UK Working Group on Landmines, a charity combining non-government agencies and funded in part by the Princess of Wales Memorial Fund.

"The unexploded bomblets effectively turn into landmines, ready to detonate on contact, causing death and injury to civilians even many years after the war has ended," said Richard Lloyd, the group's director. "As many are brightly coloured and the size of a drinks can, they are particularly attractive to children."

The report by Rae McGrath, a leading campaigner against landmines, shows the effect of cluster bombs in earlier conflicts is being ignored by confused and indiscriminate military strategies.

Cluster bombs were dropped from medium and high altitudes during the Kosovo conflict despite official US assessments after the 1991 Gulf war that they were likely to miss their targets.

The Ministry of Defence, which says RAF planes dropped 531 cluster bombs during the Kosovo war, quotes the manufacturer's estimate of a 5% failure rate. But the UN Mine Action Coordinating Centre in Kosovo gives a much higher figure.

"In Kosovo, preliminary statistics for the British RBL755 [a cluster bomb available on the open arms market] show that the failure rate is about 11-12%", the centre said in March.

Moreover, the MoD has itself admitted that the failure rate of cluster bombs used in the Falklands was at least 9.6%, nearly twice as high as the manufacturer's claims.

The bomblets are designed to explode on impact but a soft surface or the presence of trees - cluster bombs were dropped against concealed targets in wooded areas of Kosovo - can lead to "substantial failures", today's report says.

Evidence from the use of cluster bombs in Kosovo, the Gulf war, US military trials, and the Falklands conflict indicate that failure rates range between 9% and 30%, the report says. The difference between a 5% and a 9% failure rate in Kosovo would mean more than 3,000 more unexploded bomblets in the province.

Cluster bombs are capable of turning huge areas into killing fields. The report says it is clear from censored figures that their use in Kosovo was disproportionate to any military advantage gained.

It says official figures of targets destroyed during the bombing have been discredited by the release of details from the US Munitions Effects Assessment Team (Meat) which conducted a comprehensive investigation immediately after the campaign.

The Meat report was suppressed - even the UN could not get a copy - and replaced by one written by the chairman of the US joint chiefs of staff, General Henry Shelton, based mainly on interviews with aircrews.

The Shelton report estimated that 140 tanks, 220 armoured personnel carriers, and 450 artillery pieces were destroyed in Kosovo. Meat's figures are, respectively 14, 18, and 20. The Meat team found that of 744 "confirmed" Nato strikes, there was only evidence of 58 successful ones.

The 50 people killed by Nato cluster bomblets since the end of the bombing campaign include two British soldiers and a young boy whose death was witnessed by a 13-year-old friend.

The friend, who underwent a double leg amputation, recalled: "I went with my cousins to see the place where Nato bombed. As we walked I saw something yellow - someone told us it was a cluster bomb. One of us took it and put it into a well. Nothing happened... We began talking about taking the bomb to play with and then I just put it somewhere and it exploded.

"The boy near me died and I was thrown a metre into the air. The boy who died was 14 - he had his head cut off."

In June, in its report on the lessons from Kosovo, the MoD described cluster bombs as "an effective weapon against area targets such as a group of soft-skinned military vehicles". It added: "Nevertheless, we have learned that it would be useful to have a capability to strike single vehicles more accurately..."

Today's report says: "The continued use of cluster bombs has cost thousands of civilian lives, denied land to the poor and disenfranchised and is now costing the international community millions to eradicate the unexploded submunitions... To continue this distortion of the truth [the official claims of a 5% failure rate] while ignoring the advice of experts from the military and civilian mine-clearance community, is unforgivable."

Cluster bombs are not covered by legislation banning landmines since they are not "designed" to be detonated by people on the ground. Today's report calls for a new international law making governments, the military and manufacturers fully responsible for the clearance of unexploded bomblets and for marking affected land, paying compensation to civilians and handing over to the UN full records of cluster bomb deployment.

As a first step, it says, there must be a global moratorium on their use, manufacture and sale, pending an in-depth review of their legality and impact.

A global threat

Laos
More than 25 years after the Vietnam war, 500,000 tonnes of unexploded bombs remain, most of them cluster weapons.

Falklands
More than 100 British cluster bombs were dropped; more than 1,400 unexploded bomblets were cleared after the conflict.

Kuwait
More than 1,400 Kuwaitis were killed in incidents involving unexploded bombs and landmines after the Gulf war. The most dangerous were cluster bomblets.

Kosovo
200 people have been killed and more than 400 were injured by landmines and unexploded ordnance, including more than 50 people killed by Nato cluster bomblets. To date, UN and K-For troops have cleared more than 11,000 unexploded cluster bombs out of a total 30,000.

Elsewhere
Cluster bombs were used by Russian forces in Chechnya, by both sides in the Eritrea-Ethiopia war, by Nigerian forces in Sierra Leone, and by the government in the Sudan civil war.

webTitle: Robin Day, television's grand inquisitor, dies at 76

fields.headline: Robin Day, television's grand inquisitor, dies at 76
fields.trailText: Sir Robin Day, the television broadcaster famed for his aggressive yet courteous interviewing style, has died aged 76.
fields.body:
Sir Robin Day, the television broadcaster famed for his aggressive yet courteous interviewing style, has died aged 76.

Best known for his stewardship of BBC1's Question Time during the 1980s, the tenacious inquisitor died on Sunday night at Wellington hospital in north London.

A spokesman for the hospital yesterday said Sir Robin had died peacefully at 9pm. He had been admitted for a number of days as doctors investigated a heart condition. The broadcaster had been in hospital several times over the past year and in 1997 had had a pig valve fitted to his heart.

Day, who started his TV career as an ITN newscaster in 1955, built a reputation as a probing but polite interviewer and yesterday his death drew tributes from interviewees and fellow broadcasters in equal measure.

The BBC's John Humphrys, Jeremy Paxman and David Dimbleby agreed Day had fathered the modern political interview.

"At his best, there was simply nobody better," Humphrys said. "At one stage we were all totally obsequious and a difficult question was, 'What else do you have to say to a grateful nation, minister?'

"Robin changed all that. He recognised... politicians were just like the rest of us. He broke that taboo, and we are all his beneficiaries."

David Dimbleby, the current presenter of Question Time, said: "He had a barrister's training, a theatrical instinct and an absolute belief in the public right to know."

Lady Thatcher, a politician with whom Day regularly crossed swords, said: "Sir Robin Day singlehandedly pioneered modern political interviewing, and he excelled at it.

"Our paths often crossed and I always enjoyed the joust. He was tough and relentless."

The European commissioner and former Labour leader Neil Kinnock said: "He was unsurpassed and, with his mixture of knowledge and idiosyncrasy, he gave personality and passion to the task of interviewing."

The former prime minister John Major said: "Sir Robin Day set a new standard for interviewing. He was simply the best there has been."

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, said: "Robin Day set the tone for a generation of political interviewers. His skill as an interviewer was as distinctive as his bow ties."

The Conservative party leader, William Hague, described Sir Robin as "one of the greatest broadcasters of the age". "We should remember him for his reverence to the viewing public and his irreverent sense of humour towards politicians," he said.

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, described Day, who once stood as a Liberal parliamentary candidate, as "a towering figure in the history of broadcasting".

"He was the inventor of a style of political interviewing which set a trend and a benchmark for all his successors.

"He abandoned deference in favour of well-informed, persistent and penetrating questioning. A joust with Robin was always a challenge and always a treat. We shall all miss his razor-sharp mind, his wit and his instinctive sense of fairness very much."

Alan Yentob, director of BBC drama, entertainment and children's programming, called Day "one of the great characters of British journalism". "He will be remembered with affection and gratitude by millions of BBC viewers."

fields.body:
There was an outcry, talk of an international incident and protests to the Home Office last night after customs officials barred the "stars" of the world's last true flea circus from entering the country.

The Cardoso Flea Circus is having to recast its show at the Edinburgh Festival after its crack troupe of hybrid "superfleas" were turned back at Heathrow airport as illegal immigrants.

All survived the 21-hour flight back to Australia but were "visibly traumatised by their ordeal", according to the show's producer Tory Laudon, who has protested to the "highest level".

William Burdett-Coutts, artistic director of the Assembly Rooms, who helped bring the circus to Britain for the first time, said: "This is no way to treat artists."

The troupe, which includes several tightrope-walking fleas, came from a special crossed strain of kangaroo and cat fleas, ctenocethalides felis, which the circus's founder, Maria Cardosa, has been breeding for years.

Their exploits are projected on to a large screen from a camera fitted with a magnifying lens so audience can fully appreciate their skill and daring. But yesterday Ms Cardosa was frantically assembling an alternative cast from fleas sent from Cambridge and Bristol universities. The show must go on in Princes Street Gardens tonight.

Her flea wrangler, Wyman Leung, has been picking out potential stars and working one to one with them.

Ms Laudon said the Sydney-based circus had never have had a flea flee from it in all its years on the road. The circus had not bothered trying to train "rather stupid" human fleas, the pulex irritans, although some local Scottish cat fleas were found to have "amazing tenacity."

webTitle: Arts: Edinburgh: The Tempest performed in your own home? Lyn Gardner loved it

fields.headline: All the flat's a stage
fields.standfirst:
The Tempest performed in your own home? It sounds like a gimmick - but Lyn Gardner loved it. And Ferdinand even did the washing up

Special report: the Edinburgh Festival 2000
fields.trailText: The Tempest performed in your own home? It sounds like a gimmick - but Lyn Gardner loved it. And Ferdinand even did the washing up.
fields.body:
We find the paper boat long after they have left. It is sitting on the mantelpiece, the only relic of the transformations that have taken place in the flat and in our heads during the past two hours. We unfold the boat and smooth out the paper. It is the final page of the first folio of The Tempest.

Signal to Noise's production of The Tempest is performed in your own house, flat or venue of your choice. This sounds like a good Edinburgh wheeze: the company does not have to pay exorbitant venue-hire charges and the audience do not have to travel. But in a festival full of gimmick and hype, The Tempest turns out to be a rough-and-ready but enchanting version of the play. The young cast of six, who turn up off the street like strolling players, begin the play without any to do. At the end they evaporate into the night like shy spirits without even taking a bow.

Edinburgh during the festival is all about transformations - the city becomes a carnival and every available space is turned into a theatre for a few weeks. But Signal to Noise's production takes the idea of theatre as transformation even further, completely transforming your relationship with your living space. I cannot now sit on our sofa without having a mental picture of the exuberant Ariel bouncing up and down with sheer joy at the prospect of freedom. This production of The Tempest is a sharp reminder of something we so often forget: theatre is an experience that you have, not a place that you go.

It is the brainchild of director Chris Goode, who began working on a student version at Cambridge back in 1994 after reading an interview with Peter Hall, who argued that Shakespeare could not be performed in tiny spaces. He revived the idea when the year-old Signal to Noise decided that it would like to have an Edinburgh presence but couldn't afford the venue fees.

Goode is at pains to point out that while Signal to Noise may become known in Edinburgh as the company that allows you to "dial-a-Tempest" , it has no plans to make a habit out of performing in people's homes. There will be no follow-up versions of Psycho in your bathroom or Lady Chatterley's Lover on your tigerskin rug. Nor is the company making a fortune. Since they charge £40 for an audience of up to six, this is undoubtedly the best-value show in town.

As far as Goode is concerned, people's homes are simply the best place to perform a play that is all about changing perceptions, altered states and geographical confusions, allowing him and the cast to take the audience on a journey in which the familiar becomes disconcertingly unfamiliar. On Sunday night in the Guardian's Edinburgh flat, a bedroom doorway became Caliban's lair and Ferdinand was found undertaking Prospero's tasks (better known as our washing up) in the kitchen. The production takes place in semi-darkness using an array of improvised lighting from torches and bicycle lamps to candles and fairy lights.

There is something infinitely touching about watching Miranda and Prospero's murmured conversation from just a foot away, and hearing Shakespeare being spoken not declaimed. The effect is less like watching a play than eavesdropping. "When you are doubling up characters you have to make sure that the storytelling is really clear and sharp," says Goode. "You can't get away with tricks or technique. People can see through it. Very early on we decided we would play it very straight with no gloss and definitely no postmodern irony."

And that is why this Tempest works. It is transparently honest and shiningly sincere. You long for the lovers to be happy, ache for Ariel to be free and when Prospero promises to give up his magic your heart gives a wistful lurch. I have never seen a Tempest that has been quite such fun or moved me quite so much. At the end we sit in pitch black for a few seconds, slightly stunned. Then we awake as if from a dream. Signal to Noise have long departed, but we clap and stamp our feet anyway.

Till September 1. Details: 07939 588011.

webTitle: Renowned trust grateful for outside help on waiting lists

fields.headline: Renowned trust grateful for outside help on waiting lists
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: When you have to juggle 750,000 outpatient appointments a year, it is best not to be proud, and Britain's biggest hospital trust is not angry about being "named and shamed".
fields.body:
When you have to juggle 750,000 outpatient appointments a year, it is best not to be proud, and Britain's biggest hospital trust is not angry about being "named and shamed".

The staff in Leeds know about the government's need to sound proactive and no one expected the Health Department to reveal that it was the trust itself which last week asked for the hit squad, or modernisation agency, to send in a team. The problems in the city's two world-class hospitals, which have seen a 4% rise in outpatients - 1,700 new clients in the first three months of this year - were flagged up even earlier. The Leeds Teaching Hospitals trust, which had 1,000 patients on 10-hour trolley waits in the spring, warned last month that it was struggling to cope.

"We will welcome and work with the patient access team," said David Johnson, the chief executive.

Leeds has a renowned expert in second-time-round hip replacements, for instance; a complicated operation lasting an average seven hours compared with the two it takes to give someone their first artificial hip joint. The waiting list for an operation scarcely available 10 years ago reached a nightmare 50 weeks this summer.

Leeds also hopes that the access team will reinforce efforts to avoid long term outpatient re-bookings, when a consultant offers to see someone for a check-up in six months' time. The practice is bedevilled by rearrangements.

Mr Johnson also blamed the practice, in part, for "unacceptable" cases such as that of Louise Orbell, a 25-year-old Leeds customer services adviser who suffered two miscarriages. She had five appointments cancelled in as many months.

"We are partly the victims of our own success, but we would be the last to say we have got everything right," said Mr Johnson.

webTitle: Arts: Edinburgh: Three plays at the Traverse explore clashing cultures

fields.headline: Clashing cultures
fields.standfirst:
Three plays at the Traverse explore what happens when worlds collide. By Michael Billington

Special report: the Edinburgh Festival 2000
fields.trailText: Three plays at the Traverse explore what happens when worlds collide. By Michael Billington.
fields.body:
Do women write differently from men? Are certain qualities inherent in female drama? All generalities are perilous, but there are common strands to three plays by Abi Morgan, Zinnie Harris and Sue Glover, all at the Traverse: a fascination with the oblique and unresolved, with the confrontation of opposed worlds, with a peripheral view of political realities.

The interest of Abi Morgan's Splendour, presented by Paines Plough, lies in its formal experiment and preoccupation with hidden thoughts. In that sense, it is a close cousin to Caryl Churchill's Blue Heart. Four women are thrown together in a city on the brink of civil war. Micheleine is the elegant wife of the absent head of state. Kathryn is an English news photographer dispatched to snap the defecting dictator. Gilma is the thieving interpreter, and Genevieve is the hostess's equivocal best friend.

The women, from differing classes and cultures, gradually reveal themselves in a time of crisis. But the real subject of this baffling but engrossing play is, I suspect, the unreliability of language. Kathryn, not speaking the local tongue, has to "read" the situation with her photographer's eye. Gilma has the interpreter's power to mis-translate; both older women lie about what is in their hearts.

The play has a weird, cryptic fascination. But the precision of Vicky Featherstone's production and the four performances also keep us riveted. Faith Flint's photographer is all beady-eyed watchfulness; Eileen Walsh's thieving interpreter is conscious of her authority, while Mary Cunningham as the Imelda Marcos-like dictator's wife, and Myra McFadyen as her alleged chum, enact a private power-play.

It's a tough play to grasp at one sitting. But Morgan, with her shrewd understanding of the gulf between what is said and what is thought, is a talent to watch.

With Zinnie Harris's Further Than the Furthest Thing, jointly presented by the Glasgow Tron and the National Theatre, we are on slightly firmer ground; or we would be if the play did not deal with the disruptive effect on individual lives of a volcanic explosion on a remote Atlantic island.

In the first, slow-moving, act Harris traces the pattern of island life on the brink of cataclysm. In the second, far sharper half she shows how the islanders, on being shifted to Southampton, are consistently lied to by the British government. They yearn to return to a home which, because of its strategic importance, they are falsely informed has been destroyed.

Harris certainly takes her time: three hours to be precise. What she captures, however, is the resilience and pathos of remote islanders forever open to exploitation. Irina Brown's atmospheric production, with a thunderous sound design by Duncan Chave, boasts a first-rate performance by one of Britain's most under-sung actresses, Paola Dionisotti. She manages to suggest both the stubborn tenacity and exiled loneliness of someone fiercely attached to a lonely rock at the earth's end. She is well supported by Kevin McMonagle as her guilt-ridden husband and Darrell D'Silva as a Capetown businessman. But Dionisotti is the emotional centre.

Sue Glover's Shetland Saga, produced by the Traverse itself, also deals with cultural collisions - in this case between a Shetland community and a group of stranded Bulgarian sailors whose ship is the focus of capitalist shenanigans back home. Glover shows how the love between a Shetland hotel receptionist and a ship's engineer transcends language, even though it is shadowed by the past and by the Bulgarian secret police.

Glover's play is clearly authentic but, as the title implies, the play is more saga than drama: a discursive, folkloristic narrative rather than something tightly focused. Philip Howard stages it with great sensitivity to place, and Cas Harkins and Lesley Hart are impressive as the Romeo and Juliet of the northern isles. Ultimately, however, I felt I was getting an enlightened civics lesson rather than an expanding dramatic metaphor.

Splendour, Further Than the Furthest Thing and Shetland Saga are at the Traverse Theatre (0131-228 1404) till August 26.

webTitle: Millennium projects fall foul of optimism

fields.headline: Millennium projects fall foul of optimism
fields.standfirst:
Some projects launched with lottery money said to be in crisis because of exaggerated expectations of visitor numbers

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Some projects launched with lottery money said to be in crisis because of exaggerated expectations of visitor numbers
fields.body:
A string of millennium projects opened with national lottery money is in crisis because estimates of visitor numbers were "wildly optimistic", the president of the Museums Association said yesterday.

Patrick Greene urged the millennium commission to consider axeing a planned £15m tower in Portsmouth and using the funds as a safety net for existing attractions.

The experience of the Millennium Dome in Greenwich, the National Centre for Pop Music in Sheffield and the Earth Centre in Doncaster showed the dangers of relying on exaggerated predictions of visitor numbers, he said. Figures for the dome were scaled back from 15m to 12m, then to 6m.

The commission's figures show that the Earth Centre has attracted only 120,000 visitors, as against the 320,000 predicted.

By contrast, the Tate Modern gallery in London has drawn more than 1m people since it opened in May. Its projected figure was 380,000.

Mr Greene said one way to secure the future of attractions such as the Earth Centre was to claw back money from projects still on the drawing board.

He thought the overestimated numbers came about "because of an underestimate of the amount of competition there is out there for people's leisure time".

Admissions were "crucial to your financial viability". Each project had a business plan based on a certain number of visitors. "The millennium commission needs ... a safety net to nurse projects through their difficult first year or first two years."

A commission spokeswoman said it could have opened projects only in London or Edinburgh, where success was a surer bet, but this would have denied the regions the spin-off benefits of investment.

She pointed out that once contracts were signed, the commission could not legally withdraw from projects.

Centres in difficulty needed to reinvent themselves, attracting conferences and educational visits, she said. The Earth Centre, for example, opened with £50m of lottery money, was going to run residential courses for students.

The commission's director, Mike O'Connor, said: "If you are ambitious and take risks you do run into the occasional problem, but if you didn't take some risks you wouldn't get out of bed in the morning."

The Big Idea, a museum dedicated to technological innovation, built on the site of Alfred Nobel's home in Irvine, north Ayrshire, has received more than 10,000 school visits and exceeded its visitor target.

The Lowry arts centre in Salford's dockland, Greater Manchester, has had capacity attendances, attracting more than 270,000 visitors.

 Another millennium project has run into financial difficulties: the two pedestrian bridges alongside the Hungerford bridge over the Thames in London.

Second world war munitions could still rest in the riverbed around the existing bridge, the Cross River Partnership, which has had millennium commission funding towards the £30m project, said yesterday.

It also said safety concerns following the Southall and Paddington rail crashes had led London Underground to call for revised safety requirements for construction of bridge piles.

The partnership would "reassess the project in the light of these changed circumstances", which had pushed up the cost. It is in talks with the government and the mayor of London, Ken Livingstone.

webTitle: At this price?  Baltimore

fields.headline: At this price?  Baltimore
fields.trailText: Trying to value shares in Irish e-security firm Baltimore is a thankless task. Few companies inspire such a diverse range of opinions.
fields.body:
Trying to value shares in Irish e-security firm Baltimore is a thankless task. Few companies inspire such a diverse range of opinions.

The stock is one of the most volatile in the hi-tech sector, but yesterday it held steady at 640.5p.

Some analysts believe Baltimore is on the verge of becoming a global power and a fairer value is around 900p; others rate them an outright sell. Nomura describes Baltimore as "one of the most overpriced software stocks on the market" - even after it fell from March highs of almost £14.

Nomura analysts say last week's deal with Commerce One in the US is indicative of their concerns. Under the deal Baltimore will supply its public key infrastructure to the company but the contract is non-exclusive and Baltimore did not put any monetary value on it.

Nomura argues that Baltimore is valued as if it has proprietary technology and will make high margins. However, the standard it is based on is non-proprietary and Nomura predicts Baltimore will never earn much more than 20%-25% margin.

Current market value of £2bn is 46 times this year's forecast sales and 87 times 2002 forecast earnings. Nomura says this is unrealistic.

What Nomura would like to see is a bigger presence in the US market, arguing that more than half of the world's leading multinationals are based in the US and the big decisions on security will be taken by corporate headquarters. Baltimore's US revenues are growing but mainly through acquisition. Further smart buys would help to calm some analysts' nerves.

The stock is one of the most volatile in the hi-tech sector, but yesterday it held steady at 640.5p. Some analysts believe Baltimore is on the verge of becoming a global power and a fairer value is around 900p; others rate them an outright sell. Nomura describes Baltimore as "one of the most overpriced software stocks on the market" - even after it fell from March highs of almost £14. Nomura analysts say last week's deal with Commerce One in the US is indicative of their concerns. webTitle: Arts: Edinburgh: Elisabeth Mahoney tries to make sense of a Salvador Dali exhibition

fields.headline: Is there a psychiatrist in the house?
fields.standfirst:
Salvador Dali exploited his subconscious like few artists before or since. Freud said he had the eyes of a 'candid fanatic'. As an exhibition of his work opens at the Dean Gallery, Elisabeth Mahoney tries to make sense of it all

Special report: the Edinburgh Festival 2000
fields.trailText: Salvador Dali exploited his subconscious like few artists before or since. Freud said he had the eyes of a 'candid fanatic'. As an exhibition of his work opens at the Dean Gallery, Elisabeth Mahoney tries to make sense of it all.
fields.body:
The woman next to me appears to have dropped off. This is news not only because she is standing in a gallery but because she stands before a great moment of optical insecurity - a disturbing vision that comes as close as possible to representing the unrepresentable. She appears to be snoozing before Salvador Dali's vision of the unconscious, subliminal world.

She's not, in fact - it's just that the handful of really challenging, truly iconoclastic paintings in the exhibition Salvador Dali: Optical Illusions, do take some looking at. They twist, distort, revel in paranoiac double vision, borrow from Old Masters and then do weirdness with them. "I just can't get the nose," an American says, reading that he should be able to see a dog's face in one of the paintings. "Here, see?" a local points. You just know this will go back as a tale of how friendly the Scots are: "That's right - one of them showed me the nose right away."

André Breton said that looking at these great paintings was like doing a crossword. He meant this as an insult, crosswords not being the number one hobby among card-carrying Surrealists, but this is actually one of the pleasures of works like Apparition of Face and Fruit Dish. We don't know where to look; we don't know what we are looking at. Just as the syntax of the title is missing bits, we also lack the syntax to make sense of the painting.

It's a still life and a landscape all at once; there is no fixed horizon; shapes and forms jump out from corners; perspective is elastic. There is a face and a fruit dish, but a dog too, with a tunnel where his eyes should be and a collar that looks like a viaduct. Not only do people spend a long time in front of these paintings; they move, bend, crane their necks, straining lest they miss an extra nose, a donkey, a melting piano.

In Madonna of Port Lligat (1949), Dali incorporates the Renaissance iconography of Piero della Francesca to make a new vision of the Madonna for a post-war, broken world. Dali wanted to present this image to Pope Pius XII - this was at the height of his flirtation with religion- and we can only guess what he would have made of Dali's use of traditional symbolism (fish and bread), floating along with the deities in a bizarre skyline filled with chunks of masonry.

To get us to look carefully at Dali's technique as a painter is no mean feat, given that we know and love/hate him for just about everything else he did. There is also the fact that much of his later output is rotten and doesn't bear close scrutiny (and there are some stinking howlers here too, like his 1982 painting based on Velazquez's Portrait of the Infanta Margarita). But curator Dawn Ades has pulled it off in an intelligent show that brings to life Dali's struggle to stretch representation.

You see it in something like The Invisible Man (1929), his first brush with what he called the "paranoiac critical method", which was based on the idea that in certain psychologically extreme states, such as paranoia, we perceive differently. Dali thought that if we could bring that difference into view, layer the multiple realities - make vision fluid rather than fixed - we might get close to making visible the unconscious. And if in the end we couldn't, it might at least be fun to try.

Even now, The Invisible Man looks like nothing else on earth, with its odd symbolism - sweet pink forms side-by-side with dark swirling masses from which leap faces, bodies and phantoms. You can spend ages before it, trying to fathom where Dali has borrowed from, what his symbolism is all about, what the different elements might add up to - and yet something still eludes us. This and the initial wow factor are what separate Dali at his best from being merely a crossword puzzle.

At his worst, another kind of wow factor kicks in: wow, how could he? The displays of late visual trickery are painful. Stereoscopic pairs of images, such as Athens is Burning (1979), are seen through angled mirrors to intensify perspective. Peeking through, you can't help wondering why he bothered. These half-hearted enterprises are a world away from the attempts to stretch what it was possible to make visible.

It was in the tasteless, tacky 70s, of course, that Dali dabbled in the tasteless, tacky world of holograms, the cheesiest antithesis imaginable to his radical works of the 20s and 30s. Dali could always have fun, even in the early days (see the Venus de Milo with Drawers from 1936, her body featuring drawers opened with rabbit-tail pom-pom handles), but the hologram here, Dali Painting Gala, 1973, is less the work of a madman, more the lame offering of a sad man long past his best. It's as if Dali, Gala and Chairman Mao are spinning round endlessly, like a stuck record. If this was among the most tasteless fare in the whole room that is dedicated to Dali merchandise (yes, they do have melting clocks), it might look OK. Here it looks like the cheap, weak gesture it is.

But that's partly because the best work here can still take our breath away, still keep us rooted to the spot. Even run-of-the-mill Dali can sometimes astound - like The Eye (1945), one of five paintings connected with his work on the dream sequence for Hitchcock's Spellbound. No foundation-shaking optical trickery here. Instead, a glassy, weeping eye, suspended in mid-air over a sky like a bruise. It is reminiscent of the eye-slitting scene in Un Chien Andalou, the 1928 film Dali made with Bunuel. Most of all, it underlines that Dali is all about looking: in the early days, work that had to be looked at, and in the later years, work that begged and bullied to be.

He had, Freud said, the eyes of a "candid fanatic". He may have grown less candid but his love of being the subject and object of the voyeuristic gaze never left him. Go, see.

Salvador Dali: Optical Illusions is at the Dean Gallery (0131-624 6200) till October 1.

webTitle: NHS helpline offers bad advice, survey claims

fields.headline: NHS helpline offers bad advice, survey claims
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: NHS Direct, the telephone helpline hailed by the government as the way forward for the health service, could be risking lives because of shortcomings in the way calls are handled, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
NHS Direct, the telephone helpline hailed by the government as the way forward for the health service, could be risking lives because of shortcomings in the way calls are handled, it was claimed yesterday.

Research by Health Which? found that potential emergencies were missed while other patients were unnecessarily referred to overstretched accident and emergency departments. Nurses staffing the line offered inconsistent advice.

NHS Direct, launched in 1998 and enthusiastically endorsed by Tony Blair, covers two-thirds of the country and is due to go nationwide by the end of October.

Its principal aim is to reduce demand on other NHS services - but recent research by Sheffield University found there was no evidence to suggest that this had happened.

Researchers from Health Which? tested several scenarios based on everyday medical problems and made 30 calls to NHS Direct call centres.

Calls by a man pretending to have angina were poorly handled. A panel of experts said nurses should have asked enough questions to establish that he had already had one heart attack and his angina attacks were becoming more frequent. But in only one out of 10 calls were enough questions asked to discover that his condition was worsening.

In another case, a woman claiming to be the mother of a five-year-old child with vomiting and diarrhoea was given "inappropriate" advice to take her daughter to A&E.

Sally Williams, principal researcher for Health Which? said: "Our research raises a number of questions about the role of NHS Direct call handlers, the remit of nurses and about the protocols they use. One of the key challenges is getting the balance right between drawing on the skills of nurses and ensuring that advice is consistent and sound. The nurses' listening skills weren't always up to scratch."

She said her biggest concern was that there were gaps in the system. NHS Direct should take a close look at the way it deals with calls about repeat prescriptions to ensure that potential emergencies do not slip through the net.

At its annual meeting in June, the British Medical Association called on the government to halt the expansion of NHS Direct. The BMA has already demanded more evaluation of the service.

Dr John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA's general practitioners' committee, said yesterday: "Clearly in some circumstances it can do a good job - but the research from the Consumers' Association reveals potentially dangerous discrepancies in the quality of information given."

But a Department of Health spokesperson said: "NHS Direct has safely delivered health care advice to more than 3m callers, and on many occasions has acted as a lifesaver. As a result of the report we are reviewing the protocols call handlers and nurses work to if a caller rings about repeat prescriptions."

According to DoH statistics, 97% of callers were satisfied with the service.

Useful links:

www.nhsdirect.nhs.uk/main.jhtml NHS Direct online

www.nhs50.nhs.uk/healthy-direct.htm NHS questions and answers on the scheme

www.nhs.uk/nhsplan NHS national plan

webTitle: Vigilante mob forces family into hiding

fields.headline: Vigilante mob forces family into hiding
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: A family were in hiding last night after being driven from their home by a screaming 150-strong mob of vigilantes who smashed their windows with bricks - the latest in a campaign to remove suspected sex offenders from a Portsmouth housing estate.
fields.body:
A family were in hiding last night after being driven from their home by a screaming 150-strong mob of vigilantes who smashed their windows with bricks - the latest in a campaign to remove suspected sex offenders from a Portsmouth housing estate.

The family, who have two young children, fled for their own safety and their council house on Portsmouth's Paulsgrove estate was boarded up following the violence.

Neighbours said the family's car was overturned and their terrified screams could be heard in the street. They had moved their two young children out a few days earlier, fearing they would be targeted.

Hampshire police have declined to say why the family would have been targeted and would give no information about any criminal convictions.

Twelve people, mostly youths, were arrested following the angry scenes on Sunday night. Police with riot shields used CS spray to restore order. The clash was the first outbreak of violence on the estate since Thursday when a police officer suffered a broken nose and two cars were set alight.

Until Sunday, the campaigners had remained peaceful, encouraging passing motorists to beep their horns in support of their plan to drive suspected paedophiles from their homes.

The trouble started when the family were targeted after locals drew up a hit list of 20 suspected paedophiles.

The deputy chief constable of Hampshire police, Ian Readhead, appealed for calm, claiming innocent families were being targeted.

This was confirmed by residents yesterday who say another family have been forced to flee after vigilantes mistakenly confused their name with that of a suspected paedophile.

"Innocent and frightened people are being caught up in these acts of violence. They must stop now," Mr Readhead said. "The organisers must realise that these peaceful protests are being highjacked by a violent minority who are intent on causing criminal acts and behaving in a way which cannot be justified.

"This violence takes us further away from the sensible and intellectual debate we should be having. You can't have a sensible debate by using a brick."

Mr Readhead expressed concern over children being involved in the protests. "Children as young as 14 were arrested on Sunday night," he said.

But the women behind the demonstrations remained defiant yesterday. Sharon Mills, 50, who has 14 grandchildren, said: "We are not worried about the consequences of earlier demonstrations. After the riot police hit those kids, we are determined more than ever to keep going."

Katrina Kessell, 33, who also lives on the estate, said every effort had been taken to confirm suspected paedophiles' addresses.

But yesterday many residents of Paulsgrove remained fiercely opposed to the campaign, saying it had brought an atmosphere of fear to the estate. A mother of five said: "I am so frightened I have sent my children away to stay with relatives until it all calms down. It is just too violent. Last night was like something in Sarajevo. The tragedy is that this estate was a lovely place to live until the News of the World started its name and shame campaign."

Another neighbour added: "No one likes the idea of a paedophile living on the estate among our children but this is simply going to drive them into hiding. They have to live somewhere and it is far better to have them at a known address where they can be monitored by the authorities."

One resident said a friend of hers, a mother of two, was forced from her home on Friday after her husband was targeted for sharing the same surname as a suspected paedophile. She said the family spent last night in a bed and breakfast. They have been told it will take five weeks to re-house them.

"People threw rocks through their windows and screamed 'Paedophiles out' but this family have nothing to do with paedophiles. It was a case of mistaken identity," she said.

Parents in Paulsgrove have sent out hundreds of leaflets for a daytime protest on Wednesday. They hope this will be less inviting to potential trouble-makers.

The Portsmouth North Labour MP, Syd Rapson, who lives near where the latest violence took place, claimed the estate was degenerating into "mob rule". He said: "Sooner or later someone is going to get killed.

"We will be holding a meeting with other councillors in the area and our message to them is that we want these paedophiles out of the estate."

webTitle: Hands-free mobile phones 'safer'

fields.headline: Hands-free mobile phones 'safer'
fields.standfirst: Special report: mobile phone fears
fields.trailText: Health fears over hands-free mobile phone kits were today quashed by a government report which confirmed their use could substantially reduce levels of radiation going into the brain.
fields.body:
Health fears over hands-free mobile phone kits were today quashed by a government report which confirmed their use could substantially reduce levels of radiation going into the brain.

The report from the Department of Trade and Industry concludes that phone users can actually cut their exposure to radiation by using hands-free attachments instead of holding the phone to their ear.

This contradicts an earlier report by the Consumers Association which claimed the headsets trebled the amount of radiation beamed into the brains of users because the wires leading from the phone into the ear acted like an aerial, conveying a more concentrated dose of radio waves than usual.

Patricia Hewitt, the minister of e-commerce, said: "Today's report confirms that hands-free kits reduce exposure for mobile phone users. It is important that the public is provided with clear and unambiguous advice about the use of hands-free kits."

The report concluded that the devices, which have become increasingly popular after reports linking mobile phone use to possible illness and even brain tumours, "offer very substantial reductions in SAR (specific absorption ratio) compared to the normal use of a mobile phone held against the ear."

The study, conducted by an independent consultancy, SARtest ltd, found all measurements were comfortably within the guidelines of the national radiological protection board, the DTI confirmed.

The report said: "The results show that, for phones with external antennas (as tested for Which? with the cable hanging vertically downwards) PHF kits do not increase SAR but reduce SAR levels compared with the normal use of the phone."

It was found that absorption by the user of a handset in conjunction with a hands-free set could be reduced by turning the phone so the keypad faced the body.

The report recommended some precautions to users of hands-free kits: "If seeking to reduce their exposure as a precautionary measure, we recommend that users of personal hands free kits should let the earpiece cable hang down naturally from the ear, keep the cable away from the phone's antenna, and do not place the phone directly against the body."

In May, the independent group on mobile phones and health, under the chairmanship of Sir William Stewart, also noted that other studies have been carried out which claim a substantial reduction in exposure when using hands-free kit.

A report by the Australian Consumers' Association last week found hands-free kits could reduce the effects of electromagnetic radiation by 92%.

The UK Consumers Association said it had commissioned further research "to clear up the confusion".

The report recommended some precautions to users of hands-free kits: "If seeking to reduce their exposure as a precautionary measure, we recommend that users of personal hands free kits should let the earpiece cable hang down naturally from the ear, keep the cable away from the phone's antenna, and do not place the phone directly against the body." In May, the independent group on mobile phones and health, under the chairmanship of Sir William Stewart, also noted that other studies have been carried out which claim a substantial reduction in exposure when using hands-free kit. A report by the Australian Consumers' Association last week found hands-free kits could reduce the effects of electromagnetic radiation by 92%. The UK Consumers Association said it had commissioned further research "to clear up the confusion".

webTitle: Hit squads sent in to hospitals

fields.headline: Hit squads sent in to hospitals
fields.standfirst:
Action to halt increase in waiting lists for outpatients
Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Hit squads were yesterday ordered in to seven English hospital trusts "named and shamed" after a sharp rise in outpatient waiting lists left the government embarrassed.
fields.body:
Hit squads were yesterday ordered in to seven English hospital trusts "named and shamed" after a sharp rise in outpatient waiting lists left the government embarrassed.

The action teams will pay their first visits this week to draw up "recovery plans" to reduce queues for treatment, which have lengthened despite Tony Blair's pledge to improve the NHS.

New figures showed the number of patients waiting more than 13 weeks to be assessed rose nearly 43,000 during the three months to June to 444,000.

The increase overshadowed a 5,000 fall in outpatients forced to wait a year or longer for treatment, the figure targeted in Labour's election manifesto.

The figures appeared to vindicate claims by doctors' leaders and opposition politicians that ministers had extended queues to meet overstretched consultants to cut in-patient waiting lists.

Staff from the government's national patient access team are to visit all seven hospital trusts within the next few days to start compiling proposals to deliver the "dramatic improvements" over the next six months promised by the government.

Lord Hunt, a health minister who used to speak on behalf of health authorities, said: "The public's top concern about the NHS is waiting for treatment. The outpatients rise has to be tackled with immediate action. This increase is far too high."

The seven trusts on the hit list are Aintree Hospitals, Dudley Group of Hospitals, Hull and East Yorkshire Hospitals, Leeds Teaching Hospitals, Plymouth Hospitals, Southend Hospital, and Worcester NHS Trust.

Plymouth Hospitals Trust, based at the city's Derriford hospital, was recently found to have fiddled outpatient lists, forcing the resignations of its deputy and chief executives.

The 10% rise to 444,000 in the number enduring waits of beyond three months to see an NHS specialist left ministers attempting to convince the public that they could cure the health service.

Lord Hunt said a quarter of the increase was in the seven named trusts out of 400 operating in England and Wales.

Mr Blair earlier this month announced a radical restructuring of the health service, including treatment within three months by 2005 backed up by a private hospital guarantee, after the chancellor, Gordon Brown, vowed spending would go up £12bn over three years.

Lord Hunt said £40m an nounced earlier would be used to cut waiting lists, broken down to £13m for trusts with spare capacity to treat patients from other areas and £27m for departments with long waiting lists.

The extra expenditure on outpatients will be controlled by Whitehall to stop trusts wasting the money.

Other figures revealed by ministers showed 1,047,900 waiting for treatment in hospitals in England, a fall of 5,000. The total has fallen by more than the 100,000 drop Mr Blair committed himself to after inheriting 1,158,000 from the Tories.

Philip Hammond, a Tory health spokesman, said: "Morale is at an all time low and naming and shaming and sending in hit squads is the opposite of good management."

A spokesman for the Patients Association said: "It is the waiting times that we and patients are really concerned about. It is unacceptable that people are waiting so long to see a consultant after being referred by their GP."

Plymouth is recruiting 36 nurses from the Philippines to help clear the backlog, and John Yarnold, acting director of operations, said: "We have a recovery plan in place to be back on course with waiting list targets by the end of September."

He added: "The number of people waiting more than 13 weeks for an outpatients appointment has already started to fall."

webTitle: Virgin takes tilt at rail franchise

fields.headline: Virgin takes tilt at rail franchise
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Virgin said yesterday it would offer tilting diesel trains, shorter journeys and through routes to London if it won the new franchise for the Trans-Pennine Express linking the north-east and north-west of England.
fields.body:
Virgin said yesterday it would offer tilting diesel trains, shorter journeys and through routes to London if it won the new franchise for the Trans-Pennine Express linking the north-east and north-west of England.

Sir Richard Branson's group, which already operates the west coast mainline and CrossCountry franchises, is one of seven groups bidding for the 15- to 20-year franchise, the first of its kind being offered by the shadow strategic rail authority.

It is pitted against the Via GTI consortium of FirstGroup and French national rail operator SNCF; Serco, the engineering group that runs the Atomic Weapons Establishment at Aldermaston; Group 4, the security firm running private prisons; transport group Arriva; Connex, part of the French utility CGE; and National Express.

Trans-Pennine is the first new franchise on offer from the SSRA.

Arriva, operators of the Northern Spirit franchise, said it would invest £1.8bn over 20 years. Virgin refused to divulge any figures but said it would provide tilting and non-tilting trains.
