webTitle: Roy Hattersley: Bush is offering Americans the politics of nothingness

fields.headline: Like father, like son
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Bush is offering Americans the politics of nothingness.
fields.body:
During his first term as vice president of the United States, George Bush flew into London to speak at an American embassy lunch. It was a memorable occasion. During the meal itself, the noise of workmen assembling a portable podium prevented casual conversation. When the construction was complete, the vice president entertained his audience with a brief selection of his favourite platitudes. Robert Runcie, the Archbishop of Canterbury, wondered, sotto voce, if such large preparation had ever before produced so small a result.

When the ambassador announced that the vice president was willing to answer three questions, Denis Healey cried: "Good, I have three questions to ask." The first concerned the moral propriety of a superpower imposing its form of government on small nations. The concept was too complicated for Bush to comprehend. So Healey made the same point in less cerebral language. "When a man has electrodes fastened to his genitals, he is not consoled by the thought of an election in 10 year's time."

Some of the lunch guests disapproved of Healey's descent into the harsh realities of counter-insurgency. But everyone agreed that George Bush's address had been an embarrassment. Last Friday evening, watching the Republican convention on television, it was clear to me that the genes - augmented by what George W Bush had learnt at his father's knee - were working well. There was only one fundamental difference between George Bush's embassy address and the speech with which his son accepted the Republican nomination. Dad was better.

While George Bush was adjudged a catastrophe, George W was congratulated on a triumph - even by newspapers that should be more discriminating. It goes to show that, in the 20 years which separate the two events, life has changed. These days, politicians are expected to rely on vacuous generalities, and they win applause for anodyne assurances that are calculated not to cause offence. They are no longer judged on the courage of their convictions or the relevance of their policies.

Likely winners are good. Potential losers are bad. The encomiums that George W received were not for delivery or content. He did well because he said nothing to prejudice his opinion poll lead.

That is the only explanation for the praise which has been lavished on a speech that promised "a new beginning", the certain winner of the Cliche of the Century Competition. And it got worse. George W believes that "prosperity can be a tool in our hands used to build and better our country" - a stern reproof to anyone who believes that prosperity is a disaster that good presidents avoid. He went on to promise tax cuts "for everyone in every bracket", an undertaking so recklessly unattainable (without a massive penalty imposed on those who rely on state spending) that even the Conservative party has abandoned it. Not even William Hague at his worst would have intoned "The night is passing, we are awaiting for the day to dawn."

George W Bush is offering Americans the politics of nothingness. That must be a fraudulent prospectus. For Americans have the politics of nothingness already. And it looks as if Al Gore will follow in President Clinton's tradition. I give George W credit for planning to face the great issues. But he will deal with the needs of the poor and the demands of the minorities in a way that depresses rather than improves their condition. He cannot admit that now, because to do so would sacrifice the support of enlightened America as well as the votes of the minorities themselves. All credit to the country for that. But only odium for the candidate who, fearing the decent impulse, hides behind banalities.

No sensible person could have listened to the speech that George W Bush made in Philadelphia last week without realising what a tawdry manifesto he offers. It was delivered in the monotone of a man who had arrived too late to read the text in private before the public performance. Yet the style was superior to the substance. For it represented what the ad-men regard as the apotheosis (and decent people dismiss as the nadir) of new politics. It was the clear product of focus groups and opinion polls. But it made a nod to virtue by denouncing reliance on focus groups and opinion polls.

Perhaps the demand for "a bipartisan approach to governing" makes more sense in American politics than it does in Britain. But the commitment to "extend the promise of prosperity to every forgotten corner of the country" is clearly inconsistent with the aspirations of a presidential candidate who is a hostage to big business. It all adds up to stock market politics - the endorsement of a second-rate product as long as it is likely to provide the speculators with short-term dividends.

webTitle: Passport control: Who's in town and why

fields.headline: Passport control
fields.standfirst: Who's in town and why
fields.trailText: Who's in town and why
fields.body:
Rhymes with "get a new tailor"... yes, it's a gruff, manly hello to the man who levitated the Pentagon and sparred with champions, founded the Village Voice and wrote some of the greatest non-fiction of the last century, and some of its ropiest novels. (In the spirit of charity, let's leave the films out of this.) He's ageless, he's in the mood for trouble and he'll probably still punch the man who says he's not. After 52 years of unmatched notoriety, Norman Mailer stomps into Edinburgh on Monday for the International Book Festival. Still unmissable.

Boss hog... and talking of stomping, there can be no greater expert on the subject than Sonny Barger. As anyone who has read Hunter S Thompson's Hell's Angels knows, they weren't pretending to be dangerous: they were dangerous. Barger, big boss of the Oakland Angels chapter, flies in on Thursday to plug his own account, rather imaginatively entitled Hell's Angel. He's no spring chicken, of course, but there's still an aura of menace around the old chap, which only slightly dissipates when you discover that his given name was Ralph (doesn't rhyme with "safe", we're guessing). So a gentle sigh of relief, then, when Sonny/Ralph leaves on Sunday...

Say my name, say my name... You know how Zowie Bowie took the earliest opportunity to change his name back to something vaguely normal? No such born-again bourgeois behaviour from Moon Unit Zappa, Frank's little girl. That's either evidence of rare courage, or more likely a California childhood. Now, although the Passport Control team contends that Frank's whole career was one long crime against pop music, we don't subscribe to that sins of the father jive, so when Moon beams down (Wednesday to Saturday) to hawk her new novel America The Beautiful, we're keeping an open mind. Honest.

webTitle: TV guide: Buddy Holly's Rock Shrine, 8pm.

fields.headline: Location, location, location
fields.standfirst: All aspiring rock legends know how vital it is to go for an early - and preferably violent - death. But the real trick is to choose the appropriate place for your spectacular demise. Not everyone gets it right, as  Bob Stanley  explains
fields.trailText: All aspiring rock legends know how vital it is to go for an early - and preferably violent - death. But the real trick is to choose the appropriate place for your spectacular demise. Not everyone gets it right, as Bob Stanley explains.
fields.body:
Rock'n'roll deaths are notoriously romanticised, and the more untimely the death the bigger the legend. Trouble is, the locations of these deaths are frequently unromantic in the extreme. Hence every year a gang of rock enthusiasts gather in a godforsaken field near Clear Lake, Iowa, to commemorate "the day the music died", when a plane carrying Buddy Holly, Richie Valens and The Big Bopper landed in a crumpled heap a few hours after they'd played at the town's Surf Ballroom. Shrines come no more desolate.

If Buddy could have swapped his decidedly non-exotic crash site then he probably wouldn't have changed it for Chippenham in Wiltshire, the final resting place of Eddie Cochran. The man who, more than anyone, including Elvis, seemed the archetypal rocker, died in a car crash during a British tour in 1960. Every year the fans turn up on April 17th, and a service is held, oddly, in the St Mary's school playground. Someone in the town brings along the bloodstained blanket that Eddie's head rested on. Someone else sells T-shirts bearing the legend "Eddie Cochran Chippenham" - and who can blame them? After all, what more does anyone know about Chippenham? Britain's greatest rocker, Billy Fury, grew up in Liverpool's Dingle but was buried in Mill Hill cemetery, north London. This was one of the graveyards sold by Westminster council's lovely Lady Porter in the late 80s for one penny to a construction company. Fury fans did their best to keep his grave tidy while much of its surroundings became a mass of weeds. The ombudsman eventually forced the council to buy the cemeteries back - at the going commercial rate - and Bill's tomb is once more tended with due respect.

Joe Meek, the production genius who created space-age pop (Telstar, Johnny Remember Me, Tribute To Buddy Holly) in his Holloway Road studio in the early to mid 60s, shot his landlady and then himself on February 3rd, 1967, exactly eight years after Holly's death. The Joe Meek Appreciation Society meet annually at a nearby pub where a sadly dwindling number of Meek acolytes can usually be called on to sing chunks of the great man's work.

Said pub for years was The Holloway - now the horribly named Spoofer's Bar - until the pub closed after the landlord was shot dead.

When Serge Gainsbourg died, the French showed him the kind of respect usually afforded to a head of state. The bon viveur, who revelled in a lack of decorum and once famously told Whitney Houston "I want to fuck you" live on TV, would appreciate his graffiti-covered former residence on rue de Verneuil. One fan has written "Fuck me Serge"... possibly not Whitney.

Nearer to home, Freddie Mercury's house in Notting Hill and Abbey Road studios are similarly barely visible behind ink and spraypaint. A more subtle tribute, to 60s organ king Graham Bond, was paid by mod club The Mousetrap which set up shop adjacent to Finsbury Park station. Bond's obsession with the black arts convinced him that he was being chased down a platform by demons and he promptly threw himself under a Piccadilly line train. A ten minute bus ride will take you to Parkway in Camden Town where AC/DC's Bon Scott met his maker in 1980. After a night's heavy drinking at the Music Machine - now Camden Palace - Bon went to sleep off his hangover in the back of a car, but never woke up. It was an unfortunate choice of parking space, as Parkway became the centre of all things Britpop and neo-mod in the 90s. If he'd died outside the Wulfren Hall, Wolverhampton or in some other more metal-minded city, there would surely be a statue of Bon rather than a bunch of fidgety short men in ill-fitting suits outside the Spread Eagle.

Art Fein's book The LA Musical History Tour is a must for rock shrine fanatics; the dedicated can find the Webb Motel, where soul's founding father Sam Cooke was shot dead in 1964, or the homes of Tim Hardin, Janis Joplin, or The Germs' singer Darby Crash, whose double suicide with his girlfriend went slightly awry when she survived. The house where Marvin Gaye was shot dead by his father now bears a sign saying "do not disturb occupants". Also listed is the vacant lot where Bobby "I Fought The Law" Fuller was found slumped across the front seat of his car by his mother. Fuller had made the unfortunate mistake of dancing at a Hollywood club with a local mobster's girl. He was taken outside, beaten up and filled with gasoline; the coroner's verdict was suicide.

The only way to guarantee a shrine in a plum location is to have it built while you're still alive, and Japanese mods have done Paul Weller proud with a shrine they've created in The Weller's Club in beautiful Kyoto. A photo of Paul smiles down beatifically while candles burn all around. This could be tempting fate: who's to say the self-styled Modfather won't come to a sticky end in a snowy field near Mansfield, Middlesbrough or Merthyr Tydfil?

Buddy Holly's Rock Shrine, tonight, 8pm, BBC Choice.

webTitle: Women: Side lines

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.body:
With three big weddings last week, it appears that tradition and romance are alive and well. Or are they just opportunities for career-enhancing publicity? Brad and Jennifer were coy in their authorised press photo, Gordon and Sarah enjoyed a front-page frenzy when news of their nuptials leaked out, and lesbians Sophie and Rena committed in style - but without legal recognition - with a ceremony at the Groucho Club and a 16-page splash in OK! magazine. Sophie Ward and her bride helped fill column inches in a dry week for news, but it is their love and respect for each other that should be noted, not how many breasts the happy couple have between them.

The sex discrimination case brought by City analyst Julie Bower against her former employer shows that pay inequality continues to thrive: Bower claims she got a bonus of £25,000 while a man doing the same job was given £650,000. Cases such as this are hyped because of the huge sums involved. But wherever you work and whatever your age, men and women should be paid the same for doing the same job. Full stop.

It was reported yesterday that women who become obsessed with dieting are in danger of wrecking their marriages by becoming unhappy when they fail to shift the weight. But the more worrying revelation was that nine out of 10 women will go on a diet at some stage in their lives. A government summit and articles about the reality of anorexia don't seem to be getting to the root of the problem: the dissatisfaction that women feel with their bodies (often exacerbated by a partner's criticisms) and how they will deny themselves food and take diet pills to make themselves look better.

webTitle: Women: Worse than being cheated on are feelings of sexual rejection

fields.headline: Low fidelity
fields.standfirst: There are worse things about being betrayed than the feelings of sexual rejection, says  Anita Chaudhuri, who knows something about being cheated on
fields.trailText: There are worse things about being betrayed than the feelings of sexual rejection, says  Anita Chaudhuri, who knows something about being cheated on.
fields.body:
Feeling betrayed is like feeling happy: most of us think we know exactly what would make us feel that way. But in reality, the most unexpected events can end up provoking those emotions. And just as winning the lottery might make you happy, but not in the way you imagined, the discovery that the love of your life has been unfaithful doesn't always hurt in the ways you think it will.

This point is borne out in Passion Play, a West End production that concerns itself with a middle-aged married man who cheats on his wife when a predatory young woman seduces him. The wife is stoical throughout her ordeal. Not only does she forgive her errant spouse, she remains friends with the other woman. After all, despite having the body of Gisele, how could this twentysomething poppet resist falling for him? And as if being her best friend wasn't enough, they go shopping for sexy lingerie together and discuss her husband's tastes.

It is a highly unlikely scenario in a play that was written by Peter Nichols nearly 20 years ago. Critics (male) have raved about its emotional honesty, though in truth it seems reactionary and out of date in its assumptions. Nevertheless, there is a single moment, when both women are trying on wispy pieces of silk, in which the wife suddenly realises that her "friend" is continuing the affair. She has survived feelings of sexual rejection and despair caused by her husband's behaviour, yet the pain caused by the younger woman's betrayal of their friendship is the most raw and truthful moment in the entire play.

Perhaps the reason why this small scene still has emotional resonance is that the actual mechanics of infidelity no longer have the same power to trigger an emotional response from us. We are becoming desensitised to extracurricular lust, both as a dramatic story line and as a fact of life. These days, adultery has spawned a growth industry. The back pages of magazines used to concern themselves only with lonely hearts; now we have agencies for cheating hearts, or "bored marrieds" as they refer to their clients. On the internet you can log on to alibi.co.uk, a service that facilitates infidelity by providing fake phone calls, receipts and other paraphernalia for the feckless - and for those without an appropriate adulterous rendezvous, they provide a handy link to Loving Links, the biggest agency for the already attached. For the suspicious, there is Check-a-Mate, an American detective agency soon to set up shop in Britain. For a fee it will send out an alluring decoy to see if your mate is tempted, and then tape the evidence.

In this climate, discovering that your partner has been unfaithful, however devastating that may be, feels oddly familiar. We know how we are supposed to react because we have seen it on Coronation Street and read about it in Now! magazine, so it feels all the more puzzling when our responses to infidelity are more complex than the kneejerk pain of sexual rejection.

The truth is that there are many different levels of betrayal. Catherine Texier, a writer who lives in Manhattan, wrote movingly about the end of her 18-year marriage to fellow author Joel Rose in Breakup, published last year. The text is one long angry howl of rejection, unsparing in its detail. And yet, throughout the relentless descriptions of the pain of being supplanted by another woman, it is her melancholic sense of domestic betrayal, of being left to cook supper for their two daughters without him, that emerges most strongly.

"I pulled four hamburgers out of the freezer and laid them on the counter next to three ears of corn . . . and when you came down from your office upstairs - it was around 6.30pm - and saw the four hamburgers, you said, coldly, 'I'm not having dinner here tonight.' I feel a little twinge but not more than that because that's our new unspoken deal. So I say, OK, and put one hamburger back in the freezer. And right after that I feel fine."

Only I bet she doesn't. I think this kind of mundane detail has the power to wound our hearts most deeply. And I remember only too well being on the receiving end of it. I had arrived home a day early from a trip and, on walking into the kitchen, came face to face with unexpected evidence of romantic betrayal: cake. Two plates, the remnants of two slices, chocolate and raspberry fondant, from a favourite patisserie. Other couples have Our Tune, we had Our Cake, only now it had been served up to woo someone else. Sternly, I told myself that I was over-reacting - anyone can eat cake. But as it happened, my suspicions were correct. Even now, I marvel at the sense of betrayal this elicited: emotional death by chocolate cake.

Passion Play suggests that there is a link between age and attitudes towards fidelity. Again real life is more complex. One might imagine attitudes about fidelity to be more relaxed among the young, yet a recent Mori survey about moral beliefs indicated that those aged between 15 and 24 were the most unforgiving group when it came to infidelity, perhaps because theirs is the generation that has the highest number of divorced parents.

Meanwhile, another survey, for those who set much store by statistics, suggests that women in their 40s are the least faithful. Woman's Journal polled its readers and discovered that two out of three had been unfaithful to their partners. The postwar generation can have unexpected attitudes too. For these women, particularly those brought up to define themselves through marriage rather than professional life, the issues are equally complex.

"I felt betrayed financially," says Anna Rodgers, 60. Her husband had an affair last year. "OK, so he fell for a younger model and wanted to have a fling. Well, that's life. I could have lived with that. What I couldn't forgive was the fact that he had cashed in an insurance policy and used the money to wine and dine her, while I sat at home worrying about how we were going to manage for money after he retired in a few months. He'd lied about other money, our money, that he'd spent on her too. I felt that if he was capable of stealing from me, my future with him was untenable."

Rodgers was surprised, though, by the reaction of female friends of the same age group. "Many of them told me they thought I was mad to throw him out, that I should think about my future. I think there is still this stigma among my generation about divorce. One friend asked me whether I felt I had failed. Failed! Marriage isn't an exam. My one big regret is about money - I wish I'd been more shrewd. I tell my daughter, who is 34, that she should make sure she always has her own money, no matter who she marries."

When Carol Morgan, a 26-year-old teacher, discovered that her husband of seven years had been seeing a colleague, she experienced an overwhelming sense of having been belittled professionally because of her husband's rejection.

"Of course it's painful to discover that your husband has been having sex with someone else, whoever she may be," Morgan says. "But it wasn't the sex part of the equation that led me to end the marriage. We worked for schools in the same neighbourhood and so our professional worlds were connected. When people at his school began to get wind of the affair, people who I regarded as our mutual friends, he confessed to them about what was going on and begged them not to tell me. Not only that, he told them all sorts of stuff about the problems we'd been having within our marriage - really personal stuff including how I had been on anti-depressants, which I didn't want anyone at work to know. Finally, after several months, someone had the decency to tell me what was going on. I felt incandescent with rage. The affair was bad enough. That he had betrayed my trust to people who had professional power over me was beyond the pale. I felt professionally devalued because of what happened. It was inconceivable that I would continue at the same school so I left not only my marriage but my job too."

Breakup by Catherine Texier is published by Review, priced £6.99. Passion Play runs until August 26 at the Comedy Theatre. Tel: 020-7369 1731.

webTitle: Cristina Odone on Cherie the women's champ

fields.headline: Cherie the women's champ
fields.standfirst: Two comma crunch
fields.trailText: At the Labour party conference in Brighton, Cherie will join hubby in the political spotlight to sell new Labour to women.
fields.body:
At my local supermarket, they try to lure customers to buy items approaching their sell-by date with red stickers that scream "two for the price of one!". This way, the crafty retailers figure, you might just be tempted to buy a couple of mouldy plums or blackened avocados - instead of one good one.

New Labour, with an eye on its own sell-by date, has decided to adopt the two-for-one sales pitch and, as of next month, we'll be getting two Blairs for the price of one. At the Labour party conference in Brighton, Cherie will join hubby in the political spotlight to sell new Labour to women. There's a precedent, of course, for the first lady to step into the political fray: during her husband's first term in office, Hillary Rodham Clinton decided to tackle America's health care. It was a flop - but this shouldn't deter the double act on this side of the pond.

Tony's done his little number, introducing the lacklustre women's unit, the new childcare credit, the parental leave directive and, of course, that lifeless chorus line, Blair's Babes. But Tony's act only earned some half-hearted applause and a lot of jeering from disillusioned women up and down the country who voted new Labour to change their lot - only to find that life under Tony is no better than it was under John, Maggie et al.

So heeeeere's Cherie! Drums roll, the spotlight beams, a hush falls over the audience. But is this middle-aged QC capable of the high kicks and high-octane performance needed to jazz things up on the women's front? Cherie is lucky in that new Labour's present prima donna on female issues, Baroness Jay at the Women's Unit, is not a hard act to follow. Three years on, Margaret's unit has failed to come up with a strategy for daycare facilities, equal pay, equal opportunities, or domestic violence.

What it did unveil, in a blaze of publicity, was an anorexia summit, which saw the editors of Vogue and other women's mags munching soggy sandwiches while tut-tutting over photos of skeletal fashion victims; and the "listening to women" roadshow, which had the baroness being chauffeured around the land to meet with "real" women (God knows what they made of Lady Jay up in Jarrow).

Mercifully, Cherie's debut in Brighton may mean Margaret's swan-song is not far off. Although the prime minister's wife is only chairing a debate on "A Marriage of Convenience: Has new Labour Delivered for Women?", she is doing so for a fringe event sponsored by the Institute for Public Policy Research, the left-wing think-tank with close links to the government. It's hard not to think that Cherie's presence as chairperson signals tacit acknowledgement by Tony that Jay's record needs defending - and that he needs a new ambassador for women.

Who better than his QC spouse to argue his case? Cherie, professional high-flier, wife and mother all rolled into one, shows ordinary women that, yes, it's possible under new Labour to have it all. Despite her terrifying abilities and intimidating success, Cherie is resolutely one of us - modest background, broken home, a difficult teenage son and even a rumpled nightgown. She may enjoy occasional use of a royal jet, but she remains accessible - the kind of woman you could moan to about the boss, nappies, or the price of plums.

Jay made a point of announcing she was not a feminist; but Cherie is a sister who's gone on record against the prime minister on the EU directive on parental leave. The fact that she's not a professional politico just adds to her appeal: there would be no spin, no hype, no condescension.

In his wife, then, Blair has the perfect means to court those precious women's votes. Indeed, Cherie's political future seems so bright, I wonder whether, once in Brighton, she will stop at protecting Tony's party from the attacks of disgruntled feminists. She might just seize the platform to unfurl political ambitions of her own. Hillary, after all, managed to pick herself up after the health care débcle and is now running for mayor of New York. Does Cherie have a similar game plan - baby Leo notwithstanding? She stands a better chance than Hillary, whose steely self-control, before the cameras and in her marriage, are a turn-off to women voters who smell a fake. Cherie is reassuringly real - exhausted by childbirth, windswept on holiday, and ever so slightly naff whenever she turns that adoring gaze on her husband.

Yes, two Blairs are better than one. At Brighton, Cherie could well turn in the kind of crowd-pleasing performance needed to restore women's confidence in new Labour. And then, who can stop her?

* The number of individuals going bankrupt has hit a five-year high. Before you get out your handkerchiefs, let me add that it's the dot.com entrepreneurs who are swelling the bankruptcy courts. There, did you feel a touch of schadenfreude reading that? Let's face it, those teenyboppers who clicked their mice and raised their millions in less time than it took most of us to fill in a job application are difficult to mourn. For months, their smiley, Clearasil faces were everywhere, cheering us on to invest in their vision and be part of the "two comma" (£1,000,000) crowd. We had Martha Lane Fox flicking her hair and spouting web talk on the box; we had Susannah and Trinny in the nude, best assets hidden by melons, touting for clients in posters in the Underground; and endless young nerds in chinos from the Gap, convincing City fat cats to part with their money.

It wasn't just their youth that made us itch to wipe the smile off those dot.com faces, though. They simply weren't the kind of millionaire you could grow fond of. None of these kids seemed to boast the satisfying narrative that has inspired generations of would-be Bransons. In vain, you scanned their (very brief) bios in search of the weepy rags-to-riches story that had you rooting for the millionaire even while you envied him his Midas touch. No sign anywhere in their well-fed suburban lives of the hard slog of the self-made entre preneur - years of eating beans on toast and dodging the landlord until - eureka! - that brilliant flash of inspiration. These squillion-earners, just sat in front of a screen, came up with a website, and then sold it to techno-luddites like us. Now that their bubble is burst, Susannah and Trinny may be reduced to selling their melons at some market stall. I won't buy any, though.

*Flying to Sydney for the Olympic games this summer will be 300 British athletes - and 500 BBC journalists. Shurely shome mishtake? Nope. And what could be more appropriate than Auntie outnumbering the runners, swimmers and riders? Despite the schmaltzy music of Chariots of Fire and the rusty memories of Seb Coe, there are few people around the world who now identify Britannia with athletic prowess, steely muscles and bulging brawn. Today, we excel at watching sports, not doing them.

Cristina Odone is deputy editor of the New Statesman. Charlotte Raven is away.

webTitle: Women: Ultrasoundings: A cleaner way of having a child

fields.headline: A cleaner way of having a child
fields.standfirst: Kate Clanchy:   Ultrasoundings
fields.trailText: Kate Clanchy:   Ultrasoundings
fields.body:
Week 36

My perspective has changed. Also my centre of gravity: my bump is so heavy that when I walk, the weight throws my shoulders and head back. It makes the world seem distant, diminished. I can only just reach the handles of my bicycle. I turn the wheels at a snail's pace, straight-backed, just balanced, tranquil, holding the street at arm's length.

Everything inside the house, on the other hand, is much larger than usual. The dust on the stairs is bright white and as big as moon rocks. There is a jungle in the salad section of the fridge, a system of stalactites under the bath tap and a moss cave in the drain. All these things bother me enormously. They must be cleared out before the arrival of Baby, which suddenly seems a possible event. I think I've hit the nesting phase.

The trouble is, I'm not very good at housework. I have certain, odd domestic skills, the sort you learn as a singleton in an unserviced flat (I can unblock U-bends, for instance, and am a dab hand with an electric drill), but lack others. When I was growing up, I didn't trouble to learn to iron like my aunt, or sew like my grandmother, or hand wash like my mother - and I don't think many of my contemporaries did, either. In the new world girls were being prepared for, in which women would do men's work, no one, it seemed, was going to do women's work.

The professions we duly entered don't respect this work, either. Otherwise their hours would have shrunk in the past 20 years, not vastly expanded. We all know the result - households in which (mostly) women cram housework into crowded evenings or pay people from cultures that haven't yet forgotten how to iron.

When I was born, in 1965, my mother wasn't expected to work outside the home. Glasgow City Council, in fact, wouldn't give her a job as a teacher because she was married. This was wrong, but the same paternalistic council did acknowledge that, in bringing up my brother and giving birth to me, my mother was doing an important and demanding job.

The acknowledgment came in the form of a cleaner who was sent round the day after my birth and stayed for a fortnight. Her name was Mrs McKnight and she is one of the legends of my childhood. She cleaned, she made tea, she boiled nappies and hung them on the pulley, she minded my brother and arranged the vast quantities of food my grandmother delivered daily, all with shining efficiency. My parents rested upstairs with me, giggling.

But 1965 was the end of an era. My mother went on to be one of Glasgow's first working mothers and I was indirectly responsible for the privatisation of Mrs McKnight. My parents recommended her to a family who needed a nanny and she went, on an increased salary.

She wasn't replaced - in fact she probably had irreplaceable skills. English councils crossed housework off their list of important jobs at about the same time, though the Dutch, of course, being relentlessly better at all family things, still send help round after a home birth. I suppose the rest of us now have unpaid paternity leave instead.

T he quality of that kind of help depends, of course, on the father. Men have as little or less time than women to learn domestic skills. And strange shifts start happening in previously equal partnerships when a woman goes on maternity leave. Professional men work such long hours that they tend to view anyone not chained to the same desk as having a holiday. It is all too easy for them to resent domestic demands, especially when such work isn't quantified or valued - after all, hasn't the mother just been sitting around all day?

Men can also have domestic advantages, though. My husband is a far more efficient cleaner than I am, for instance, because he doesn't view the task through a miasma of mothers, grandmothers, guilt and children - he just sees a job to be done. When he comes home to find me scrubbing under the cooker, he simply thinks it's funny and gets out the squeezy mop to do it better. But then he's not eight months pregnant and can still view the kitchen from a height.

The dust on the stairs is bright white and as big as moon rocks. There is a jungle in the salad section of the fridge, a system of stalactites under the bath tap and a moss cave in the drain. All these things bother me enormously. They must be cleared out before the arrival of Baby, which suddenly seems a possible event. I think I've hit the nesting phase. The trouble is, I'm not very good at housework. I have certain, odd domestic skills, the sort you learn as a singleton in an unserviced flat (I can unblock U-bends, for instance, and am a dab hand with an electric drill), but lack others. When I was growing up, I didn't trouble to learn to iron like my aunt, or sew like my grandmother, or hand wash like my mother - and I don't think many of my contemporaries did, either. In the new world girls were being prepared for, in which women would do men's work, no one, it seemed, was going to do women's work. The professions we duly entered don't respect this work, either. Otherwise their hours would have shrunk in the past 20 years, not vastly expanded. We all know the result - households in which (mostly) women cram housework into crowded evenings or pay people from cultures that haven't yet forgotten how to iron. When I was born, in 1965, my mother wasn't expected to work outside the home. Glasgow City Council, in fact, wouldn't give her a job as a teacher because she was married. This was wrong, but the same paternalistic council did acknowledge that, in bringing up my brother and giving birth to me, my mother was doing an important and demanding job. The acknowledgment came in the form of a cleaner who was sent round the day after my birth and stayed for a fortnight. Her name was Mrs McKnight and she is one of the legends of my childhood. She cleaned, she made tea, she boiled nappies and hung them on the pulley, she minded my brother and arranged the vast quantities of food my grandmother delivered daily, all with shining efficiency. My parents rested upstairs with me, giggling. But 1965 was the end of an era. My mother went on to be one of Glasgow's first working mothers and I was indirectly responsible for the privatisation of Mrs McKnight. My parents recommended her to a family who needed a nanny and she went, on an increased salary. She wasn't replaced - in fact she probably had irreplaceable skills. English councils crossed housework off their list of important jobs at about the same time, though the Dutch, of course, being relentlessly better at all family things, still send help round after a home birth. I suppose the rest of us now have unpaid paternity leave instead. T he quality of that kind of help depends, of course, on the father. Men have as little or less time than women to learn domestic skills. And strange shifts start happening in previously equal partnerships when a woman goes on maternity leave. Professional men work such long hours that they tend to view anyone not chained to the same desk as having a holiday. It is all too easy for them to resent domestic demands, especially when such work isn't quantified or valued - after all, hasn't the mother just been sitting around all day? Men can also have domestic advantages, though. My husband is a far more efficient cleaner than I am, for instance, because he doesn't view the task through a miasma of mothers, grandmothers, guilt and children - he just sees a job to be done. When he comes home to find me scrubbing under the cooker, he simply thinks it's funny and gets out the squeezy mop to do it better. But then he's not eight months pregnant and can still view the kitchen from a height.

webTitle: Filipino kidnappers net millions

fields.headline: Filipino kidnappers net millions
fields.trailText: The Philippines' military chief has let slip that the equivalent of about £3.6m in ransom money has so far been paid to a southern rebel group who kidnapped a group of tourists from a Malaysian diving resort in April.
fields.body:
The Philippines' military chief has let slip that the equivalent of about £3.6m in ransom money has so far been paid to a southern rebel group who kidnapped a group of tourists from a Malaysian diving resort in April.

A senior civilian official later accused non-state organisations abroad and at home of making the payments, against Manila's better judgment.

General Angelo Reyes disclosed the sum at a cabinet meeting, but President Joseph Estrada cut him off because journalists were there covering the meeting: "We can talk about that privately, not in this forum," Mr Estrada said.

The Philippines says it has a no-ransom policy and officials have never publicly confirmed that large amounts have been paid to the Abu Sayyaf group.

They seized 21 foreign tourists and workers from the Sipadan resort on April 23. The hostages were taken to the island of Jolo in the southern Philippines by the rebels, who staged more abductions later.

In recent weeks the rebels have freed one German and six Malaysians from the Sipadan captives, along with a German journalist and two Filipino reporters. They also have released three people seized in other kidnappings.

Abu Sayyaf is the smaller of two groups who say they are fighting for a separate Islamic state in the southern Philippines. State officials consider that various forms of extortion are the groups' core activity.

The remaining hostages consist of six French, three Malaysians, two Germans, two Finns, two South Africans and 14 Filipinos. The Abu Sayyaf guerrillas have demanded $1m (£660,000) for each western hostage.

Presidential spokesman Ricardo Puno later toned down Gen Reyes's remarks, saying the Philippines maintained its no-ransom policy and that government negotiators would continue to talk to the Abu Sayyaf rebels "on that basis".

"But you know if people don't respect that policy ... then there is only a limited amount of control that you can maintain in that situation," Mr Puno said.

His meaning was clear: non-state organisations have been paying off the kidnappers on behalf of some captives. Local officials have referred to "backdoor negotiations" with rebels.

This was "unfortunate", Mr Punto said, "because we will be left holding the bag in terms of amounts that the Abu Sayyaf will be able to use in order to further kill, injure Filipino citizens and possibly continue their terroristic activities."

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Bomb scare at US mission
fields.body:
Bomb scare at US mission

A police bomb disposal unit in Johannesburg detonated two suspicious packages, including a tape recorder, delivered to the US consulate yesterday.

The incident occurred on the second anniversary of the day bomb blasts at the American embassies in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam killed 226 people and injured 4,000. Reuters, Johannesburg

Greeks launch murder hotline

The Greek police opened two confidential telephone lines yesterday in the hope of encouraging tips about Europe's most elusive terrorist organisation, November 17, which claims responsibility for the death of the British defence attache, Brigadier Stephen Saunders, in May.

The hotline was suggested by Scotland Yard officers who are in Athens to investigate the Saunders murder. AP, Athens

Fires consume a third of park

A forest fire which has burned 6,300 hectares (15,740 acres) of land in Gerona province in north-east Spain was slowly being brought under control yesterday as winds eased.

Xavier Pomes, interior minister of the Catalonia regional government, said 35% of the Cabo de Creus national park had been burned. AP, Madrid

Hutu ambush kills 32

Ethnic Hutu rebels killed 27 military cadets and five civilians on Sunday in an ambush near the Burundian capital Bujumbura, a military source said.

The cadets were returning from a handball match, he said. The civilians had "probably just asked for a lift". Reuters, Bujumbura

Prowling lions spark panic

Six lions escaped from a circus, causing panic in a Brazilian town yesterday but injured only a horse before they were shot dead, police said. The lions broke out of their cages and prowled for almost six hours through the small town of Sao Simao, 150 miles north-west of Sao Paulo. Reuters, Sao Paulo

webTitle: Passnotes: Zinedine Zidane

fields.headline: No: 1694
fields.standfirst: Zinedine Zidane
fields.trailText: Zinedine Zidane
fields.body:
Age: 28.

Distinguishing features: A small bald spot, prominent cheekbones, lantern jaw and strong, kissable lips. The erect posture and visionary footballing genius of an Eric Cantona wedded to the serene temperament of a Gary Lineker, with more than a hint of the withering steeliness of Sol Campbell. Brooding eyes, shadowed by long, curving, one might almost say Byronic, brows.

You fancy him, don't you? No.

Yes you do. Now why are we writing about the footballer known as "Zizou"? Because he has just been voted the most popular person in France, not least because this titan of the modern football game with the verve of a latter-day Johann Cruyff ...

Get on with it ... was instrumental in making French football great again by playing in the team that won the World Cup in 1998 and Euro 2000.

Who did he beat in the popularity poll? Catherine Deneuve, Jean-Paul Belmondo, Gerard Depardieu, Johnny Hallyday and an 88-year-old Capuchin abbot.

Fading actors, an ageing rock star - and who was that last bloke? Abbé Pierre, who won a place in French hearts for his work with the Emmaus charity, which he founded in 1949 to help the homeless. Zizou beat him into second place this year.

We don't really care about French popularity polls, do we? In this case, yes, we do. Mainly because Zizou's elevation is another slap in the face for racists who dislike the multicultural nature of France. In a recent survey, 60% of French people felt that there were too many Arabs in the country. "Ten years ago certain extremists would have seen this as a provocation," wrote the Journal du Dimanche this week, of Zidane's triumph in the poll.

What is Zidane's background? He was born on a rough council estate in Castellane, north Marseilles, to poor Algerian immigrants.

Any chance of him filling the Gallic gap in the Arsenal midfield left by Emmanuel Petit? Not unless they can stump up £20m or so.

Do say: "Zizou for president" (as French fans chanted in Paris after the World Cup victory).

Don't say: "Zizou for Tranmere."

webTitle: Velvet in the distance

fields.headline: Velvet in the distance
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Somerset
fields.body:
Somerset

The eight Camelot parishes are scattered amongst little hills and valleys. In summer, with leaves on the trees and the verges overgrown, paths and lanes become dark, winding tunnels. Round sharp bends, or over the brows of hills, or at the edge of a wood, they can open out, quite unexpectedly, into sudden and memorable views.

On a still Sunday morning we ventured, along one path that was enclosed like a cloister by a stone wall on one side and a row of overarching elms on the other. It opened on to a small churchyard perched on a terraced slope. We could hear the organ playing and voices singing a Matins hymn as we went softly round behind the church and came upon a view like a stage set. Pevsner writes of the "fine group of church above and house below" and there it was, directly in front of us, the classical facade of the house facing onto a lawn just below the churchyard. Table and chairs were set as if ready for the actors' entrances. We felt like intruders and crept away.

Down by the stream at Compton Pauncefoot, cattle stood like statues, completing the formal group - church and manor house by the green and Georgian rectory across smooth lawns. But the best of the morning's surprises was a view only just visible through the hedge from a footpath that wound through scrub and nettles nearby.

We passed a deserted quarry, source of the golden limestone of which much of the village is built. Blocks of stone lay in random heaps and shrubs were growing out of the quarry walls. A little further on, the hedge thinned to reveal a wide and shallow valley. In the middle distance, barely distinguishable from the surroundings at first because of their summer camouflage, pale fawn and dappled white, antlers still covered in velvet, stood a herd of fallow deer. They pricked up their ears, looked towards us, and froze in a tableau with Compton Castle and its park as backdrop - castellated Gothic splendour across lakes and sloping lawns, with a limp flag at the masthead. We froze too. Then the spell broke; the deer turned and leapt away kicking their heels.

webTitle: Analysts say cable group Telewest remains in takeover frame

fields.headline: Analysts say cable group Telewest remains in takeover frame
fields.trailText: Telewest shareholders were yesterday anxiously eyeing the cable television group's future, despite denials from a rival that the British firm had become a takeover target.
fields.body:
Telewest shareholders were yesterday anxiously eyeing the cable television group's future, despite denials from a rival that the British firm had become a takeover target.

Analysts said Microsoft and United GlobalCom-Liberty Media, which own 23.7% and 25% respectively of Telewest, would still be mulling merger possibilities even though the US group Callahan Associates over the weekend ruled out a hostile offer for the group.

With many arguing that an independent future for Telewest is unlikely, the shareholders' options seem to centre on a merger with NTL or United Pan European Communications, a subsidiary of UGC-Liberty Media. Microsoft also owns a share of NTL.

The outcome might follow a battle between Telewest's major shareholders because it is understood Microsoft would prefer to consolidate its stakes in both companies and speed the push into interactive television services in the UK rather than allow a merger of United GlobalCom-Liberty Media's interests.

Adam Singer, chief executive of Telewest, told analysts in briefings last week that NTL and Telewest were already planning to work more closely together by sharing purchasing costs for content and set-top boxes. This arrangement is expected to be viewed favourably by regulatory authorities with the imminent arrival of more competition.

The advent of ADSL technology will deliver high speed internet access, and video on demand and traditional television entertainment services down the telephone line. Telewest and NTL will face competition in the entertainment market from telecoms companies as well as traditional rival BSkyB.

Telecom companies are expected to bundle television, internet and telephone services when the broadcast ban is lifted in December 2001.

A Telewest spokesman insisted: "It's company policy not to comment on market speculation."

The concerns about Telewest's future follows a scathing report from HSBC late last month which said shareholders were misguidedly expecting "supernormal" returns from the British cable company.

The broker put a "sell" label on Telewest and said it had a poor track record of profits forecasts; for six years it had been announcing it expected to break even within three years.

HSBC set its target share price for Telewest at 143p and with 2008 as the date for the company to break even.

That report depressed the share price from around 260p to below 180p. Yesterday the stock was up 10p to 170p.

HSBC's concerns were underlined last week when Telewest revealed it would miss its targets for the roll-out of digital TV services by up to three months. Digital technology is seen as a prime revenue growth area for Telewest as existing analogue customers switch to new products and services.

Telewest had hoped to gain 500,000 digital customers by year-end but has now put that target back to the first quarter of 2001.

Some 80% of BSkyB's 4.5m strong customer base is now receiving digital services.

Telewest has 223,000 digital customers in a total TV subscriber base of 1.1m, which Mr Singer said put the company 18 months behind BSkyB.

The cable company also said its half-year pre-tax losses had deepened to £296m and revenues were up 35% to £514m.

Analysts said another scenario for a takeover of Telewest would be for UPC, Europe's second-biggest cable company, to make an all-share bid. However, HSBC has recommended Telewest not to accept such a bid because it would be a switch to a potentially "worse" cable stock.

webTitle: Kvaerner launches £384m hostile bid for Aker

fields.headline: Kvaerner launches £384m hostile bid for Aker
fields.trailText: Kvaerner, the Anglo-Norwegian engineering group, yesterday launched a 4.5bn-crown (£348m) hostile bid for its biggest shareholder in a bizarre twist to an increasingly bitter fight for survival.
fields.body:
Kvaerner, the Anglo-Norwegian engineering group, yesterday launched a 4.5bn-crown (£348m) hostile bid for its biggest shareholder in a bizarre twist to an increasingly bitter fight for survival.

The London-based but Oslo-listed group said its all-share offer for Aker Maritime would create the world's second largest oil and gas services company after Halliburton of the United States.

Last month Aker Maritime surprised Kvaerner by buying a 26% stake in it from the shipping group, Bergesen.

Aker Maritime is controlled by billionaire industrialist Kjell Inge Roekke, whose Aker RGI holding company also owns Wimbledon football club in south London.

Kvaerner said it was deeply unhappy about a competitor holding such an important stake in the company; it admitted its assault on Aker Maritime yesterday sought to reverse this situation.

But a Kvaerner spokeman claimed talks between the two about Kvaerner making a bid had been going on for 15 months. "We have made direct approaches for Aker on three occasions, the latest offer being put before the board in June. We believe Kvaerner oil and gas and Aker would make a good fit."

Aker RGI last night said the latest proposal did not reflect the true value of the company and had been put forward without discussion.

The spokeswoman pointed out an offer would need 90% of Aker Maritime shareholders to accept. Oslo analysts said the offer was generous, but probably not enough to convince Rokke to sell.

Both firms have offshore manufacturing yards in Britain and in the 1980s and 1990s both built most of the larger oil and gas platforms in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea.

However, driven by advances in technology, field operators are now producing more oil and gas from sub-acquatic structures, leaving Kvaerner and Aker with a great deal of spare capacity.

Merging the oil and gas businesses would save £20m a year in costs and create a business with 20,000 employees. Kvaerner has been struggling to recover from huge losses stemming from an ill-fated takeover of the British engineering group, Trafalgar House, which eventually led to senior executives departing.

New chief executive Kjell Almskog has been trying to dispose of the company's massive network of shipyards to concentrate on construction, engineering and oil and gas. He indicated that the Aker takeover might be the first of a number of acquisitions.

webTitle: AP Biotech moves to US

fields.headline: AP Biotech moves to US
fields.standfirst: Health group says Britain trails in race towards gene economy
fields.trailText: Hi-tech healthcare group Nycomed Amersham is shifting the headquarters of its £3bn biotechnology offshoot to America, on the grounds that Britain is lagging behind in the race towards the gene economy.
fields.body:
Hi-tech healthcare group Nycomed Amersham is shifting the headquarters of its £3bn biotechnology offshoot to America, on the grounds that Britain is lagging behind in the race towards the gene economy.

The business, Amersham Pharmacia Biotech, presently has joint bases in Norway and Buckinghamshire. The company intends to move its head office to Piscataway, New Jersey, to coincide with a flotation of a 10% stake on Nasdaq.

The government faced calls to step in yesterday, as the decision to relocate was dubbed "dreadful news" for British science. The business makes machines for the sequencing of the human genome, widely used by drugs companies and academics.

Nycomed's chief executive, Sir William Castell, said: "If you want to be a leader in this field in ten years' time, my belief is that your chances are greater if you're in the biggest market."

webTitle: The Grid gives up GPU

fields.headline: The Grid gives up GPU
fields.trailText: National Grid, the British electricity group, is understood to have decided not to pursue takeover talks with GPU, the US power company, which is up for sale.
fields.body:
National Grid, the British electricity group, is understood to have decided not to pursue takeover talks with GPU, the US power company, which is up for sale.

The decision leaves the way open for GPU to be bought by FirstEnergy, an Ohio-based utility group, in a $4.5bn (£3bn) deal that could create the largest electricity firm in the United States. A merger, which could be announced as early as today, would also be further evidence of increasing consolidation in the fragmented US energy market.

A spokeswoman for National Grid declined to comment on specific negotiations yesterday. However, the company is understood to be exploring takeover opportunities with other American companies with the intention of announcing a deal by the end of this year.

Among the possible partners are Energy East, a Connecticut-based company, or N Star in Massachusetts. Both companies are smaller than GPU, which was valued at $3.7bn yesterday after its shares rose on the back of takeover speculation.

National Grid has made it clear that it wants to buy a regional company in the US to expand its international presence.

webTitle: Scots firm snaps up Swalec

fields.headline: Scots firm snaps up Swalec
fields.standfirst: British Energy switches policy
fields.trailText: The UK power utility market experienced a further sea-change yesterday when British Energy, the nuclear generator, pulled out of the domestic electricity and gas supply market after selling Swalec to Scottish & Southern Energy for £210m.
fields.body:
The UK power utility market experienced a further sea-change yesterday when British Energy, the nuclear generator, pulled out of the domestic electricity and gas supply market after selling Swalec to Scottish & Southern Energy for £210m.

British Energy bought Swalec, based in south Wales, for just half the price (£107m) from Hyder, the Welsh multi-utility at the centre of a bidding war, a year ago but decided to focus on wholesale contracting and commercial customers after realising it would cost it £1bn or more to be a serious player in domestic supply.

Yesterday Hyder directors paved the way for further consolidation among UK utilities by switching allegiance and unanimously backing a £526m bid from Western Power, the US group that owns South-West Electricity (Sweb), having previously recommended the rival £495m offer from Japanese bank Nomura.

Yesterday's Swalec purchase propelled Scottish & Southern, which already owns Scottish Hydro-Electric and Southern Electric, into second position as electricity supplier and third spot as gas supplier by adding 850,000 electricity and 300,000 gas customers.

Observers expect Scottish & Southern to swoop for Northern Electric, now owned by Warren Buffett's Berkeley Hathaway investment vehicle, or - a less likely pair of options - Yorkshire Electric or Seeboard, the last of the small fry.

Scottish & Southern now rates behind Eastern, part of TXU, in electricity and British Gas (Centrica) and Eastern in gas. These three are likely to dominate the market with Scottish Power, owner of Manweb, PowerGen, Innogy (National Power) and EdF, French state owner of London Electricity, fighting it out for other leading positions.

Scottish finance director Ian Merchant said the group was paying double the price for Swalec because British Energy had bought it with a 10-year contract to purchase power from its part-owned Teesside plant and would maximise savings by linking its Welsh customers to its new IT systems. The deal would enhance earnings in the first year.

British Energy, which said Swalec made some £10m operating profits last year, is transferring 400 Welsh staff to Scottish & Southern and claimed the deal was worth £257m to it - enough to cover the cost of taking on the Bruce nuclear power plant in Canada. It would increase earnings by removing an annual £17m interest charge.

Its shares were unchanged at 256p while Scottish & Southern put on 9p to close at 584p. Hyder's shares, meanwhile, closed at 353p, signalling that investors still expect Nomura to increase its 320p offer to trump WPD's recommended 340p bid later this week. The Japanese bank has until Friday to act or pull out.

webTitle: Comment:  Mr Benn should reconsider the speakership

fields.headline: The two Tonys show would be much too good to miss
fields.standfirst:
Mr Benn should reconsider the speakership, and give the government a jolt

Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Mr Benn should reconsider the speakership, and give the government a jolt
fields.body:
Tony Benn's breakfast-time chat with Sue MacGregor yesterday did not, alas, sound very encouraging for those of his fans who would like to see him abandon his retirement plans and embark on a new career as speaker of the House of Commons. True, he didn't rule the idea out entirely. But there was - shall we say - a distinct absence of the driving enthusiasm that has marked earlier phases of his parliamentary career.

Even I - no great admirer of his role as leader of the loony left in the 1980s - confess to a twinge of regret about this. Let's face it, a Benn speakership would have been full of incident, and might possibly have made the House of Commons an interesting, even exciting, place again. At the very least, he would have jolted the prime minister and his minions into paying some attention to it, after three years of scandalous neglect.

Even more important, perhaps, he would have rekindled the interest of the newspapers in what goes on in the chamber of the House, in contradistinction to what goes on in the bedchambers of its members. We would have witnessed a return to real politics about real issues (or "ishoos", as Mr Benn prefers to call them) instead of tittle-tattle, rumours of sleaze and rows about spin doctors.

I suspect, for example, that Mr Speaker Benn would have given new life to the almost defunct standing order No 10 procedure - a glorious instrument for forcing ministers to answer for their conduct to MPs. When I first entered the press gallery in the Macmillan years, applications to adjourn the House under standing order 10 - "in order to debate a matter of urgent public importance" - were commonplace. What's more, they were quite frequently granted by the then speaker, a rather disembodied Tory lawyer called Harry Hylton-Foster.

When this happened, most of the day's scheduled business would be wiped out, to be replaced by a three-hour emergency debate on the "matter of urgent public importance". The responsible minister was expected to drop everything and dash to the Commons to defend himself. Among other things, it led to a series of riveting debates in which the ebullient George Brown laid waste to then home secretary Henry Brooke over - believe it or not - an asylum case. Not even today's blasé editors would have felt able to ignore such ready-made drama.

This drama, however, was somewhat undermined when subsequent speakers were persuaded by ministers to impose a 24-hour delay on the ensuing emergency debate. With time to consult his civil servants, the minister no longer appeared like a naughty schoolboy. Instead, he was able to stand up at the dispatch box clutching a full Sir Humphrey-style text. It was never the same again.

Hylton-Foster eventually died of a heart attack in Bond Street ("The only street in which he would have been seen dead," as one Tory wag put it) and his successors proved much less willing to grant applications under standing order 10. Sadly, this anti-libertarian trend began under the very first Labour speaker, Horace King, who took the chair soon after Wilson's election win in 1964.

Old 'orace, as everyone called him, was an improbable choice. Most people knew him as the man nursing a pint in the corner of the Strangers' Bar. A widowed school teacher who suddenly found himself all alone in the speaker's vast house, he used to come downstairs to "the Stranglers" for a jar with his old mates. He also visited the Strand Corner House occasionally, where he was once spotted giving an impromptu performance on the piano. The more pompous MPs were shocked by this conduct, and a deputation was sent to ask him to desist. Which the poor fellow duly did, with the result that he developed an attachment to hock - in his view, non- alcoholic - as he sat in his lonely lodgings.

Such was his enthusiasm for this fine German wine that it began to show. The wig began to slip rakishly, and he sometimes was seen - though no one dared say so - to have dropped off in the chair. On one occasion he attended a party in the press gallery, at which Michael Foot was a fellow guest. Mr Foot seized the opportunity to give 'orace some advice on what he should do to become a great speaker - including, I am pleased to say, a suggestion that he should grant more emergency debates.

Swaying slightly, Mr Speaker King replied sonorously: "I ought to have you crucified for addressing Mr Speaker like that." Then he dropped his voice and added: "But if they were ever to crucify Michael Foot, I would want to be on the next cross." "I knew it," cried Foot triumphantly, "Barabbas!"

But at least 'orace was a decent enough chap. Not so the next Labour speaker, George Thomas. A bachelor, he was known as "The Man from Mam" because he was always going on about his mother. He secured vast public fame because he was the first speaker ever to be heard by non-MPs uttering the mantra "Order, order!" when the proceeding of the Commons began to be broadcast on radio. But if he seemed loveable, it was an illusion. In the end, he betrayed most of his former colleagues on the Labour benches, and eventually became almost a Thatcher groupie.

So it was left to the incomparable Betty Boothroyd to redeem the good name of Labour and demonstrate that the people's party was capable of providing not just an adequate but an outstanding speaker. She may even have been the best speaker of my 30-odd years at Westminster. But I have considerable respect for her Tory predecessor, Bernard ("Jolly Jack") Weatherill, the ex-tailor who keeps a thimble in his waistcoat pocket to remind him of his origins. Best of all, he saw off the Iron Lady when she tried to steamroller her favourite, the sleekly handsome Humphrey Atkins, into the job. She never forgave him, and he never forgave her.

I suspect that Weatherill had always felt a slight outsider in the Tory party. But he didn't let it trouble him. One of his favourite stories was about his first day as an MP, when he proudly entered one of the lavatories marked "members only". Safely locked in a cubicle, he heard a voice boom: "Don't know what this place is comin' to, old boy. D'you know, I've just seen my tailor here?"

Theoretically, it should now be the turn of the Tories. But Buggins's turn is only a recent convention, and the current mood on the government benches seems to be that they want another Labour speaker. The danger, in that case, is that the whips will see to it that the winner is, well, more biddable than Betty. Which is why I hope someone can persuade Mr Benn to have a go, if nothing more. The two Tonys show is much too good to miss, and we might even get some real debates again.

webTitle: Business news in brief

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Inchcape buys UK car dealers
fields.body:
Inchcape buys UK car dealers

Inchcape, the automotive services group, is planning to spend £250m on buying car dealerships in the UK. The group believes there will be investment opportunities as the industry consolidates in the wake of the competition commission report on car pricing.

The group said that although first half pre-tax profits fell from £40.9m to £30m, it still had a strong balance sheet to fund growth.

CGNU recruits ethics experts

The fund management operation of newly merged insurance group CGNU yesterday stepped up its "socially responsible investment" team by hiring seven specialists from rival Henderson Investors.

The CGNU business, which uses the trade name Morley, set out its goal to become the leading player in ethical investments and said it would give clients a choice between socially responsible investment products or its more traditional approach.

Ofex tightens regulation

The Ofex market yesterday moved to tighten its notoriously light regulatory regime by clarifying its position on insider dealing and substantial share purchases.

Peter Freeman, group compliance director of the market run by stockbroker JP Jenkins, said instances of insider trading on Ofex would be included within the scope of the FSA regulator's civil and criminal regime.

Ofex companies will also be included in the Blue Book of the takeover panel, meaning companies buying large tranches of shares in Ofex-listed firms will have to declare their stakeholdings.

Fast fit tyre chain at risk

A fast-fit tyre chain has gone into receivership, threatening 840 jobs. Montinex of Shipley, west Yorkshire, is the largest independent fast-fit chain in the UK and operates 144 Charlie Browns Autocentres and subsidiaries under other names throughout Britain. Administrative receiver Ernst & Young said the plan was to continue business with the aim of selling the company as a going concern.

4,000 savers gain bonus

A banking watchdog yesterday ordered Bristol & West to raise the amount of interest it pays to thousands of savers with discontinued accounts - those no longer available to new customers.

More than 4,000 savers with the former building society will now get up to 31 times more interest. The Banking Code Standard Board said the announcement "shows we have got some teeth".

More all-night Asda stores

Supermarket group Asda is to create 800 jobs by increasing the number of its stores to open on a 24-hour basis. The move to build upon the number of all-night stores came as Asda's market share for the latest quarter hit a record 14.4%.

webTitle: Go may be cut from BA as price of deal

fields.headline: Go may be cut from BA as price of deal
fields.trailText: For regulators in Brussels the price of a merger with KLM could mean that Go, the low-cost airline established by British Airways in May 1998, is released from BA's clutches.
fields.body:
For regulators in Brussels the price of a merger with KLM could mean that Go, the low-cost airline established by British Airways in May 1998, is released from BA's clutches.

Rod Eddington hinted that the Stansted-based carrier could be cut free yesterday when he announced his company's second-quarter earnings.

He said "nothing has been ruled in or out" when it came to a decision on the future of Go. But he added that success or failure of talks with KLM had implications for Go.

Analysts believe BA will come under pressure from regulators to offload assets such as Go to win approval from the EU for a tie-up with the Dutch national flag carrier.

But KLM has its own low-cost airline Buzz that took over many of KLM's British routes and competes with Go. A sell-off would suit the British low-cost operator whose chief executive Barbara Cassani is understood to favour independence perhaps via a flotation.

Go has been extremely successful in opening new routes and bringing in passengers. No quarterly figures are given but it reported an unaudited pre-tax loss of £17m in the 12 months to March 2000.
